{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} [[File:GlobalTrade wheat coarse grain soy 2008 usda.png|300px|thumb|Chart of global trade volume in wheat, coarse grain and soybeans 1990 to 2008, and projected to 2016. [[United States Department of Agriculture]], 2008.]] [[File:Stocks to use ag Indicators market 1977 2007.png|300px|thumb|right|Chart of the United States stock to use ratio of soybeans, maize and wheat, from 1977 to 2007, and projected to 2016. United States Department of Agriculture, September 2007.]] [[File:FAO Food Price Index.png|300px|thumb|right|World food [[price index]], 1990–2012. Record high prices occurred during the food price crisis followed by another surge in prices since 2010. [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the United Nations.]]
World [[food prices]] increased dramatically in 2007 and the first and second quarter of 2008,<ref name=WFSFAO>{{cite web|title=World Food Situation|url=http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/en/|publisher=FAO|accessdate=24 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110429085859/http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/en/| archivedate= 29 April 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref> creating a [[International crisis|global crisis]] and causing political and [[Economic stability|economic instability]] and social unrest in both [[Poor countries|poor]] and [[Developed country|developed nations]]. Although the media spotlight focused on the riots that ensued in the face of high prices, the ongoing crisis of [[Food security|food insecurity]] had been years in the making.<ref name="ICTSD">[http://www.ictsd.org/themes/agriculture/research/how-do-food-prices-affect-producers-affect-producers-and-consumers-in How do Food Prices Affect Producers and Consumers in Developing Countries?], [[ICTSD]], Information Note Number 10, SEPTEMBER 2009</ref><ref name="FAO2009">UN Food and Agriculture Organization (2009). The State of Food Insecurity in the World 2009. Rome.</ref> Systemic causes for the worldwide increases in food prices continue to be the subject of debate. After peaking in the second quarter of 2008, prices fell dramatically during the [[late-2000s recession]] but increased during late 2009 and 2010, reaching new heights in 2011 and 2012 (see [[2010–12 world food price crisis]]) at a level slightly higher than the level reached in 2008.<ref name=WFSFAO /><ref>{{cite news |last=Rahman |first=M. Mizanur |date=11 August 2011 |title=Food price inflation: Global and national problem |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=198044 |newspaper=The Daily Star}}</ref> Over the next years, prices fell, reaching a low in March 2016 with the deflated [[FAO]] food price index close to pre-crisis level of 2006. Since then prices have been increasing, but as of 2017-05 they have not reached crisis levels again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/|title=FAO Food Price Index|accessdate=2017-05-02|publisher=FAO}}</ref>
The initial causes of the late-2006 price spikes included droughts in grain-producing nations and [[2000s energy crisis|rising oil prices]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/10/opinion/10thu1.html | work=The New York Times | title=The World Food Crisis | date=10 April 2008| accessdate=29 July 2011}}</ref> Oil price increases also caused general escalations in the costs of [[fertilizer]]s, food transportation, and [[industrial agriculture]]. Root causes may be the increasing use of [[biofuel]]s in developed countries (see also [[food vs fuel]]),<ref>{{cite news |date=11 April 2008 |title=Biofuels major cause of global food riots |url=http://www.inform.kz/showarticle.php?lang=eng&id=162989 |newspaper=Kazinform (Kazakhstan National Information Agency) |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126180447/http://www.inform.kz/showarticle.php?lang=eng&id=162989 |archive-date=26 January 2009}}</ref> and an increasing demand for a more varied diet across the expanding middle-class populations of Asia.<ref name="BBC16Oct2008">{{cite news |date=16 October 2008 |title=The cost of food: Facts and figures |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/7284196.stm |work=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Fear of rice riots as surge in demand hits nations across the Far East |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/consumer_goods/article3701347.ece |work=Times Online |location=London}}</ref> The [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] also raised concerns about the role of [[hedge fund]]s [[food speculation|speculating]] on prices leading to major shifts in prices.<ref>{{cite news |author=Katie Allen |date=18 July 2010 |title=Hedge funds accused of gambling with lives of the poorest as food prices soar |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/jul/19/speculators-commodities-food-price-rises |work=the Guardian}}</ref> These factors, coupled with falling world-food stockpiles, all contributed to the worldwide rise in food prices.<ref name="gm" />[[File:Wheat yields in developing countries 1951-2004.png|thumb|300px|Wheat yields in developing countries, 1950 to 2004, kg/HA baseline 500. The steep rise in [[crop yield]]s in the US began in the 1940s. The percentage of growth was fastest in the early rapid growth stage. In developed counties the yield growth slowdown has been less for maize than for wheat and soybeans. In developing countries maize yields are still rapidly rising.<ref>{{ Cite journal | last1 = Fischer | first1 =R. A. | last2 =Byerlee | first2 =Eric | last3 =Edmeades | first3 =E. O. | title = Can Technology Deliver on the Yield Challenge to 2050 | year = |journal=Expert Meeting on How to Feed the World |issue= |pages=12 |publisher= Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations | url = ftp://ftp.fao.org/docrep/fao/012/ak977e/ak977e00.pdf }}</ref>]]
==Drastic price increases== Between 2006 and 2008 average world prices for rice rose by 217%, wheat by 136%, [[maize|corn]] by 125% and soybeans by 107%.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} In late April 2008 rice prices hit 24 cents (US) per US pound, more than doubling the price in just seven months.<ref name=cyclone/>
===World population growth=== [[File:Food production per capita.svg|thumb|Growth in food production was greater than population growth since 1961.]] Although some commentators have argued that this food crisis stems from unprecedented [[World population|global]] [[population growth]],<ref>[http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/world-news/world-in-grip-of-food-crisis_10035221.html World in grip of food crisis]. ''IANS'', Thaindian News. 7 April 2008. </ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Burgonio |first=TJ |date=30 March 2008 |title=Runaway population growth factor in rice crisis—solon |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20080330-127349/Runaway-population-growth-factor-in-rice-crisissolon |newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |location=Manila |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150828190402/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20080330-127349/Runaway-population-growth-factor-in-rice-crisissolon |archive-date=28 August 2015}}</ref> others point out that world population [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories by fertility rate|growth rates]] have dropped dramatically since the 1980s,<ref> [https://www.census.gov/ipc/www/idb/worldpopinfo.html World Population Information]. United States Census Bureau. Data updated 27 March 2008. </ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/publications/Files/WPP2012_HIGHLIGHTS.pdf |title=World Population Prospects: The 2012 Revision |date=2013 |website=Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division |publisher=United Nations |format=PDF |page=4}}</ref> and grain availability has continued to outpace population.
To prevent price growth, food production should outpace population growth, which [[World population estimates|was about 1.2% per year]]. But there was a temporary drop in food production growth:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.earth-policy.org/datacenter/xls/indicator3_2013_03.xlsx |title=World Grain Production and Consumption, 1960–2012 |website=Earth Policy Institute |quote=The 2006 world grain harvest of 2,005 million tons, from the USDA Production, Supply, & Distribution database, was down 11 million tons from last year, or roughly 0.5%.}}</ref><ref>U.S. non-food corn use (ethanol). http://www.earth-policy.org/datacenter/xls/indicator3_2006_4.xls</ref> for example, wheat production during 2006 and 2007 [[International wheat production statistics|was 4% lower]] than that in 2004 and 2005.
World population has grown from 1.6 billion in 1900 to over 7.5 billion today.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.census.gov/population/international/ |title=International Programs |website=United States Census Bureau |access-date=7 December 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819022202/http://www.census.gov/population/international/ |archive-date=19 August 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldometers.info/world-population/ |title=World Population Clock: 7.3 Billion People (2015) – Worldometers |work=worldometers.info}}</ref>
===Increased demand for more resource intensive food=== The head of the [[International Food Policy Research Institute]], stated in 2008 that the gradual change in diet among newly prosperous populations is the most important factor underpinning the rise in global food prices.<ref>von Braun, "High and Rising Food Prices", 2008, p 5, slide 14</ref> Where food consumption has increased, it has largely been in processed ("[[value added]]") foods, sold in developing and developed nations.<ref> [http://www.fao.org/docrep/010/ai465e/ai465e04.htm "World cereal supply could improve in 2008/09"], [[Food and Agriculture Organization|FAO]]: Global cereal supply and demand brief, ''Crop Prospects and Food Situation'', No. 2., April 2008. The report notes that: "[O]n a per capita basis, wheat and rice consumption levels decline marginally in the developing countries, mostly in favour of higher intakes of more value-added food, especially in China." </ref> Total grain utilization growth since 2006 (up three percent, over the 2000–2006 per annum average of two percent) has been greatest in non-food usage, especially in feed and biofuels.<ref> [http://www.fao.org/docrep/010/ai465e/ai465e04.htm Crop Prospects and Food Situation, No. 2, April 2008]: Global cereal supply and demand brief, Growth in cereal utilization in 2007/08. ''Food and Agriculture Organization''. United Nations. April 2008. </ref><ref> [http://www.globalpolicy.org/socecon/hunger/general/2008/0303foodcrisis.htm Are We Approaching a Global Food Crisis? Between Soaring Food Prices and Food Aid Shortage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422035616/http://www.globalpolicy.org/socecon/hunger/general/2008/0303foodcrisis.htm |date=22 April 2009 }}. ''Katarina Wahlberg Global Policy Forum: World Economy & Development in Brief''. 3 March 2008.</ref>
One kilogram of beef requires seven kilograms of feed grain.<ref>[http://blogs.ft.com/wolfforum/2008/04/food-crisis-is-a-chance-to-reform-global-agriculture/#comment-11083 Comment] by [[Paul Collier]] on 2 May 2008 to the ''[[Financial Times]]'' ''The Economists' Forum'' blog post [http://blogs.ft.com/wolfforum/2008/04/food-crisis-is-a-chance-to-reform-global-agriculture "Food crisis is a chance to reform global agriculture]" by [[Martin Wolf]], 30 April 2008</ref> These reports, therefore, conclude that usage in industrial, feed, and input intensive foods, not population growth among poor consumers of simple grains, has contributed to the price increases. Rising meat consumption due to changes in lifestyle can in turn lead to higher energy consumption due to the higher energy-intensity of meat products, for example, one kilogram of meat uses about 19 times as much energy to produce it as the same amount of apple.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://truecostblog.com/2010/02/24/list-of-foods-by-environmental-impact-and-energy-efficiency/|title=List of Foods By Environmental Impact and Energy Efficiency|work=True Cost – Analyzing our economy, government policy, and society through the lens of cost-benefit}}</ref> {|class="wikitable" style="float:right;margin:0 0 1em 1em;" |+2005/1990 ratios of per-capita consumption<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ifpri.org/sites/default/files/publications/20080411jvbfoodprices.pdf |title="High and Rising Food Prices: Why Are They Rising, Who Is Affected, How Are They Affected, and What Should Be Done?" }}, presentation by Joachim von Braun to the [[U.S. Agency for International Development]] conference ''Addressing the Challenges of a Changing World Food Situation: Preventing Crisis and Leveraging Opportunity'', Washington, D.C., 11 April 2008, p. 3, slide 7</ref> |- ! ! India ! China ! Brazil ! Nigeria |- | Cereals | 1.0 | 0.8 | 1.2 | 1.0 |- | Meat | 1.2 | 2.4 | 1.7 | 1.0 |- | Milk | 1.2 | 3.0 | 1.2 | 1.3 |- | Fish | 1.2 | 2.3 | 0.9 | 0.8 |- | Fruits | 1.3 | 3.5 | 0.8 | 1.1 |- | Vegetables | 1.3 | 2.9 | 1.3 | 1.3 |}
Although the vast majority of the population in Asia remains rural and poor, the growth of the middle class in the region has been dramatic. For comparison, in 1990, the middle class grew by 9.7 percent in India and 8.6 percent in China, but by 2007 the [[Population growth rate|growth rate]] was nearly 30 percent and 70 percent respectively.<ref name="gm"/> The corresponding increase in Asian affluence also brought with it a change in lifestyle and eating habits, particularly a demand for greater variety, leading to increased competition with western nations for already strained agricultural resources.<ref name="BBC16Oct2008" /><ref>http://research.cibcwm.com/economic_public/download/smay08.pdf (hamburgers replacing rice bowls)</ref> This demand exacerbates dramatic increases in [[commodity]] prices such as oil.
Another issue with rising affluence in India and China was reducing the "shock absorber" of poor people who are forced to reduce their resource consumption when food prices rise. This reduced price elasticity and caused a sharp rise in food prices during some shortages. In the media, China is often mentioned as one of the main reasons for the increase in world food prices. However, China has to a large extent been able to meet its own demand for food, and even exports its surpluses in the world market.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ers.usda.gov/AmberWaves/June08/Features/ChinaFeed.htm |title=USDA ERS – Who Will China Feed?|author=Bryan Lohmar, Fred Gale |work=USDA}}</ref>
===Effects of petroleum and fertilizer price increases=== Starting in 2007, the prices of fertilizers of all kinds increased dramatically, peaking around the summer of 2008 (see graphs by the [[International Fertilizer Industry Association]]). Prices approximately tripled for [[ammonia]], [[urea]], [[diammonium phosphate]], [[muriate of potash]] (KCl), and [[sulfuric acid]] (used for making phosphate fertilizer), and then fell just as dramatically in the latter part of 2008. Some prices doubled within the six months before April 2008.<ref>{{cite news |date=16 April 2008 |title=Fertilizer cost rising sharply: Result will be higher food prices |url=http://www.sunherald.com/business/story/493854.html |newspaper=Sun Herald |agency=[[Associated Press]] |access-date=16 April 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421010500/http://www.sunherald.com/business/story/493854.html |archive-date=21 April 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Part of the cause for these price rises was the [[Oil price increases since 2003|rise in the price of oil]], since the most fertilizers require petroleum or natural gas to manufacture.<ref name="gm"/> Although the main fossil fuel input for fertilizer comes from natural gas to generate hydrogen for the [[Haber–Bosch process]] (see: [[Ammonia production]]), natural gas has its own supply problems similar to those for oil. Because natural gas can substitute for petroleum in some uses (for example, [[natural gas liquids]] and [[Fossil fuel power plant|electricity generation]]), increasing prices for petroleum lead to increasing prices for natural gas, and thus for fertilizer.
Costs for fertilizer raw materials other than oil, such as [[potash]], have been increasing<ref>[http://biz.yahoo.com/nytimes/080430/1194770341872.html?.v=6] Shortages Threaten Farmers' Key Tool: Fertilizer</ref> as increased production of staples increases demand. This is causing a boom (with associated volatility) in agriculture stocks.
The major [[International Food Policy Research Institute|IFPRI]] Report launched in February 2011 stated that the causes of the 2008 global food crisis were similar to that of the 1972–74 food crisis, in that the oil price and energy price was the major driver, as well as the shock to cereal demand (from biofuels this time), low interest rates, devaluation of the dollar, declining stocks, and some adverse weather conditions.<ref>[http://www.ifpri.org/sites/default/files/publications/rr165.pdf Reflections on the Global Food Crisis: How Did It Happen? How Has It Hurt? And How Can We Prevent the Next One?<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Unfortunately the IFPRI states that such shocks are likely to recur with several shocks in the future; compounded by a long history of neglecting agricultural investments.
===Declining world food stockpiles=== In the past, nations tended to keep more sizable food stockpiles, but more recently, due to a faster pace of food growth and ease of importation, less emphasis is placed on high stockpiles. For example, in February 2008 wheat stockpiles hit a 60-year low in the United States (see also [[Rice shortage]]).<ref name="gm"/> Data stocks are often calculated as a residual between Production and Consumption but it becomes difficult to discriminate between a de-stocking policy choices of individual countries and a deficit between production and consumption.
===Financial speculation=== Destabilizing influences, including indiscriminate lending and real estate speculation, led to a [[Black Monday (January 2008)|crisis in January 2008]], and eroded investment in food commodities.<ref name="gm"/>
Foreign investment drives productivity improvements, and other gains for farmers.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Barrows, Roth|title=Land Tenure and Investment in African Agriculture: Theory and Evidence|journal=The Journal of Modern African Studies|year=1990|volume=20|issue=2|pages=265–297|doi=10.1017/S0022278X00054458}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unescap.org/pdd/publications/apdj_10_2/mahadevan.pdf |title=Productivity Growth in Indian Agriculture: The Role of Globalization and Economic Reform |date=December 2003 |website=United Nations ESCAP |accessdate=18 December 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Linking Globalization, Economic Growth and Poverty: Impacts of Agribusiness Strategies on Sub-Saharan Africa|journal=American Journal of Agricultural Economics|date=August 2001|volume=83|issue=3|pages=722–729|jstor=1245106|doi=10.1111/0002-9092.00197 | last1 = Weatherspoon | first1 = Dave}}</ref>
==== Commodity index funds ==== {{main|Commodity index fund}} Goldman Sachs' entry into the commodities market via the [[S&P GSCI|Goldman Sachs Commodity Index]] has been implicated by some in the 2007–2008 world food price crisis. In a 2010 article in Harper's magazine, Frederick Kaufman accused Goldman Sachs of profiting while many people went hungry or even starved. He argued that Goldman's large purchases of long-options on wheat futures created a [[demand shock]] in the wheat market, which disturbed the normal relationship between [[supply and demand]] and price levels. He argues that the result was a '[[contango]]' wheat market on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which caused prices of wheat to rise much higher than normal, defeating the purpose of the exchanges (price stabilization) in the first place.<ref>[http://www.harpers.org/archive/2010/07/0083022 The Food Bubble: How Wall Street Starved Millions and got away with it], by Frederick Kaufman, Harper's, 2010 July</ref><ref>[http://www.pacificfreepress.com/news/1/6629-the-great-food-bubble-swindle-starving-the-multitudes-for-fun-and-profit.html Democracy Now (radio show)], Amy Goodman and Juan Gonzales, Interview with Frederick Kaufman, 2010 7 17</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pacificfreepress.com/news/1/6154-a-global-food-bubble.pdf |title=Global Food Bubble |date=6 May 2010|publisher=Pacific Free Press |author=TRNN – Jayati Ghosh |accessdate=30 July 2010}}</ref> however, a report by the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] – using data from the [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]] – showed tracking funds (of which Goldman Sachs Commodity Index was one) did not cause the bubble. For example, the report points out that even commodities without futures markets also saw price rises during the period.<ref>[http://www.economist.com/research/articlesBySubject/displaystory.cfm?subjectid=2512631&story_id=16432870 Clearing the usual suspects], Buttonwood, The Economist, 2010 6 24</ref> Some commodities ''without'' futures markets saw their prices rise as a consequence of the rising prices of commodities ''with'' futures markets: the World Development Movement states there is strong evidence that the rising price of wheat caused the price of rice to subsequently rise as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wdm.org.uk/sites/default/files/Tricky%20questions_06.10%20FINAL.pdf |title=WDM food speculation campaign: Questions and answers |website=World Development Movement |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403113921/http://www.wdm.org.uk/sites/default/files/Tricky%20questions_06.10%20FINAL.pdf |archive-date=3 April 2013}}</ref>
===Effects of trade liberalization=== Some theorists, such as [[Martin Khor]] of the [[Third World Network]],<ref name="MK">[[Martin Khor|Khor, Martin]]. ''[http://www.twnside.org.sg/title2/books/Ghanarevised.htm The Impact of Trade Liberalisation on Agriculture in Developing Countries: The Experience of Ghana]'', [[Third World Network]](2008) {{ISBN|978-983-2729-31-0}}</ref> point out that many developing nations have gone from being food independent to being net food importing economies since the 1970s and 1980s [[International Monetary Fund]] (and later the [[World Trade Organization]]'s [[Agreement on Agriculture]]) [[free market economics]] directives to debtor nations. In opening developing countries to [[developed world]] food imports subsidised by Western governments, [[developing nations]] can become more dependent upon food imports if local agriculture does not improve.<ref name="MK"/><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Moseley | first1 = W.G. | last2 = Carney | first2 = J. | last3 = Becker | first3 = L. | year = 2010 | title = Neoliberal Policy, Rural Livelihoods and Urban Food Security in West Africa: A Comparative Study of The Gambia, Côte d'Ivoire and Mali | url = | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 107 | issue = 13| pages = 5774–5779 | doi=10.1073/pnas.0905717107| pmc = 2851933 }}</ref>
While developed countries pressured the developing world to abolish subsidies in the interest of trade liberalization, rich countries largely kept subsidies in place for their own farmers. In recent years United States government subsidies have been added to push production toward biofuel rather than food and vegetables .<ref name="gm"/>
===Effects of food for fuel=== {{Main|Food vs fuel}} One systemic cause for the price rise is held to be the diversion of food crops (maize in particular) for making [[first-generation biofuel]]s.<ref>[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2008/04/19/stories/2008041950260800.htm Paying the price for ignoring the real economy G. CHANDRASHEKHAR] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090213005213/http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2008/04/19/stories/2008041950260800.htm |date=13 February 2009 }}, [[The Hindu]], 18 April 2008.</ref> An estimated 100 million tons of grain per year are being redirected from food to fuel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planetark.com/dailynewsstory.cfm/newsid/43377/newsDate/31-Jul-2007/story.htm |title=Planet Ark : Biofuels to Keep Global Grain Prices High – Toepfer |publisher=Planetark.com |accessdate=3 October 2008}}</ref> (Total worldwide grain production for 2007 was just over 2000 million tons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldwatch.org/node/5539 |title=Grain Harvest Sets Record, But Supplies Still Tight | Worldwatch Institute |publisher=Worldwatch.org |accessdate=3 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080922231702/http://www.worldwatch.org/node/5539| archivedate= 22 September 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref>) As farmers devoted larger parts of their crops to fuel production than in previous years, land and resources available for food production were reduced correspondingly.
This has resulted in less food available for human consumption, especially in [[Developing country|developing]] and [[least developed countries]], where a family's daily allowances for food purchases are extremely limited. The crisis can be seen, in a sense, to dichotomize [[North-South divide|rich and poor nations]], since, for example, filling a tank of an average car with [[biofuel]], amounts to as much maize (Africa's principal food staple) as an African person consumes in an entire year.<ref name="gm">{{cite news |last=Reguly |first=Eric |date=12 April 2008 |title=How the cupboard went bare |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com//servlet/story/LAC.20080412.FOOD12/TPStory/International/ |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415055334/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20080412.FOOD12/TPStory/International/ |archive-date=15 April 2008}}</ref>
Brazil, the world's second largest producer of ethanol after the US, is considered to have the world's first sustainable biofuels economy<ref name="Apollo">{{Cite journal |author1=Inslee, Jay |author2=Bracken Hendricks | title = Apollo's Fire | year = 2007 | pages=153–155, 160–161 | publisher = [[Island Press]], Washington, D.C. | id = . ''See Chapter 6. Homegrown Energy.'' | postscript = <!--None--> | isbn = 978-1-59726-175-3 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/10/world/americas/10brazil.html?pagewanted=1&sq=Bush%20Brazil%20ethanol&st=nyt&scp=5 |title=With Big Boost From Sugar Cane, Brazil Is Satisfying Its Fuel Needs |author=Larry Rother|work=The New York Times|date=10 April 2006|accessdate=28 April 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090425044808/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/10/world/americas/10brazil.html?pagewanted=1&sq=Bush%20Brazil%20ethanol&st=nyt&scp=5| archivedate=25 April 2009| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="Econon06_08">{{cite news |date=26 June 2008 |title=Biofuels in Brazil: Lean, green and not mean |url=http://www.economist.com/node/11632886 |work=The Economist |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120221121038/http://www.economist.com/node/11632886 |archive-date=21 February 2012 |accessdate=30 July 2008}}</ref> and its government claims Brazil's sugar cane based ethanol industry has not contributed to the 2008 food crises.<ref name="Econon06_08"/><ref name="Veja_30_04">{{Cite news|url=http://veja.abril.com.br/300408/p_058.shtml |title=Ele é o falso vilão |author=Julia Duailibi |work=Veja Magazine |language=Portuguese |date=27 April 2008 |accessdate=28 April 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506103110/http://veja.abril.com.br/300408/p_058.shtml |archivedate=6 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> A [[World Bank]] policy research working paper released in July 2008<ref name="WorldBank_07_08">{{Cite web | url=http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/IW3P/IB/2008/07/28/000020439_20080728103002/Rendered/PDF/WP4682.pdf|format=PDF|title=A note on Rising Food Crisis|publisher=[[The World Bank]]| author=Donald Mitchell |accessdate=29 July 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080819214631/http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/IW3P/IB/2008/07/28/000020439_20080728103002/Rendered/PDF/WP4682.pdf| archivedate= 19 August 2008| deadurl= no |date=July 2008}}Policy Research Working Paper No. 4682. Disclaimer: This paper reflects the findings, interpretation, and conclusions of the authors, and do not necessarily represent the views of the World Bank</ref> concluded that "...large increases in biofuels production in the United States and Europe are the main reason behind the steep rise in global food prices", and also stated that "Brazil's sugar-based ethanol did not push food prices appreciably higher".<ref name="Veja_28_07">{{Cite news |url=http://vejaonline.abril.com.br/notitia/servlet/newstorm.ns.presentation.NavigationServlet?publicationCode=1&pageCode=1&textCode=145568&date=currentDate |title=Etanol não influenciou nos preços dos alimentos |publisher=[[Editora Abril]] |work=[[Veja (magazine)|Veja Magazine]] |language=Portuguese |date=28 July 2008 |accessdate=29 July 2008 |archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160519034021/http://vejaonline.abril.com.br/notitia/servlet/newstorm.ns.presentation.NavigationServlet?publicationCode=1&pageCode=1&textCode=145568&date=currentDate |archive-date=19 May 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Reuters">{{Cite news|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N28615016.htm|title=Biofuels major driver of food price rise-World Bank |publisher=Reuters|date=28 July 2008|accessdate=29 July 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080829070302/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N28615016.htm| archivedate= 29 August 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref> An economic assessment published in July 2008 by the [[OECD]]<ref name="OECD_07_08"/> disagrees with the World Bank report regarding the negative effects of subsidies and trade restrictions, finding that the effect of biofuels on food prices are much smaller.<ref name="OECDweb08"/>
A report released by [[Oxfam]] in June 2008<ref name="Oxfampdf">{{Cite web |url=http://www.oxfam.org/files/bp114-inconvenient-truth-biofuels-0806.pdf |format=PDF |title=Another Inconvenient Truth: Biofuels are not the answer to climate or fuel crisis |website=[[Oxfam]] |author=Oxfam |date=25 June 2008 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080819214631/http://www.oxfam.org/files/bp114-inconvenient-truth-biofuels-0806.pdf |archivedate= 19 August 2008 |accessdate=30 July 2008}} Report available in pdf</ref> criticized biofuel policies of rich countries and concluded that, of all biofuels available in the market, Brazilian sugarcane ethanol is "far from perfect" but it is the most favorable biofuel in the world in term of cost and [[Greenhouse gas|GHG]] balance. The report discusses some existing problems and potential risks and asks the Brazilian government for caution to avoid jeopardizing its environmental and social sustainability. The report also says that: "Rich countries spent up to $15 billion last year supporting biofuels while blocking cheaper Brazilian ethanol, which is far less damaging for global [[food security]]."<ref name="Oxfam08">{{Cite web |url=http://www.oxfam.org/pressroom/pressrelease/2008-06-25/another-inconvenient-truth-biofuels-are-not-answer |title=Another Inconvenient Truth: Biofuels are not the answer to climate or fuel crisis |publisher=[[Oxfam]] |author=Oxfam |date=26 June 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081031143804/http://www.oxfam.org/pressroom/pressrelease/2008-06-25/another-inconvenient-truth-biofuels-are-not-answer |archive-date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=30 July 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/portuguese/reporterbbc/story/2008/06/080625_biocombustiveisrelatorio.shtml|title=ONG diz que etanol brasileiro é melhor opção entre biocombustíveis |publisher=BBCBrasil|language=Portuguese |date=25 June 2008|accessdate=30 July 2008}}</ref> (See [[Ethanol fuel in Brazil]])
German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] said the rise in food prices is due to poor agricultural policies and changing eating habits in developing nations, not biofuels as some critics claim.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/environmentNews/idUSL1721113520080417?feedType=RSS&feedName=environmentNews |title= Bad policy, not biofuel, drive food prices: Merkel|author=Gernot Heller |publisher= Reuters|date=17 April 2008|accessdate=1 May 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080430000738/https://www.reuters.com/article/environmentNews/idUSL1721113520080417?feedType=RSS&feedName=environmentNews| archivedate= 30 April 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref> On 29 April 2008, US President [[George W. Bush]] declared during a press conference that "85 percent of the world's food prices are caused by weather, increased demand and energy prices", and recognized that "15 percent has been caused by ethanol".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2008/04/20080429-1.html |title=Press Conference by the President |publisher= The White House|date=29 April 2008|accessdate=1 May 2008}}</ref> On 4 July 2008, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that a leaked World Bank report estimated the rise in food prices caused by biofuels to be 75%.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/jul/03/biofuels.renewableenergy | title=Secret report: biofuel caused food crisis| date=4 July 2008|work=The Guardian |location=London | first=Aditya | last=Chakrabortty | accessdate=22 April 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100417165950/http://www.guardian.co.uk/environment/2008/jul/03/biofuels.renewableenergy| archivedate= 17 April 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref> This report was officially released in July 2008.<ref name="WorldBank_07_08"/>
Since reaching record high prices in June 2008, corn prices fell 50% by October 2008, declining sharply together with other commodities, including oil. As ethanol production from corn has continued at the same levels, some have argued this trend shows the belief that the increased demand for corn to produce ethanol was mistaken. "Analysts, including some in the ethanol sector, say ethanol demand adds about 75 cents to $1.00 per bushel to the price of corn, as a rule of thumb. Other analysts say it adds around 20 percent, or just under 80 cents per bushel at current prices. Those estimates hint that $4 per bushel corn might be priced at only $3 without demand for ethanol fuel."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/oilRpt/idUKN2338007820081023|title=Ethanol no longer seen as big driver of food price|author=Sam Nelson|publisher=Reuters UK|date=23 October 2008|accessdate=26 November 2008}}</ref> These industry sources consider that a [[speculative bubble]] in the [[commodity markets]] holding positions in corn [[Futures contract|futures]] was the main driver behind the observed hike in corn prices affecting food supply.
Second- and third-generation biofuels (such as [[cellulosic ethanol]] and [[algae fuel]], respectively) may someday ease the competition with food crops, as can grow on marginal lands unsuited for food crops, but these advanced biofuels require further development of farming practices and refining technology; in contrast, ethanol from maize uses [[mature technology]] and the maize crop can be shifted between food and fuel use quickly.
===Biofuel subsidies in the US and the EU=== The World Bank lists the effect of biofuels as an important contributor to higher food prices.<ref>[http://go.worldbank.org/3YYF4BOSN0 "The Effects of High Food Prices in Africa – Q&A"], [[World Bank]]. Retrieved 6 May 2008</ref> The [[FAO]]/ECMB has reported that world land usage for agriculture has declined since the 1980s, and subsidies outside the United States and EU have dropped since the year 2004, leaving supply, while sufficient to meet 2004 needs, vulnerable when the United States began converting agricultural commodities to [[biofuels]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Corcoran |first=Katherine |date=24 March 2008 |title=Food Prices Soaring Worldwide |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hY6QytGQclZ5k8yFlaDr0VZin6IwD8VJULF00 |newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080331195822/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5hY6QytGQclZ5k8yFlaDr0VZin6IwD8VJULF00 |archive-date=31 March 2008}}</ref> According to the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] (USDA), global wheat imports and stocks have decreased, domestic consumption has stagnated, and world wheat production has decreased from 2006 to 2008.<ref>[http://www.fas.usda.gov/psdonline/psdgetreport.aspx?hidReportRetrievalName=BVS&hidReportRetrievalID=686&hidReportRetrievalTemplateID=8 Regional Wheat Imports, Production, Consumption, and Stocks (Thousand Metric Tons)], United States Department of Agriculture Foreign Agricultural Service 3 November 2008.</ref>
In the United States, government subsidies for ethanol production have prompted many farmers to switch to production for biofuel. Maize is the primary crop used for the production of ethanol, with the United States being the biggest producer of maize ethanol. As a result, 23 percent of United States maize crops were being used for ethanol in 2006–2007 (up from 6 percent in 2005–2006), and the USDA expects the United States to use 81 million tons of maize for ethanol production in the 2007–2008 season, up 37 percent.<ref>[http://www.globalpolicy.org/socecon/hunger/general/2008/0303foodcrisis.htm Are We Approaching a Global Food Crisis? Between Soaring Food Prices and Food Aid Shortage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422035616/http://www.globalpolicy.org/socecon/hunger/general/2008/0303foodcrisis.htm |date=22 April 2009 }}. Katarina Wahlberg Global Policy Forum: World Economy & Development in Brief, 3 March 2008.</ref> This not only diverts grains from food, but it diverts agricultural land from food production.
Nevertheless, supporters of ethanol claim that using [[maize|corn]] for ethanol is not responsible for the worst [[food riot]]s in the world, many of which have been caused by the price of rice and oil, which are not affected by biofuel use but rather by supply and demand.
However, a World Bank policy research working paper released in July 2008<ref name="WorldBank_07_08" /> says that [[biofuel]]s have raised food prices between 70 and 75 percent. The study found that higher oil prices and a weak dollar explain 25–30% of total price rise. The "month-by-month" five-year analysis disputes that increases in global grain consumption and droughts were responsible for price increases, reporting that this had had only a marginal effect and instead argues that the EU and US drive for biofuels has had by far the biggest effect on food supply and prices. The paper concludes that increased production of biofuels in the US and EU were supported by subsidies and tariffs on imports, and considers that without these policies, price increases would have been smaller. This research also concluded that Brazil's sugar cane based ethanol has not raised sugar prices significantly, and suggest to remove tariffs on ethanol imports by both the US and EU, to allow more efficient producers such as Brazil and other developing countries to produce ethanol profitably for export to meet the mandates in the EU and the US.<ref name="Veja_28_07" /><ref name="Reuters" />
The Renewable Fuel Association (RFA) published a rebuttal based on the version leaked before the formal release of the World Bank's paper.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/jul/03/biofuels.renewableenergy|title=Secret report: biofuel caused food crisis|author=Aditya Chakrabortty |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=4 July 2008|accessdate=29 July 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080729083527/http://www.guardian.co.uk/environment/2008/jul/03/biofuels.renewableenergy| archivedate= 29 July 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref> The RFA critique considers that the analysis is highly subjective and that the author "estimates the effect of global food prices from the weak dollar and the direct and indirect effect of high petroleum prices and attributes everything else to biofuels."<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ethanolrfa.org/objects/documents/1812/lecg_work_bank_critique.pdf |format=PDF |title=Critique of World Bank Working Paper "A Note of Rising Food Prices" |author=John M. Urbanchuk |date=11 July 2008 |publisher=Renewable Fuel Association |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819214631/http://www.ethanolrfa.org/objects/documents/1812/lecg_work_bank_critique.pdf |archivedate=19 August 2008 |accessdate=29 July 2008}}</ref>
An economic assessment report also published in July 2008 by the [[OECD]]<ref name="OECD_07_08">{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/19/62/41007840.pdf |format=PDF |title=Economic Assessment of Biofuel Support Policies |author=Directorate for Trade and Agriculture, OECD |publisher=[[OECD]] |date=16 July 2008 |accessdate=1 August 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080718170926/http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/19/62/41007840.pdf |archivedate=18 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Disclaimer: This work was published under the responsibility of the Secretary-General of the OECD. The views expressed and conclusions reached do not necessarily correspond to those of the governments of OECD member countries.</ref> agrees with the World Bank report regarding the negative effects of subsidies and trade restrictions, but found that the effect of biofuels on food prices are much smaller. The OECD study is also critical of the limited reduction of [[Greenhouse gas|GHG]] emissions achieved from biofuels produced in Europe and North America, concluding that the current biofuel support policies would reduce greenhouse gas emissions from transport fuel by no more than 0.8 percent by 2015, while Brazilian ethanol from sugar cane reduces greenhouse gas emissions by at least 80 percent compared to fossil fuels. The assessment calls on governments for more open markets in biofuels and feedstocks to improve efficiency and lower costs.<ref name="OECDweb08">{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/document/28/0,3343,en_2649_37401_41013916_1_1_1_1,00.html|title=Biofuel policies in OECD countries costly and ineffective, says report |author=Directorate for Trade and Agriculture, OECD |publisher=[[OECD]]|date=16 July 2008|accessdate=1 August 2008}}</ref>
===Idled farmland=== According to the ''New York Times'' on 9 April 2008, the United States government pays farmers to [[fallow|idle their cropland]] under a conservation program. This policy reached a peak of {{convert|36800000|acre|km2}} idled in 2007, that is 8% of cropland in United States, representing a total area bigger than the state of New York.<ref>"As Prices Rise, Farmers Spurn Conservation Program" New York Times 9 April 2008. In England thousands of acres of land were "set-a-side" in hope to encourage wild birds and insects. This has had detrimental effects on the amount of food in England. Stockpiles of grain is virtually nil, which has made the price of bread excel over the past couple of months.</ref>
===Agricultural subsidies=== The global food crisis has renewed calls for removal of distorting [[agricultural subsidy|agricultural subsidies]] in developed countries.<ref>[http://www.euractiv.com/en/sustainability/food-crisis-set-weigh-cap-reform/article-172484 Food crisis set to weigh on CAP Reform] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609192138/http://www.euractiv.com/en/sustainability/food-crisis-set-weigh-cap-reform/article-172484 |date=9 June 2011 }}, EurActiv, 20 May 2008</ref> Support to farmers in OECD countries totals 280 billion USD annually, which compares to official development assistance of just 80 billion USD in 2004, and farm support depresses global food prices, according to OECD estimates.<ref>[http://www.oecd.org/document/45/0,2340,fr_2649_201185_35738477_1_1_1_1,00.html Doha Development Round, Understanding the Issues] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612183045/http://www.oecd.org/document/45/0%2C2340%2Cfr_2649_201185_35738477_1_1_1_1%2C00.html |date=12 June 2008 }} OECD, Doha Development Round</ref> These [[agricultural subsidies]] lead to underdevelopment in rural developing countries, including the [[least developed countries]]; meanwhile subsidised food increases [[overconsumption]] in developed countries. The US Farm Bill brought in by the Bush Administration in 2002 increased agricultural subsidies by 80% and cost the US taxpayer 190 billion USD.<ref>[http://www.foodfirst.org/node/52 Giving away the farm, the 2002 Farm Bill] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624223823/http://www.foodfirst.org/node/52 |date=24 June 2008 }} Food First, 8 July 2002</ref> In 2003, the EU agreed to extend the [[Common Agricultural Policy]] until 2013. Former UNDP Administrator Malloch Brown renewed calls for reform of the farm subsidies such as the CAP.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/may/10/food.unitednations Perfect Storm, The Rocketing Price of Food] Guardian, 10 May 2008</ref>
===Distorted global rice market=== Japan is forced to import more than 767,000 tons of rice annually from the United States, Thailand, and other countries due to [[WTO]] rules,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unctad.org/infocomm/anglais/rice/ecopolicies.htm#japon |title=Japan rice policy |website=United Nations Conference on Trade and Development |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130131309/http://www.unctad.org/infocomm/anglais/rice/ecopolicies.htm#japon |archive-date=30 January 2012}}</ref> although Japan produces over 100% of domestic rice consumption needs with 11 million tons produced in 2005 while 8.7 million tons were consumed in 2003–2004 period.{{citation needed|date=October 2008}} Japan is not allowed to re-export this rice to other countries without approval. This rice is generally left to rot and then used for [[Fodder|animal feed]]. Under pressure, the United States and Japan are poised to strike a deal to remove such restrictions. It is expected 1.5 million tons of high-grade American rice will enter the market soon.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Leo |date=17 May 2008 |title=Japan's silos key to relieving rice shortage |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/consumer_goods/article3948493.ece |newspaper=[[The Times]] |location=London |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612060238/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/consumer_goods/article3948493.ece |archive-date=12 June 2011}}</ref>
===Crop shortfalls from natural disasters=== Several distinct weather- and climate-related incidents have caused disruptions in crop production. Perhaps the most influential is the [[Drought in Australia#Rainfall deficiencies in 2006|extended drought in Australia]], in particular the fertile [[Murray-Darling Basin]], which produces large amounts of wheat and rice. The drought has caused the annual rice harvest to fall by as much as 98% from pre-drought levels.<ref> [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/17/business/worldbusiness/17warm.html?n=Top/News/Science/Topics/Global%20Warming Drought in Australia reduces Australia’s rice crop by 98 percent.] The New York Times, 17 April 2008. </ref>
Australia is historically the second-largest exporter of wheat after the United States, producing up to 25 million tons in a good year, the vast majority for export. However, the 2006 harvest was 9.8 million.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7289194.stm "Australia's food bowl lies empty"], ''BBC News'', 11 March 2008</ref> Other events that have negatively affected the price of food include the [[2006 North American heat wave|2006 heat wave]] in California's [[San Joaquin Valley]], which killed large numbers of farm animals, and unseasonable 2008 rains in [[Kerala]], India, which destroyed swathes of grain. These incidents are consistent with the effects of [[climate change]].<ref> [http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/GlobalWarming/Story?id=2277893&page=1 Food Prices Could Rise as Farmers in California's Prolific San Joaquin Valley Feel the Effects of Global Warming] ABC News, 5 August 2006. </ref><ref> [http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/Economy/Rs_39333_cr_in_crops_lost_due_to_rains/articleshow/2935708.cms Crops lost due to unseasonal rains in Kerala] The Economic Times, 8 April 2008. </ref>
The effects of [[Cyclone Nargis]] on Burma in May 2008 caused a spike in the price of rice. Burma has historically been a rice exporter, though yields have fallen as government [[price controls]] have reduced incentives for farmers. The [[storm surge]] inundated rice paddies up to {{convert|30|mi|km}} inland in the [[Irrawaddy Delta]], raising concern that the salt could make the fields infertile. The FAO had previously estimated that Burma would export up to 600,000 tons of rice in 2008, but concerns were raised in the cyclone's aftermath that Burma may be forced to import rice for the first time, putting further upward pressure on global rice prices.<ref name=cyclone>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7387251.stm "Cyclone fuels rice price increase"], ''BBC News'', 7 May 2008</ref><ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/07/AR2008050700642.html?hpid=topnews "Scant Aid Reaching Burma's Delta"] by Amy Kazmin and Colum Lynch, ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 8 May 2008</ref>
[[Stem rust]] reappeared in 1998<ref name=cornell>{{cite web |url=http://www.wheatrust.cornell.edu/about/index.html |title=About this project |website=Durable Rust Resistance in Wheat |publisher=Cornell}}</ref> in Uganda (and possibly earlier in Kenya)<ref name=CIMMYT>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070729144609/http://www.globalrust.org/uploads/documents/SoundingAlarmGlobalRust.pdf An assessment of race UG99 in Kenya and Ethiopia and the potential for impact in neighbouring regions and beyond]. By expert panel on the stem-rust outbreak in Eastern Africa. 29 May 2005.</ref> with the particularly virulent [[Stem rust#Ug99|UG99]] fungus. Unlike other rusts, which only partially affect crop yields, UG99 can bring 100% crop loss. Up to 80% yield losses were recently recorded in Kenya.<ref name=KARI>Effect of a new race on wheat production/use of fungicides and its cost in large vs small scale farmers, situation of current cultivars. Kenya Agricultural Research Institute, 2005. Njoro. Cited in [https://web.archive.org/web/20070729144609/http://www.globalrust.org/uploads/documents/SoundingAlarmGlobalRust.pdf CIMMYT 2005 study].</ref>
As of 2005 stem rust was still believed to be "largely under control worldwide except in Eastern Africa".<ref name = CIMMYT/> But by January 2007 an even more virulent strain had gone across the Red Sea into Yemen. FAO first reported on 5 March 2008 that Ug99 had now spread to major wheat-growing areas in Iran.<ref name=FAOmar08>http://www.fao.org/newsroom/en/news/2008/1000805/index.html First report of wheat stem rust, strain Ug99, in Iran</ref>
These countries in North Africa and Middle East consume over 150% of their own wheat production;<ref name = cornell/> the failure of this staple crop thus adds a major burden on them. The disease is now expected to spread over China and the Far-East. The strong international collaboration network of research and development that spread disease-resistant strains some 40 years ago and started the [[Green Revolution]], known as [[CGIAR]], was since slowly starved of research funds because of its own success and is now too atrophied to swiftly react to the new threat.<ref name = cornell/>
=== Soil and productivity losses === Sundquist<ref>{{cite web |url=http://home.alltel.net/bsundquist1/se0.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031008022016/http://home.alltel.net/bsundquist1/se0.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=8 October 2003 |title=Soils and Croplands Degradation |publisher=Home.alltel.net |accessdate=3 October 2008 }}</ref> points out that large areas of croplands are lost year after year, due mainly to [[soil erosion]], water depletion and urbanisation. According to him "60,000 km<sup>2</sup>/year of land becomes so severely degraded that it loses its productive capacity and becomes wasteland", and even more are affected to a lesser extent, adding to the crop supply problem.
Additionally, agricultural production is also lost due to [[Water crisis|water depletion]]. Northern China in particular has depleted much of its non-renewables [[aquifer]]s, which now impacts negatively its crop production.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skmconsulting.com/news/2006/Managing+Chinas+Shrinking+Groundwater+Reserves.htm |title=Managing China's Shrinking Groundwater Reserves |publisher=Skmconsulting.com |accessdate=3 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081009162239/http://www.skmconsulting.com/news/2006/Managing%2BChinas%2BShrinking%2BGroundwater%2BReserves.htm |archivedate=9 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Urbanisation is another, smaller, difficult to estimate cause of annual cropland reduction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://home.alltel.net/bsundquist1/se6.html |title=Chapter 6 – Urbanization-caused topsoil loss |publisher=Home.alltel.net |accessdate=3 October 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011193251/http://home.alltel.net/bsundquist1/se6.html |archivedate=11 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Rising levels of ozone=== One possible environmental factor in the food price crisis is rising background levels of ground-level [[tropospheric ozone]] in the atmosphere. Plants have been shown to have a high sensitivity to ozone levels, and lower yields of important food crops, such as wheat and soybeans, may have been a result of elevated ozone levels. Ozone levels in the [[Yangtze Delta]] were studied for their effect on [[oilseed rape]], a member of the cabbage family that produces one-third of the vegetable oil used in China. Plants grown in chambers that controlled ozone levels exhibited a 10–20 percent reduction in size and weight ([[biomass]]) when exposed to elevated ozone levels. Production of seeds and oil was also reduced.<ref>[http://newswise.com/articles/view/541362/ Lower Crop Yields Due to Ozone a Factor in World Food Crisis] Newswise. Retrieved 15 July 2008.</ref> The Chinese authors of this study also reported that rice grown in chambers that controlled ozone levels exhibited a 14 to 20 percent reduction in [[biomass]] yield when exposed to ozone levels over 25 times higher than was normal for the region.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S1001-0742(08)60050-9 | volume=20 | title=Effects of elevated ozone on growth and yield of field-grown rice in Yangtze River Delta, China | year=2008 | journal=Journal of Environmental Sciences | pages=320–325 | last1 = Chen | first1 = Zhan | last2 = Wang | first2 = Xiaoke | last3 = Feng | first3 = Zhaozhong | last4 = Zheng | first4 = Feixiang | last5 = Duan | first5 = Xiaonan | last6 = Yang | first6 = Wenrui}}</ref>
==Rising prices== From the beginning of 2007 to early 2008, the prices of some of the most basic international food commodities increased dramatically on international markets.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Timmer|first=Peter C.|title=Reflections on food crises past|journal=Food Policy|year=2010|volume=35|issue=1|pages=1–11|doi=10.1016/j.foodpol.2009.09.002}}</ref> The international market price of wheat doubled from February 2007 to February 2008 hitting a record high of over US$10 a [[bushel]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7148374.stm Wheat breaks through $10 a bushel], BBC, 17 December 2007.</ref> Rice prices also reached ten-year highs. In some nations, milk and meat prices more than doubled, while [[soy]] (which hit a 34-year high price in December 2007<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7149079.stm Corn's key role as food and fuel], Adam Brookes BBC News, 17 December 2007.</ref>) and maize prices have increased dramatically.
Total food import bills rose by an estimated 25% for developing countries in 2007. Researchers from the [[Overseas Development Institute]] have suggested this problem will be worsened by a likely fall in food aid. As food aid is programmed by budget rather than volume, rising food prices mean that the [[World Food Programme]] (WFP) needs an extra $500 million just to sustain the current operations.<ref name = "bpdnsw">[http://www.odi.org.uk/resources/details.asp?id=1009&title=rising-food-prices-global-crisis Rising Food Prices: A Global Crisis], [[Overseas Development Institute]], 22 April 2008.</ref>
To ensure that food remains available for their domestic populations and to combat dramatic price inflation, major rice exporters, such as China, Brazil, India, Indonesia, Vietnam, Cambodia and Egypt, imposed strict export bans on rice.<ref>{{cite news |date=14 April 2008 |title=The global food crisis and the Indian situation |url=http://www.navhindtimes.com/articles.php?Story_ID=04147 |newspaper=[[Navhind Times]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625010620/http://www.navhindtimes.com/articles.php?Story_ID=04147 |archive-date=25 June 2008}}</ref> Conversely, several other nations, including Argentina, Ukraine, Russia, and Serbia either imposed high tariffs or blocked the export of wheat and other foodstuffs altogether, driving up prices still further for net food importing nations while trying to isolate their internal markets. North Korea suffered from the food crisis to such extent that a North Korean official was quoted in June '08 with saying "Life is more than difficult. It seems that everyone is going to die".<ref name="autogenerated1"/> This nation however is solely relying on food assistance to cope with the crisis.<ref>{{cite news |date=10 April 2002 |title=North Korea faces 'looming' food crisis |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/1921634.stm |work=BBC News}}</ref> <!--[hiding multi-item ref – it has a lot of useful items, but it's presented as too much of an overview.
