=== In developed countries === {{Expand section|date=May 2008}}
====United States==== A May 2008 national survey found that food banks and pantries across the US were being forced to cut back on food distribution as 99 percent of respondents reported an increase in the number of people requesting services. Rising food and fuel prices, inadequate food stamp benefits, unemployment, underemployment, and rent or mortgage costs were factors reported as forcing an average of 15–20 percent more people.<ref>[http://www.secondharvest.org/news_room/2008_press_releases/051208.html "New Survey Underscores Urgent Need For Farm Bill As Demands Are Up, Food Down"], "[[America's Second Harvest]]", 12 May 2008. Retrieved 18 June 2008.</ref> Compounding this issue, USDA bonus foods have declined by $200 million and local food donations were down nationally about 9 percent over the same period. According to the California Association of Food Banks, which is an umbrella organization of nearly all food banks in the state, food banks are at the "beginning of a crisis."<ref>[http://www.cafoodbanks.org/docs/crisis/Food_Crisis_FB%20(2).pdf "International Food Crisis: Food Bank Clients in Peril"], California Association of Food Banks, 2008-6. Retrieved 18 June 2008.</ref>
==Effects on farmers== If global price movements are transmitted to local markets, farmers in the developing world could benefit from the rising price of food. According to researchers from the [[Overseas Development Institute]], this may depend on farmers' capacity to respond to changing market conditions. Experience suggests that farmers lack the credit and inputs needed to respond in the short term. In the medium or long term, however, they could benefit, as seen in the Asian [[Green Revolution]] or in many African countries in the recent past.<ref name = "bpdnsw"/>
=== Relationship with 2008 Chinese milk scandal === {{Details|2008 Chinese milk scandal}} As grain prices increased, China's numerous small-holding milk farmers, as well as producers of feed for cattle, were unable to exist economically. As a result, they turned to putting additives into the feed and milk, including [[melamine]], to boost the measured level of protein. Hundreds of thousands of children became ill, China's milk exports virtually ended, executives and officials were arrested and some executed, and companies went bankrupt.<ref name="tele1"> [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/3545733/China-milk-scandal-Families-of-sick-children-fight-to-find-out-true-scale-of-the-problem.html China milk scandal: Families of sick children fight to find out true scale of the problem – Telegraph] Malcolm Moore, photos Daniel Traub, 2008 03 12, via www.telegraph.co.uk on 2010 11 10 </ref>
==Unrest and government actions in individual countries and regions== The price rises affected parts of [[Economy of Asia|Asia]] and [[Economy of Africa|Africa]] particularly severely with Burkina Faso,<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSL08851567._CH_.2400 Burkina general strike starts over cost of living] Mathieu Bonkoungou: Reuters, 8 April 2008</ref> Cameroon, Senegal, Mauritania, Côte d'Ivoire,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7325733.stm Riots prompt Ivory Coast tax cuts], BBC, 2 April 2008. [http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=77538 COTE D'IVOIRE: Food price hikes spark riots], 31 March 2008 (IRIN)</ref> Egypt<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7288196.stm Egyptians hit by rising food prices], BBC, 11 March 2008.<br />[http://web.archive.org/web/20080411015845/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L08810639.htm Two die after clashes in Egypt industrial town] Gamal: Reuters, 8 April 2008. Archived from the [http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L08810639.htm original] on 28 September 2018. </ref> and Morocco seeing protests and [[List of riots|riot]]s in late 2007 and early 2008 over the unavailability of basic food staples. Other countries that have seen food riots or are facing related unrest are: Mexico, Bolivia, Yemen, Uzbekistan, Bangladesh,<ref>[http://www.thetrumpet.com/index.php?q=5021.3306.0.0 "Soaring Food Prices Spark Unrest"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080420174511/http://www.thetrumpet.com/index.php?q=5021.3306.0.0 |date=20 April 2008 }}, ''[[The Philadelphia Trumpet]]'', 11 April 2008</ref> Pakistan,<ref>[http://www.independent-bangladesh.com/200804013859/business/pakistan-heading-for-yet-anther-wheat-crisis.html "Pakistan heading for yet another wheat crisis"], ''[[The Independent (Bangladesh)|The Independent]]'', 1 April 2008</ref> Sri Lanka,<ref>[http://www.wsws.org/articles/2008/apr2008/sril-a11.shtml "Anger grows over rising prices in Sri Lanka"], ''[[World Socialist Web Site]]'', 11 April 2008</ref> and South Africa.<ref>{{cite news |last=Boyle |first=Brendan |date=13 April 2008 |title=SA must grow food on all arable land, says Manuel |url=http://www.thetimes.co.za/PrintEdition/Article.aspx?id=747211 |newspaper=[[The Times (South Africa)|The Times]] |location=Johannesburg |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090111091639/http://www.thetimes.co.za/PrintEdition/Article.aspx?id=747211 |archive-date=11 January 2009}}</ref>
===Bangladesh=== 10,000 workers rioted close to the Bangladeshi capital [[Dhaka]], smashing cars and buses and vandalising factories in anger at high food prices and low wages. Dozens of people, including at least 20 police officials, were injured in the violence. Ironically, the country achieved food self-sufficiency in 2002, but food prices increased drastically due to the reliance of agriculture on oil and fossil fuels.<ref>{{cite news |date=12 April 2008 |title=Bangladesh workers riot over soaring food prices |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20080412/wl_sthasia_afp/bangladeshtextile_080412095619 |newspaper=Yahoo News |agency=Agence France-Presse |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424010543/http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20080412/wl_sthasia_afp/bangladeshtextile_080412095619 |archive-date=24 April 2008}}]</ref>
Economists estimate 30 million of the country's 150 million people could go hungry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azstarnet.com/sn/news/234144.php|title=Bangladesh in critical shape as people desperate for food|author=Julhas Alam The Associated Press|work=Arizona Daily Star}}</ref>
===Brazil=== In April 2008, the Brazilian government announced a temporary ban on the export of rice. The ban is intended to protect domestic consumers.<ref>Olle, N. 2008, [http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/04/25/2227615.htm?section=business 'Brazil halts rice exports as world food prices climb'], ''ABC News'' (Aust.), 25 April. Retrieved 28 April 2008.</ref><ref>The Real News 2008, [http://therealnews.com/web/index.php?thisdataswitch=0&thisid=1408&thisview=item&renewx=2008-04-26+01%3A04%3A51 'Brazil bans rice exports, protests in Peru'], ''The Real News'', 26 April. Retrieved 28 April 2008. (Video.)</ref>
===Burkina Faso=== One of the earlier food riots took place in Burkina Faso, on 22 February, when rioting broke out in the country's second and third largest cities over soaring food prices (up to a 65 percent increase), sparing the capital, [[Ouagadougou]], where soldiers were mobilized throughout strategic points. The government promised to lower taxes on food and to release food stocks. Over 100 people were arrested in one of the towns.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=76905 "Burkina Faso: Food riots shut down main towns"], ''[[IRIN]]'', 22 February 2008</ref> Related policy actions of the Burkinabe government included: * The removal of customs duty on rice, salt, dairy-based products and baby foods * The removal of value added tax on durum wheat, baby foods, soap and edible oils * Establishing negotiated prices with wholesalers for sugar, oil and rice * Releasing food stocks * Strengthening of community grain banks * Food distribution in-kind * Reduction of electricity cost, partial payment of utility bills for the poor * Enacting special programs for schools and hospitals * Fertilizer distribution and production support.
A ban was also imposed on exportation of cereals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://knol.google.com/k/sergey-polovinkin/food-crisis-and-food-security-policies/cju5lr97z6h4/32 |title=Polovinkin, Sergey. Food Crisis and Food Security Policies in West Africa: An Inventory of West African Countries' Policy Responses During the 2008 Food Crisis. Version 9. Knol. 2010 Apr 11. |publisher=Google |accessdate=12 April 2010}}</ref>
=== Cameroon === {{main|2008 Cameroonian anti-government protests}} Cameroon, the world's fourth largest [[Cocoa bean|cocoa]] producer, saw large scale rioting in late February 2008 in Douala, the country's commercial capital. Protesters were against inflating food and fuel prices, as well as the attempt by President [[Paul Biya]] to extend his 25-year rule. Protesters set up barricades, burned tires, and targeted businesses that they believed belonged to the Biya family, high members of the ruling party, the government, or France.<ref name="Amin 2012 20–43">{{cite journal|last=Amin|first=J.|title=Understanding the Protest of February 2008 in Cameroon|journal=Africa Today|year=2012|volume=58|issue=4|pages=20–43|doi=10.2979/africatoday.58.4.21}}</ref> It became the first protest in the nation's history in which minute- by-minute events were covered by social media. By 27 February, a strike was taking place in thirty-one cities, including Yaoundé, Douala, Bamenda, Bafoussam, Buea, Limbe, Tiko, Muea, Mutengene, and Kumba.<ref name="Amin 2012 20–43"/> At least seven people were killed in the worst unrest seen in the country in over fifteen years.<ref>{{cite news |date=27 February 2008 |title=Anti-government rioting spreads in Cameroon |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/02/27/africa/27cameroon.php |newspaper=[[International Herald Tribune]] |agency=Reuters |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310021014/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/02/27/africa/27cameroon.php |archive-date=10 March 2009}}</ref> This figure was later increased to 24.<ref name=autogenerated1>Time; Food Prices:What went wrong (16 June 2008)</ref> Youths were mobilized in ways that had not been seen since the days of the villes mortes.<ref name="Amin 2012 20–43"/> Part of the government response to the protests was a reduction in import taxes on foods including rice, flour, and fish. The government reached an agreement with retailers by which prices would be lowered in exchange for the reduced import taxes. As of late April 2008, however, reports suggested that prices had not eased and in some cases had even increased.<ref>IRIN 2008, [http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=77971 'CAMEROON: Lifting of import taxes fails to reduce food prices'], 29 April. Retrieved 30 April 2008.</ref>
On 24 April 2008, the government of Cameroon announced a two-year emergency program designed to double Cameroon's food production and achieve food self-sufficiency.<ref>IRIN 2008, [http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=77931 'Cameroon: Food self-sufficient in two years?'], ''IRIN'', 25 April. Retrieved 27 April 2008.</ref>
=== Côte d'Ivoire === On 31 March, Côte d'Ivoire's capital [[Abidjan]] saw police use tear gas and a dozen protesters injured following food riots that gripped the city. The riots followed dramatic hikes in the price of food and fuel, with the price of beef rising from US$1.68 to $2.16 per kilogram, and the price of gasoline rising from $1.44 to $2.04 per liter, in only three days.<ref>[http://allafrica.com/stories/200803311850.html "Côte d'Ivoire: Food Price Hikes Spark Riots"], ''[[AllAfrica.com]]'', 31 March 2008.</ref>
===Egypt=== In Egypt, a boy was killed from a gunshot to the head after Egyptian police intervened in violent demonstrations over rising food prices that gripped the industrial city of [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra|Mahalla]] on 8 April 2008. Large swathes of the population have been hit as food prices, and particularly the price of bread, have doubled over the last several months as a result of producers exploiting a shortage that has existed since 2006<ref>{{cite news |date=8 April 2008 |title=Egyptian boy dies from wounds sustained in Mahalla food riots |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/04/08/africa/ME-GEN-Egypt-Protest-Death.php |newspaper=[[International Herald Tribune]] |agency=Associated Press |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080623012845/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/04/08/africa/ME-GEN-Egypt-Protest-Death.php |archive-date=23 June 2008}}</ref>{{,}}.<ref>{{cite news|last=Steavenson|first=Wendell|title=It's the baladi, stupid|work=[[The Australian Financial Review]]|page=Perspectives Review supplement (pp. 3–5)|date=9 January 2009|quote=The difference between the subsidised and market price of bread [in Egypt] is exploited at every stage of production and sale, by importers, millers, warehousers, traders, bakers and consumers alike.}}</ref>
===Ethiopia=== {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} Drought and the food price crisis threatened thousands in Ethiopia.<ref>{{cite news|title=4.5 million drought-stricken Ethiopians need food aid: govt |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20080603-45-million-drought-stricken-ethiopians-need-food-aid-govt |work=France 24 |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=3 June 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609224205/http://www.france24.com/en/20080603-45-million-drought-stricken-ethiopians-need-food-aid-govt |archivedate=9 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy |accessdate=3 October 2008 |quote=Addis Ababa says the number of Ethiopians in need of emergency food aid in drought-affected regions has risen to 4.5 million }}</ref>
===Haiti=== On 12 April 2008, the Haitian Senate voted to dismiss Prime Minister [[Jacques-Édouard Alexis]] after violent food riots hit the country.<!--what, can I say? Read the source... Or explain why the media is wrong and you're right, don't just remove it – account for it]--><ref>{{cite news |date=13 April 2008 |title=Haiti PM ousted over soaring food prices |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hL0HvIfNZQ2nMgFdy9dSKLZ7t2Gw |newspaper=Google News |agency=Agence France-Presse |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130714050611/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hL0HvIfNZQ2nMgFdy9dSKLZ7t2Gw |archive-date=14 July 2013}}</ref> The food riots caused the death of 5 people.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Prices for food items such as rice, beans, fruit and condensed milk have gone up 50 percent in Haiti since late 2007 while the price of fuel has tripled in only two months.<ref>[http://www.jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20080413/focus/focus1.html "The world food crisis"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421030612/http://www.jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20080413/focus/focus1.html |date=21 April 2008 }}, ''[[Jamaica Gleaner]]'', 13 April 2008</ref> Riots broke out in April due to the high prices, and the government had been attempting to restore order by subsidizing a 15 percent reduction in the price of rice.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSN15226767 "Price of rice prompts renewed anger in Haiti"], [[Reuters]], April l5, 2008</ref> As of February 2010, post-earthquake Port-au-Prince is almost entirely reliant on foreign food aid, some of which ends up in the black markets.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2010/02/04/world/international-us-quake-haiti-food.html "Foreign Food Aid Trickles Into Haiti's Black Market"],''[[The New York Times]]'', 4 February 2010</ref>
=== India === India has banned the export of rice except for Basmati which attracts a premium price.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/feb/26/food.unitednations|title=Feed the world? We are fighting a losing battle, UN admits|author=Julian Borger|work=the Guardian}}</ref>
The ban has since been removed, and India now exports a variety of rice. {{Citation needed|reason=reliable source needed for this claim|date=December 2012}}
===Indonesia=== Street protests over the price of food took place in Indonesia<ref>[http://www.iran-daily.com/1386/3041/html/ieconomy.htm#s287070 "Indonesia takes action over soyabeans"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070710075729/http://www.iran-daily.com/1386/3041/html/ieconomy.htm#s287070 |date=10 July 2007 }}, ''Iran Daily'', 16 January 2008</ref> where food staples and gasoline have nearly doubled in price since January 2008.<ref name="gm-I">{{cite news |last=Coren |first=Michael |date=12 April 2008 |title=Food beyond the reach of the poor |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/food-beyond-the-reach-of-the-poor/article17983702/ |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]}}</ref>
===Latin America=== In April 2008, the Latin American members of the United Nations' [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO) met in [[Brasília]] to confront the issues of high food prices, scarcities and violence that affect the region.<ref>[http://upsidedownworld.org/main/content/view/1223/68/ Latin America: Food or Fuel – That Is the Burning Question] Upside Down World, 15 April 2008. Retrieved 1 May 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5gwsSrfOE?url=http://upsidedownworld.org/main/content/view/1223/68/ Archived] 21 May 2009.</ref>
===Mexico=== The [[President of Mexico]], [[Felipe Calderón]], with industry representatives and members of the Confederation of Industrial Chambers (Concamin), agreed to freeze prices of more than 150 consumer staples, such as coffee, sardines, tuna, oil, soup or tea, among others, until the end of December 2008. The measure was carried out in an attempt to control inflation, which stood at an annual rate of 4.95%, the highest increase since December 2004.
Mexican baking company [[Grupo Bimbo]]'s CEO, Daniel Servitje, announced in the 19th Plenary Meeting of the Mexico–China Business Committee that Bimbo agreed to freeze their product prices, despite a 20% rise in production costs.<ref>{{cite news |date=28 August 2015 |title=Bimbo busca mantener sus precios durante 2009 |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/finanzas/69118.html |newspaper=El Universal}}</ref> Bimbo is one of the most important baking companies worldwide, having recently expanded to China. Bimbo has also acquired five bakeries in the United States and Canada.<ref>{{cite news |date=23 January 2002 |title=Company News; Grupo Bimbo of Mexico Buys 5 Bakeries in United States |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/01/23/business/company-news-grupo-bimbo-of-mexico-buys-5-bakeries-in-united-states.html |newspaper=The New York Times | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref>
===Mozambique=== In mid February, rioting that started in the Mozambican rural town of [[Chokwe, Mozambique|Chokwe]] and then spread to the capital, [[Maputo]], has resulted in at least four deaths. The riots were reported in the media to have been, at least in part, over food prices and were termed "food riots." A biofuel advocacy publication, however, claimed that these were, in fact, "fuel riots", limited to the rise in the cost of diesel, and argued that the "food riot" characterization worked to fan "anti-biofuels sentiment."<ref>[http://www.biofuelsdigest.com/blog2/2008/02/19/mozambique-diesel-riots-reported-in-western-media-as-food-riots-fanning-anti-biofuels-sentiment/ "Mozambique diesel riots reported in Western media as "food riots", fanning anti-biofuels sentiment"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421001450/http://www.biofuelsdigest.com/blog2/2008/02/19/mozambique-diesel-riots-reported-in-western-media-as-food-riots-fanning-anti-biofuels-sentiment/ |date=21 April 2008 }}, ''Biofuel Digest'', 19 February 2008</ref>
=== Pakistan === The [[Pakistan Army]] has been deployed to avoid the seizure of food from fields and warehouses. This hasn't stopped the food prices from increasing. The new government has been blamed for not managing the countries food stockpiles properly.<ref>[http://www.zawya.com/Story.cfm/sidANA145104100629 zawya.com] (need to be login first)</ref>
=== Myanmar === Once the world's top rice producer, has produced enough rice to feed itself until now. Rice exports dropped over four decades from nearly 4 million tons to only about 40,000 tons last year, mostly due to neglect by Myanmar's ruling generals of infrastructure, including irrigation and warehousing. On 3 May 2008 [[Cyclone Nargis]] stripped Myanmar's rice-growing districts, ruining large areas with salt water. U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization estimates that these areas produce 65 percent of Myanmar's rice. Worries of long-term food shortages and rationing are rife. The military regime says nothing about the rice crisis, but continues to export rice at the same rate. <!-- The reference cannot be checked, but I'm the native that know the fact --> "...at least the next two harvests are going to be greatly affected and there'll be virtually no output from those areas during that time. So we're likely to see considerable food and rice shortages for the next couple of years. The damage to the economy is going to be profound." said economist and Myanmar expert Sean Turnell, of Australia's Macquarie University. (interviewed in "The Irriwaddy", Tuesday, 27 May 2008)
===Panama=== In Panama, in response to higher rice prices the government began buying rice at the high market price and selling rice to the public at a lower subsidized price at food kiosks.
===Philippines=== In the Philippines, the [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo|Arroyo government]] insisted on 13 April that there would be no food riots in the country and that there could be no comparison with Haiti's situation.<ref>[http://www.sunstar.com.ph/static/net/2008/04/13/palace.assures.no.food.riots.in.rp. (7.03.p.m.).html "Palace assures no food riots in RP"], ''Sun Star Network Exchange (Sunnex)'', 13 April 2008</ref> Chief Presidential Legal Counsel, [[Sergio Apostol]] stated that: "Haiti is not trying to solve the problem, while we are doing something to address the issue. We don't have a food shortage. So, no comparison..."<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-04/13/content_7969073.htm "Official: Philippines not comparable with Haiti in food crisis"], [[Xinhua]], 13 April 2008</ref> Comments by the Justice Secretary, [[Raul M. Gonzalez|Raul Gonzalez]], the following day, that food riots are not far fetched, were quickly rebuked by the rest of the government.<ref>[http://www.upiasiaonline.com/Economics/2008/04/14/food_riots_to_hit_manila_soon/6830/ "Food riots to hit Manila soon?"], [[United Press International]], 14 April 2008</ref>
On 15 April, the Philippines, the world's largest rice importer, urged China, Japan, and other key Asian nations, to convene an emergency meeting, especially taking issue with those countries' rice export bans. "Free trade should be flowing", Philippine Agriculture Secretary Arthur Yap stated.<ref>[http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=17&art_id=64446&sid=18492523&con_type=1 "Manila calls for Asian summit over food crisis"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614225623/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=17&art_id=64446&sid=18492523&con_type=1 |date=14 June 2013 }}, ''[[The Standard (Hong Kong)|The Standard]]'', 15 April 2008</ref> In late April 2008, the Philippines government requested that the World Bank exert pressure on rice exporting countries to end export restrictions.<ref>{{cite news |date=29 April 2008 |title=Manila urges end to rice export ban |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/84B4ED9E-DD71-4C2D-BA12-626A80052D09.htm |work=Al Jazeera English |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709000237/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/84B4ED9E-DD71-4C2D-BA12-626A80052D09.htm |archive-date=9 July 2008 |access-date=29 April 2008}}</ref>
===Russia=== The Russian government pressured retailers to freeze food prices before key elections for fear of a public backlash against the rising cost of food in October 2007.<ref>{{cite news |date=26 October 2007 |title=Kremlin orders a freeze on food prices as country gets set for polls |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article2741064.ece |newspaper=Times Online |location=London |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904175555/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article2741064.ece |archive-date=4 September 2011}}</ref> The freeze ended on 1 May 2008.<ref>{{cite news |last=Titova |first=Irina |date=12 May 2008 |title=Food Prices Forecast to Keep Rising |url=http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=25957 |work=St. Petersburg Times |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407215715/http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=25957 |archive-date=7 April 2014}}</ref>
===Senegal=== On 31 March 2008, Senegal had riots in response to the rise in the price of food and fuel. Twenty-four people were arrested and detained in a response that one local human rights group claimed included "torture" and other "unspeakable acts" on the part of the security forces.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=77539 "Senegal: Heavy handed response to food protesters"], ''[[IRIN]]'', 31 March 2008</ref> Further protests took place in [[Dakar]] on 26 April 2008.<ref>{{cite news |date=27 April 2008 |title=Food costs spark protests in Senegal |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/6239F12A-AE9B-44FC-A6CD-1A01A9F3586E.htm |work=Al Jazeera English |access-date=27 April 2008}}</ref>
=== Somalia === Riots in Somalia occurred on 5 May 2008 over the price of food, in which five protesters were killed. The protests occurred amid a serious humanitarian emergency due to the [[War in Somalia (2006–2009)|Ethiopian war in Somalia]].
=== Tajikistan === ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'', neweurasia, and other media observers are predicting that a nascent hunger crisis will erupt into a full [[famine]] as a consequence of the [[2008 Central Asia energy crisis|energy shortages]].<ref name=neweurasia>{{cite web|title=Hunger to replace energy crisis|work=[[neweurasia]]|author=Vadim|date=4 March 2008|url=http://tajikistan.neweurasia.net/2008/03/04/hunger-to-replace-energy-crisis/| accessdate=3 March 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090114031922/http://tajikistan.neweurasia.net/2008/03/04/hunger-to-replace-energy-crisis/| archivedate=14 January 2009| deadurl= yes}}</ref> UN experts announced on 10 October that almost one-third of Tajikistan's 6.7 million inhabitants may not have enough to eat for the winter of 2008–09.<ref>[http://www.eurasianet.org/departments/insight/articles/eav100708.shtml Tajikistan: Almost One-Third of the Population Is in Danger of Going Hungry This Winter], EurasiaNet</ref>
===Yemen=== Food riots in southern Yemen that began in late March and continued through early April, saw police stations torched, and roadblocks were set up by armed protesters. The army has deployed tanks and other military vehicles. Although the riots involved thousands of demonstrators over several days and over 100 arrests, officials claimed no fatalities; residents, however, claimed that at least one of the fourteen wounded people has died.<ref>[http://www.inteldaily.com/?c=148&a=5876 "Food riots rock Yemen"], ''The Intelligence Daily'', 4 April 2008.</ref>
==Projections and early mitigation efforts== The [[FAO|UN (FAO)]] released a study in December 2007 projecting a 49 percent increase in African cereal prices, and 53 percent in European prices, through July 2008.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7244382.stm Cereal prices hit poor countries], BBC, 14 February 2008.<br />[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/7148880.stm UN warns on soaring food prices], 17 December 2007.</ref> In April 2008, the World Bank, in combination with the [[International Monetary Fund]], announced a series of measures aimed at mitigating the crisis, including increased loans to African farmers and emergency monetary aid to badly affected areas such as Haiti.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7344892.stm World Bank tackles food emergency], BBC, 14 April 2008.</ref> According to FAO director [[Jacques Diouf]], however, the [[World Food Programme]] needed an immediate cash injection of at least $1700 million,<ref name="gm"/> far more than the tens of million-worth in measures already pledged. On 28 April 2008, the United Nations Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] established a Task Force on the Global Food Security Crisis [https://www.un.org/issues/food/taskforce/] under his chairmanship and composed of the heads of the United Nations specialized agencies, funds and programmes, Bretton Woods institutions and relevant parts of the UN Secretariat to co-ordinate efforts to alleviate the crisis.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7372393.stm UN Sets up food crisis task force], BBC, 29 April 2008.</ref>
==After the crisis== 2013 research concluded that the spike was the result of an unusual combination of circumstances and prices in the future will be higher than before the spike, depending on [[oil prices]], [[climate change]], and future diets. The impacts of the spike on poor people were concentrated in low-income countries and may have been less severe than once thought, thanks to rising rural wages in some countries. The researchers called on developing countries to ensure good data on the key indicators of distress and to strengthen [[social protection]], and on those involved in international development to continue increasing focus on reducing child [[malnutrition]] and stimulating agricultural development.<ref>Steve Wiggins and Sharada Keats, July 2013, Looking back, peering forward: what has been learned from the food-price spike of 2007–2008? http://www.odi.org.uk/publications/7384-look-back-peering-forward-food-price-spike</ref>
== Actions by governments == [[IFAD]] is making up to US$200 million available to support poor farmers boost food production in face of the global food crisis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifad.org/media/press/2008/25.htm|title=US$200 million from IFAD to help poor farmers boost food production in face of food crisis|work=ifad.org|access-date=28 April 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080427191030/http://www.ifad.org/media/press/2008/25.htm|archive-date=27 April 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 2 May 2008, US President [[George W. Bush]] said he was asking Congress to approve an extra $770 million funding for international food aid.<ref>{{cite news |date=2 May 2008 |title=Bush offers $770m for food crisis |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7378807.stm |work=BBC News |accessdate=3 October 2008}}</ref> On 16 October 2008, in a speech at a United Nations gathering on [[World Food Day]], former US president [[Bill Clinton]] criticized the bipartisan coalition in Congress that blocked efforts to make some aid donations in cash rather than in food.<ref name="sfgate.com">{{cite news|last=Hanley |first=Charles J. |date=23 October 2008 |title='We blew it' on global food, says Bill Clinton |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2008/10/23/international/i142025D32.DTL |work=The San Francisco Chronicle |agency=Associated Press |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028071414/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fn%2Fa%2F2008%2F10%2F23%2Finternational%2Fi142025D32.DTL |archive-date=28 October 2008 |accessdate=3 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Referring in part to policies that had pressured African governments to reduce subsidies for fertilizer and other agricultural inputs, Clinton also said:<blockquote>We need the World Bank, the IMF, all the big foundations, and all the governments to admit that, for 30 years, we all blew it, including me when I was President. We were wrong to believe that food was like some other product in international trade, and we all have to go back to a more responsible and sustainable form of agriculture.<ref>Bill Clinton, [http://www.clintonfoundation.org/news/news-media/speech-united-nations-world-food-day "Speech: United Nations World Food Day"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20110605130326/http://www.clintonfoundation.org/news/news-media/speech-united-nations-world-food-day |date=5 June 2011 }}, October 13, 2008</ref></blockquote>The release of Japan's rice reserves onto the market may bring the rice price down significantly. As of 16 May, anticipation of the move had already lowered prices by 14% in a single week.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/natural_resources/article3943779.ece |title=Rice price dives as US and Japan set to unlock grain pact – Times Online |work=The Times |location=London |author=Leo Lewis, Asia Business Correspondent |date= 16 May 2008|accessdate=3 October 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080923190555/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/natural_resources/article3943779.ece| archivedate= 23 September 2008| deadurl= no}}</ref>
On 30 April 2008 Thailand announced the creation of the [[Organization of Rice Exporting Countries]] (OREC) with the potential to develop a price-fixing [[cartel]] for rice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/news/stories/200804/s2232076.htm?tab=asia%7cRadio|title=Mekong nations to form rice price-fixing cartel|work=radioaustralia.net.au}}</ref><ref>[http://www.bangkokpost.com/News/01May2008_news07.php|Bangkok Post|1 May 2008|PM floats idea of five-nation rice cartel]</ref> This is seen by some as an action to capitalise on the crisis.{{citation needed|date=June 2008}}
In June 2008 the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] hosted a [[High-Level Conference on World Food Security (2008)|High-Level Conference on World Food Security]], in which $1.2 billion in food aid was committed for the 75 million people in 60 countries hardest hit by rising food prices.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7435265.stm "UN increases food aid by $1.2bn"], ''BBC News'', 4 June 2008</ref>
In June 2008, a sustained commitment from the [[G8]] was called for by some humanitarian organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cgdev.org/content/general/detail/16244 |title=Center for Global Development : Food Crisis Requires Sustained Commitment from the G8 |publisher=Cgdev.org |accessdate=3 October 2008}}</ref>
==Food price decreases==
In December 2008, the [[Late-2000s recession|global economic slowdown]], [[2000s energy crisis#Falling prices in late 2008|decreasing oil prices]], and speculation of decreased demand for commodities worldwide brought about sharp decreases in the price of staple crops from their earlier highs. Corn prices on the [[Chicago Board of Trade]] dropped from US$7.99 per bushel in June to US$3.74 per bushel in mid-December; wheat and rice prices experienced similar decreases.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601012&sid=aFEkJtgBWsSA|title=Corn Caps Record Week, Soybeans Drop on Shifts in U.S. Planting|publisher=Bloomberg|date=12 December 2008|accessdate=14 December 2008}}</ref> The UN's Food and Agriculture Organization, however, warned against "a false sense of security", noting that the [[subprime mortgage crisis|credit crisis]] could cause farmers to reduce plantings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d125dbf2-ac2c-11dd-aa46-000077b07658,dwp_uuid=a955630e-3603-11dc-ad42-0000779fd2ac.html?nclick_check=1|title=Another food crisis year looms, says FAO|work=Financial Times|date=6 November 2008|accessdate=14 December 2008}}</ref> FAO convened a [[World Summit on Food Security]] at its headquarters in Rome in November 2008, noting that food prices remained high in developing countries and that the global [[food security]] situation has worsened.
By early 2011, food prices had risen again to surpass the record highs of 2008. Some commentators saw this as the resumption of the price spike seen in 2007–08.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jn.nutrition.org/content/140/1/143S.abstract|title=Medium- to Long-Run Implications of High Food Prices for Global Nutrition|publisher=Journal of Nutrition|date=31 January 2010|accessdate=3 November 2011}}</ref> Prices had dropped after good weather helped increase grain yields while demand had dropped due to the recession.<ref name=Brown>{{cite journal|last=Brown|first=Lester|title=The New Geopolitics of Food|journal=Foreign Policy|date=May–June 2011|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/04/25/the_new_geopolitics_of_food?page=full|accessdate=7 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110624094608/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/04/25/the_new_geopolitics_of_food?page=full| archivedate= 24 June 2011| deadurl= no}}</ref>

{{Infobox Convention | name = SC, The International Conference for High Performance Computing Networking, Storage, and Analysis | status = Active | genre = High Performance Computing Conference | country = {{flagicon|United States}} [[United States]] | first = 1988 | last = 2018 ([[Dallas]]) | next = 2019 ([[Denver]]) | organizer = [[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]] [[SIGHPC]] and [[IEEE Computer Society]] }}
'''SC''' (formerly '''Supercomputing'''), the '''International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis''', is the name of the annual conference established in 1988 by the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] and the [[IEEE Computer Society]]. In 2016, about 11,000 people participated overall.<ref name="SC16 final pr">{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Just Released: SC16 Breaks Exhibits and Workshop Attendance Records |url=http://sc16.supercomputing.org/2016/11/18/sc16-breaks-exhibits-workshop-attendance-records/ |location=Salt Lake City |publisher=SC16 |agency= |date= November 18, 2016 |access-date= 2018-02-01}}</ref> The not-for-profit conference is run by a committee of approximately 600 volunteers who spend roughly three years organizing each conference.
Not to be confused with the [[International Supercomputing Conference]], now known as ISC High Performance, or ICS, the [[ACM SIGARCH#Conferences|ACM SIGARCH International Conference on Supercomputing]].
==Sponsorship and Governance== SC is sponsored by the [[Association for Computing Machinery]] and the [[IEEE Computer Society]]. From its formation through 2011, ACM sponsorship was managed through ACM's [[ACM SIGARCH|Special Interest Group on Computer Architecture (SIGARCH)]]. Sponsors are listed on each proceedings page in the ACM DL; see for example.<ref name="SC88 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=62972 | title = Proceedings of SC88 | year = 1988 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/history.php | location = Orlando, FL, USA | isbn = 0-8186-0882-X }}</ref> Beginning in 2012,<ref name="SC12 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2388996 | title = Proceedings of SC12 | year = 2012 | conference = The International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis | conference-url = http://sc12.supercomputing.org/ | location = Salt Lake City, UT, USA | isbn = 978-1-4673-0804-5 }}</ref> ACM began the process of transitioning sponsorship from SIGARCH to the recently formed [[ACM SIGHPC|Special Interest Group on High Performance Computing (SIGHPC)]]. This transition was completed after SC15,<ref name="SC15 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2807591 | title = Proceedings of SC15 | year = 2015 | conference = The International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis | conference-url = http://sc15.supercomputing.org/ | location = Austin, TX, USA | isbn = 978-1-4503-3723-6 }}</ref> and for SC16 ACM sponsorship was vested exclusively in SIGHPC (IEEE sponsorship remained unchanged).<ref name="SC16 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3014904 | title = Proceedings of SC16 | year = 2016 | conference = The International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis | conference-url = http://sc16.supercomputing.org/ | location = Salt Lake City, UT, USA | isbn = 978-1-4673-8815-3 }}</ref> The conference is non-profit.
The conference is governed by a steering committee that includes representatives of the sponsoring societies, the current conference general chair, the general chairs of the preceding two years, the general chairs of the next two conference years, and a number of elected members.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://supercomputing.org/steering.php |title=SC Steering Committee |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=The Supercomputing Conference Series |access-date= 2016-11-06 }}</ref> All steering committee members are volunteers, with the exception of the two representatives of the sponsoring societies, who are employees of those societies. The committee selects the conference general chair, approves each year's conference budget, and is responsible for setting policy and strategy for the conference.
==Conference Components== Although each conference committee introduces slight variations on the program each year, the core components of the conference remain largely unchanged from year to year.
===Technical Program=== The SC Technical Program is competitive with an acceptance rate around 20% for papers (see [[#History|History]]). Traditionally, the program includes invited talks, panels, research papers, tutorials, workshops, posters, and Birds of a Feather (BoF) sessions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sc16.supercomputing.org/full-program/ |title=SC16 Full Conference Program |author=<!--Not stated--> |website=SC16 conference website |access-date= 2016-11-06 }}</ref>
===Awards=== Each year, SC hosts the following conference and sponsoring society awards:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sc16.supercomputing.org/submitters/awards/ |title=SC16 Awards Program |author=<!--Not stated--> |website=SC16 conference website |access-date= 2016-11-06 }}</ref>
*[[Gordon Bell Prize|ACM Gordon Bell Prize]] *ACM/IEEE-CS George Michael Memorial HPC Fellowship *[[Ken Kennedy Award|ACM/IEEE-CS Ken Kennedy Award]] *ACM SIGHPC Computational & Data Science Fellowships *[[Seymour Cray Computer Engineering Award|IEEE-CS Seymour Cray Computer Engineering Award]] *[[Sidney Fernbach Award|IEEE-CS Sidney Fernbach Memorial Award]] *IEEE CS TCHPC Award for Excellence for Early Career Researchers in HPC *Test of Time Award
=== Exhibits=== In addition to the technical program, SC hosts a research exhibition each year that includes universities, state-sponsored computing research organizations (such as the Federal labs in the US), and vendors of HPC-related hardware and software from many countries around the world. There were 353 exhibitors at SC16 in Salt Lake City, UT.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://iebms.heiexpo.com/iebms/oep/oep_p1_exhibitors.aspx?oc=34&ct=OEP&eventid=5016 |title=SC16 List of Exhibitors |author=<!--Not stated--> |website=SC16 exhibitor directory |access-date= 2016-11-06 }}</ref>
===Student Program=== SC's program for students has gone through a variety of changes and emphases over the years. Beginning with SC15<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sc15.supercomputing.org/conference-program/student-program.html |title=Students@SC |author=<!--Not stated--> |website=SC15 conference website |access-date= 2016-11-06 }}</ref> the program is called "Students@SC", and is oriented toward undergraduate and graduate students in computing related fields, and computing-oriented students in science and engineering. The program includes professional development programs, opportunities to learn from mentors, and engagement with SC's technical sessions.
===SCinet=== [[SCinet]] is SC's research network. Started in 1991, SCinet features emerging technologies for very high bandwidth, low latency wide area network communications in addition to operational services necessary to provide conference attendees with connectivity to the commodity Internet and to many national research and engineering networks.
==Name changes== Since its establishment in 1988,<ref name="SC88 Proceedings" /> and until 1995,<ref name="SC95 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=224170 | title = Proceedings of SC95 | year = 1995 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/history.php | location = San Diego, CA, USA | isbn = 0-89791-816-9 }}</ref> the full name of the conference was the "ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference" (sometimes: "ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing"). The conference's abbreviated (and more commonly used) formal name was "Supercomputing 'XY", where XY denotes the last two digits of the year. In 1996, according to the archived [http://portalparts.acm.org/370000/369028/fm/frontmatter.pdf front matter] of the conference proceedings,<ref name="SC96 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=369028 | title = Proceedings of SC96 | year = 1996 | conference = The ACM/IEEE International Conference on High Performance Computing and Communications | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/history.php | location = Pittsburgh, PA, USA | isbn = 0-89791-854-1 | access-date = 2016-04-17 }}</ref> the full name was changed to the ACM/IEEE "International Conference on High Performance Computing and Communications". The latter document further announced that, as of 1997, the conference will undergo a name change and will be called "SC97: High Performance Networking and Computing". The document explained that
{{Quote | text = 1997 [will mark] the first use of "SC97" as the name of the annual conference you've known as "Supercomputing 'XY". This change reflects our growing attention to networking, distributed computing, data-intensive applications, and other emerging technologies that push the frontiers of communications and computing. | source = SC97 Call for Participation, included in the archived front matter of Supercomputing '96.<ref name="SC96 Proceedings"/>}}
A 1997 HPCwire article discussed at length the reasoning, considerations, and concerns that accompanied the decision to change the name of the conference series from "Supercomputing 'XY" to "SC 'XY",<ref name="smith97:hpcwire">{{cite web | last = Smith | first = Norris Parker | date = 1997-02-07 | title = Supercomputing is dead; the new king needs a name | url = http://www.hpcwire.com/1997/02/07/supercomputing-is-dead-the-new-king-needs-a-name/ | journal = HPCwire | access-date= 2016-04-17 }}</ref> stating that
{{Quote | text = It's official: the age of supercomputing has ended. At any rate, the word "supercomputing" has been excised from the title of the annual trade shows, sponsored by the IEEE and ACM, that have been known for almost ten years as "Supercomputing '(final two digits of year)". The next event, to be held in San Jose next November, has been redesignated "SC '97." Like Lewis Carroll's Cheshire Cat, "supercomputing" has faded steadily away until only the smile, nose, and whiskers remain. [...] The loss is a real one. An enormous range of ordinary people had some idea, however vague, what "supercomputing" meant. No-caf, local alternatives like "SC" and "HPC" lack this authority. This is not a trivial issue. In these days of rapid change, passing technofancies, and information overload, a rose with the wrong name is just another thorn -- or forgotten immediately. After all, how can businessmen, ordinary consumers, and taxpayers be expected to pay money for something they can't comprehend? More important, will investors and grant-givers hand over money to support further R&D on something whose only identity is an arbitrary clump of capital letters? | source = Norris Parker Smith. HPCwire. February 7, 1997.}}
Despite these concerns, the abbreviated name of the conference, "SC", is still used today, a reminiscent of the abbreviation of the conference's original name—"Supercomputing Conference".
The full name, in contrast, underwent several changes. Between 1997 and 2003,<ref name="SC97 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=509593 | title = Proceedings of SC97 | year = 1997 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/history.php | location = San Jose, CA, USA | isbn = 0-89791-985-8 }}</ref><ref name="SC98 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=509058 | title = Proceedings of SC98 | year = 1998 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/history.php | location = Orlando, FL, USA | isbn = 0-89791-984-X }}</ref><ref name="SC99 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=331532 | title = Proceedings of SC99 | year = 1999 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/history.php | location = Portland, OR, USA | isbn = 1-58113-091-0 }}</ref><ref name="SC00 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3700492 | title = Proceedings of SC00 | year = 2000 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.sc2000.org/ | location = Dallas, TX, USA | isbn = 0-7803-9802-5 }}</ref><ref name="SC01 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=582034 | title = Proceedings of SC01 | year = 2001 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.sc2001.org/ | location = Denver, CO, USA | isbn = 1-58113-293-X }}</ref><ref name="SC02 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=762761 | title = Proceedings of SC02 | year = 2002 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/sc2002/ | location = Baltimore, MD, USA }}</ref><ref name="SC03 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1048935 | title = Proceedings of SC03 | year = 2003 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/sc2003/ | location = Phoenix, AZ, USA | isbn = 1-58113-695-1 }}</ref> the name "High Performance Networking and Computing" was specified in the front matter of the archived conference proceedings in some years (1997, 1998, 2000, 2002), whereas in other years it was omitted altogether in favor of the abbreviated name (1999, 2001, 2003). In 2004,<ref name="SC04 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=104893 | title = Proceedings of SC04 | year = 2004 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://www.supercomp.org/sc2004/ | location = Pittsburgh, PA, USA | isbn = 0-7695-2153-3 | access-date = 2016-04-17 }}</ref> the stated front matter full name was changed to "High Performance Computing, Networking and Storage Conference". In 2005,<ref name="SC05 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1105760 | title = Proceedings of SC05 | year = 2005 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://sc05.supercomputing.org/ | location = Seattle, WA, USA | isbn = 1-59593-061-2 }}</ref> this name was replaced by the original name of the conference—"supercomputing"— in the front matter. Finally, in 2006,<ref name="SC06 Proceedings">{{Cite conference | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1188455 | title = Proceedings of SC06 | year = 2006 | conference = The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing | conference-url = http://sc06.supercomputing.org/ | location = Tampa, FL, USA | isbn = 0-7695-2700-0 }}</ref> the current full name, as used today, emerged: "The International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis".
Despite all of the name variances in the proceedings through the years, the digital library of ACM, the co-sponsoring society, records the name of the conference as "The ACM/IEEE Conference on Supercomputing" from 1998 - 2008, when it changes to ""The International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis". It is these two names that are used in the full citations to the conference proceedings provided in this article.

{{Use American English|date=January 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Boris Epshteyn |office = White House Assistant Director of Communications for Surrogate Operations |president = [[Donald Trump]] |term_start = January 20, 2017 |term_end = March 25, 2017 |predecessor = Position established |successor = ''Vacant'' |birth_name = Boris Alexandrovich Epshteyn |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|8|14}} |birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]] {{small|(now [[Russia]])}} |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Lauren Tanick |children = 1 |education = [[Georgetown University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy |BA]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]])}} }} '''Boris Alexandrovich Epshteyn''' ({{lang-ru|Бори́с Алекса́ндрович Эпштейн}}; born August 14, 1982) is a Russian-born American [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] political strategist, investment banker, and attorney. He is currently the Chief Political Analyst at [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]]. He was a senior advisor to [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 campaign]] for [[President of the United States]], and previously worked on the [[John McCain presidential campaign, 2008|McCain-Palin campaign]]. Following Trump's election, he was named director of communications for the Presidential Inaugural Committee,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/presidential-inaugural-committee-seeks-workers-and-volunteers/2016/11/23/29a886d0-b188-11e6-be1c-8cec35b1ad25_story.html|title=Presidential Inaugural Committee seeks workers and volunteers|work=Washington Post|date=November 23, 2016|access-date=2016-11-26}}</ref> and then assistant communications director for surrogate operations in the administration, until he resigned in March 2017.
==Early life and education== Epshteyn was born in 1982 in [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]], the son of Anna Shulkina and Aleksandr Epshteyn. His family is Russian Jewish.<ref name="NYT"/> In 1993, he immigrated with his family to [[Plainsboro Township, New Jersey]].
Epshteyn is a graduate of [[Georgetown University School of Foreign Service in Qatar|Georgetown University School of Foreign Service]] (BSFS, 2004). During his time as an undergraduate at Georgetown, Epshteyn became a brother of the Eta Sigma chapter of the Alpha Epsilon Pi (AEPi) fraternity.<ref>[http://www.aepi.org/about-aepi/notable-alumni/ "Notable Alumni"], ''aepi.org''.</ref> He graduated from the [[Georgetown University Law Center]] with a law degree.<ref name="Wedding">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/29/fashion/weddings/29tanick.html|title=Lauren Tanick, Boris Epshteyn - Weddings and Celebrations|date=November 27, 2009|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-09-29}}</ref>
==Career== Following his graduation from law school, Epshteyn was part of the finance practice of [[Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy]] New York. He worked on securities transactions, private placements, and bank finance.<ref name="TGPS">{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://www.tgpsecurities.com/about-us.html|publisher=TGP Securities|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en}}</ref>
In 2008, Epshteyn was a communications aide with the McCain-Palin campaign. While at the campaign, he was part of a rapid response task force which concentrated on issues related to the vice presidential nominee [[Sarah Palin]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.politico.com/arena/bio/boris_epshteyn.html | title=Arena Profile: Boris Epshteyn | work=Politico | accessdate=2 October 2016}}</ref>
Epshteyn was managing director of business and legal affairs at the boutique investment bank West America Securities Corporation until the firm was expelled from the Financial Industry Regulatory Agency in 2013.<ref name="FinRA">{{cite web|title=Boris Epshtyn|url=https://brokercheck.finra.org/individual/summary/5712968#timelineSection|publisher=FinRA|accessdate=26 June 2018|language=en}}</ref> He is managing director of business and legal affairs for investment banking firm TGP Securities.<ref name="TGPS"/> In October 2013, Epshteyn moderated a panel at the investment conference "Invest in Moscow!" The panel was composed mainly of Moscow city government officials, including Sergey Cheremin, a city minister who heads Moscow's foreign economic and international relations department.<ref name="Marans">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-advisers-russia-ties_us_57acd474e4b007c36e4db94c|title=When It Comes To Donald Trump's Russia Ties, It's All About The Aides|last=Marans|first=Daniel|date=2016-08-12|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-09-29}}</ref>
===Trump campaign=== During the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign, Epshteyn acted as a senior advisor to the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump campaign]], making frequent television appearances as a Trump media surrogate on Trump's behalf.<ref name="Marans"/>
In September 2016, Epshteyn responded to a question from [[MSNBC]]'s [[Hallie Jackson]] by offering a new explanation for why a portrait of Trump – paid for by the [[Donald J. Trump Foundation]] – wound up on display at [[Trump National Doral Miami]], a Trump-owned for-profit golf resort in Florida. Epshteyn said, "There are IRS rules which specifically state that when a foundation has an item, an individual can store those items – on behalf of the foundation – in order to help it with storage costs... And that's absolutely proper." Epshteyn's explanation was, in effect, that Trump hadn't used his foundation to buy some art for his resort, which would be [[self-dealing]]. Instead, Trump's resort was helping the foundation – which has no employees or office space of its own – to store one of its possessions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/09/27/trump-is-actually-doing-his-foundation-a-favor-by-storing-its-portrait-his-golf-resort-wall-his-adviser-says/|title=Trump is actually doing his foundation a favor, by ‘storing’ its portrait on his golf resort wall, his adviser says|first=David A.|last=Fahrenthold|date=September 27, 2016|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2016-09-30}}</ref>
In September 2016, the media watchdog organization [[Media Matters for America]] criticized [[CNN]], [[Fox News]], and [[PBS]] for failing to disclose Epshteyn's "financial ties to the former Soviet Union, which include consulting through Strategy International LLC for 'entities doing business in Eastern Europe' and moderating a Russian-sponsored conference on 'investment opportunities in Moscow.'"<ref>Hananoki, Eric (September 15, 2016). [http://mediamatters.org/research/2016/09/15/media-host-trump-adviser-boris-epshteyn-russia-without-disclosing-his-business-ties/213113 "Media host Trump adviser Boris Epshteyn on Russia without disclosing his business ties,"] Media Matters for America, retrieved January 25, 2017.</ref>
In an October 2016 ''[[New York Times]]'' article, three political commentators said in separate interviews that Epshteyn "often acted in a rude, condescending manner toward show staffers, makeup artists and others." [[Joy-Ann Reid|Joy Reid]], an [[MSNBC]] show host, said "Boris is abrasive. That is who he is both on the air and off."<ref name="NYT">Meier, Barry; Craig, Susanne (October 13, 2016). [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/14/us/politics/boris-epshteyn-trump.html?_r=0 "The Obscure Lawyer Who Became Donald Trump’s TV Attack Dog,"] ''The New York Times'', retrieved January 25, 2017.</ref>
Epshteyn co-hosted the Trump Campaign [[Facebook|Facebook Live]] coverage before and after the final presidential debate. He also anchored "Trump Tower Live", the Trump Campaign Facebook live nightly program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/10/trumps-campaign-launching-nightly-news-show-facebook/|title=Trump’s Campaign Is Launching a Nightly News Show on Facebook|last=Lapowsky|first=Issie|newspaper=Wired|date=October 24, 2016|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-26}}</ref>
===Trump administration=== Epshteyn became a special assistant in the [[Trump administration]] as it took office. He wrote Trump's controversial statement for [[Holocaust Remembrance Day]] in January 2017, which omitted any mention of the Jewish people.<ref name="Karni">{{cite news|last1=Karni|first1=Annie|title=White House aide Epshteyn wrote controversial Holocaust memorial statement|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/trump-holocaust-memorial-234394|work=Politico|date=January 30, 2017}}</ref> Following criticism of the omission, press secretary [[Sean Spicer]] defended the statement as written by "an individual who is both Jewish and the descendent of Holocaust survivors."<ref name="Karni"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Salkin|first1=Jeffrey|title=Meet Trump’s Holocaust tutor|url=http://religionnews.com/2017/01/31/trump-holocaust-boris-epshteyn/|work=Religion News Service|date=January 31, 2017}}</ref> At the end of March 2017, it was reported that unnamed sources had said Epshteyn was resigning.<ref>Haberman, Maggie, [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/25/us/politics/boris-epshteyn-white-house-press-official-is-let-go-from-his-job.html "Boris Epshteyn, Trump TV Surrogate, Is Leaving White House Job"], ''New York Times'', March 25, 2017. "according to three people with knowledge of the move". Retrieved 2017-03-26.</ref>
===Sinclair Broadcast Group=== In mid-April 2017, [[Sinclair Broadcast Group|Sinclair]] announced it had hired Epshteyn as its senior political analyst. Regarding the appointment, Scott Livingston at Sinclair said in part, "We understand the frustration with government and traditional institutions." Epshteyn said in part, "I greatly admire Sinclair’s mission to provide thoughtful impactful reporting throughout the country." At the time, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' also noted [[Jared Kushner]]'s December 2016 revelation of [[Sinclair_Broadcast_Group#Political_programming|discussions]] between the Trump campaign and the company and content provided to the company which, the report said, Sinclair had "vehemently denied".<ref>Littleton, Cynthia, [https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/trump-spokesman-boris-epshteyn-sinclair-broadcast-group-1202032200/ "Trump Spokesman Boris Epshteyn Joins Sinclair Broadcast Group as Political Analyst"], ''Variety'', April 17, 2017. Retrieved 2017-04-25.</ref>
==Personal life== Epshteyn married Lauren Tanick Epshteyn, a sales manager at [[Google]], in 2009.<ref name="Wedding"/> They have one child.
Epshteyn was reported to be a friend of [[Eric Trump]], who also attended Georgetown.<ref name="NYT"/>
Following a bar fight in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]], in 2014, Epshteyn was charged with misdemeanor [[assault]]. The charge was dropped after he agreed to undergo [[anger management]] counseling and perform community service.<ref name="NYT"

Cine Productions | released = 14 April 1991 | runtime = 162 minutes | country = India | language = Tamil | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Captain Prabhakaran''''' is a 1991 [[Tamil language|Tamil-language]] Indian [[action film]] directed by [[R. K. Selvamani]]. It features [[Vijayakanth]] in the lead role. It also features [[Mansoor Ali Khan (actor)|Mansoor Ali Khan]], [[Rupini (actress)|Rupini]], [[Livingston (actor)|Livingston]] and [[Ramya Krishnan]], while [[R. Sarathkumar]] appears in a cameo role. It was Vijayakanth's 100th film, after which he earned the Sobriquet "captain".{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/mp/2004/01/12/stories/2004011200970200.htm|title=The Hindu : Vijayakanth vs `Virumaandi'|publisher=}} The character of the antagonist Veerabhadran, played by Mansoor Ali Khan, is loosely based on the forest brigand [[Veerappan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/quizzing-with-kcircle/article2965018.ece|title=Quizzing with K-Circle|date=6 March 2012|publisher=|via=The Hindu}} The title of the film was inspired from [[Velupillai Prabhakaran]], the leader of the [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aPgw32Gpi7U|title=R. K. Selvamani in Toronto 16 Mar 2013 - Part 1|first=|last=Tamils Business Connections|date=17 March 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x-lssnqf_RI|title=R. K. Selvamani in Toronto, Part 2|first=|last=Tamils Business Connections|date=17 March 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}} Upon its release, the film became a blockbuster at the box office.https://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/tamil-film-industry-100th-film-jinx-grips-the-mighty-sans-captain/article8595803.ece The [[film score]] and soundtrack were composed by [[Ilaiyaraaja]]. The film was dubbed and released in [[Telugu language|Telugu]] as ''Captain Prabhakar''.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CbokyUrVx14 ==Plot== Captain Prabhakaran ([[Vijayakanth]]) is an [[Indian Forest Service|IFS officer (Indian Forest Service)]] sent to Sathyamangalam to nab Veerabhadran ([[Mansoor Ali Khan (actor)|Mansoor Ali Khan]]) who tortures the people of that place. Prabhakaran is not only going to nab Veerabhadran, but also avenge the death of his friend Rajaraman [[Indian Forest Service|IFS]] ([[R. Sarathkumar]]) who was a forest officer killed by Veerabhadran. The police commissioner and the district collector are corrupt and also support Veerabhadran. In the climax, Veerabhadran kidnaps Prabhakaran's wife and son. Prabhakaran arrives at the right time and saves his wife and son. He then nabs Veerabhadran. Poongudi ([[Ramya Krishnan]]) was Rajaraman's lover. She dies while giving birth to his child. Veerabhadran is shot dead by the corrupt inspector and collector. Prabhakaran kills both of them. He is then dragged to court for killing the police inspector and the collector. Prabhakaran tells the truth that they were corrupt, and the film ends with Prabhakaran being released from the court. ==Cast== * [[Vijayakanth]] as Captain Prabhakaran IFS * [[Sarath Kumar]] as Rajaraman IFS * [[M.N. Nambiar]] as Officer in charge of Special Task Force * [[Rupini (actress)|Rupini]] as Gayathri * [[Ramya Krishnan]] as Poongudi * [[Mansoor Ali Khan (actor)|Mansoor Ali Khan]] as Veerabhadran * [[Livingston (actor)|Livingston]] as Krishnamurthy/Kitti *Peeli Sivam as Raja *[[Ganthimathi]] as Prabhakaran's Mother *Yuvasri as Rajaraman's Sister *Krishnamoorthy as Poongudi's Brother *[[Ponnambalam (actor)|Ponnambalam]] as Sub Inspector (uncredited) *[[LIC Narasimhan]] as Police officer *[[Karikalan]] as Mansoor ali khan's henchman (uncredited) ==Production== After the success of ''[[Pulan Visaranai]]'', Rowther decided to make another project with Vijayakanth and Selvamani titled ''Captain Prabhakaran'', the plotline of the film was based on the forest brigand [[Veerappan]]. The film also was the 100th project of Vijayakanth. The filming was held at [[Chalakudy]] for 60 days.{{cite web|url=http://cinema.maalaimalar.com/2013/09/05231139/selvamani-cinema-history.html|title=Tamil Cinema news - Tamil Movies - Cinema seithigal|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://cinema.maalaimalar.com/2013/09/06231550/selvamani-cinema-history.html|title=Tamil Cinema news - Tamil Movies - Cinema seithigal|publisher=}} The film had Mansoor Ali Khan in his first major role.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/grill-mill-mansoor-ali-khan/article821865.ece|title=Grill Mill - Mansoor Ali Khan|date=9 October 2010|publisher=|via=The Hindu}} During the shoot, a rope to which Vijayakanth was bound snapped and his shoulder got dislocated. With both his hands tied he screamed in pain, but this was mistaken for acting, and as a result, there was a delay in getting medical assistance.{{cite news|last1=Shivakumar|first1=S.|title=Playing a Captain's innings|url=http://www.thehindu.com/thehindu/fr/2005/08/26/stories/2005082600040400.htm|accessdate=16 May 2018|work=The Hindu|date=26 August 2005}} ==Soundtrack== The soundtrack has only two songs composed by [[Ilaiyaraaja]] while the lyrics were written by [[Gangai Amaran]] and [[Piraisoodan]]. The song "Aattama Therottama" is set in the [[carnatic raga]] known as [[Sindhu Bhairavi (raga)|Sindhu Bhairavi]].{{Cite book |title=Raga Chintamani: A Guide to Carnatic Ragas Through Tamil Film Music |last=Sundararaman |publisher=Pichhamal Chintamani |year=2007 |edition=2nd |location=Chennai |pages=125 |oclc=295034757 |ref=harv |orig-year=2005}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.thehindu.com/features/friday-review/music/light-and-melodious/article4702358.ece |title=Light and melodious |last=Mani |first=Charulatha |date=10 May 2013 |work=[[The Hindu]] |access-date=23 July 2018}} It was later remixed by Prasanna Sekhar in ''[[Singakutty]]'' (2008).{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/well-picturised/article1408347.ece|title=Well picturised|date=20 February 2008|publisher=|via=The Hindu}} {{Infobox album | name = Captain Prabhakaran | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Ilaiyaraaja]] | cover = | alt = | released = 1991 | recorded = 1991 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Soundtrack]] | length = 10:21 | label = Oriental Records | producer = [[Ilaiyaraaja]] | prev_title = [[Surya IPS]] | prev_year = 1991 | next_title = Puthiya Swarangal | next_year = 1991 }} {{tracklist | headline = Track list | extra_column = Singer(s) | total_length = 10:21 | title1 = Paasamulla Paandiyare | lyrics1 = [[Gangai Amaran]] | extra1 = [[Mano (singer)|Mano]], [[K. S. Chithra|K. S. Chitra]] | length1 = 5:09 | title2 = Aattama Therottama | lyrics2 = [[Piraisoodan]] | extra2 = [[Swarnalatha]] | length2 = 5:12 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{R. [[File:Sticky And Sweet Tour 2008 Santiago Chile.JPG|thumb|A bird's eye view of [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s 2008 [[Sticky & Sweet Tour]] in the [[Estadio Nacional Julio Martínez Prádanos|national stadium]] of [[Santiago]], Chile.|alt=A stadium filled with spectators on the podiums and on the ground. In the middle is a stage with two giant pink 'M' symbols flanking it. A large flood light is visible behind it.]] A '''concert tour''' (or simply '''tour''') is a series of [[concert]]s by an artist or group of artists in different cities, countries or locations. Often concert tours are named to differentiate different tours by the same artist and to associate a specific tour with a particular album or product (for example: [[U2]]'s [[The Joshua Tree Tour]] named after [[The Joshua Tree|the album]]). Especially in the popular music world, such tours can become large-scale enterprises that last for several months or even years, are seen by hundreds of thousands or millions of people, and bring in millions of dollars (or the equivalent) in ticket revenues. A performer who embarks on a concert tour is called a '''touring artist'''.<ref>https://www.billboard.com/articles/photos/live/488653/hot-tours-roger-waters-mana-bob-dylan</ref><ref>https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7271843/madonna-extends-record-highest-grossing-solo-touring-artist</ref>
Different segments of longer concert tours are known as "legs".<ref>{{cite web|title=What is a Concert Tour?|url=http://tourbeat.com/news-and-announcements/what-is-a-concert-tour|publisher=[[TourBeat]]|accessdate=10 January 2015|quote=A concert tour is an opportunity for musicians to perform over longer periods of time across several cities, which are differentiated by segments known as "legs." Legs of tours of can be denoted by a series of dates that have no long break between them, by geographical regions or destinations, or by different opening acts. Each city or region may have the same opening act for each leg, or they may change opening acts at each city.}}</ref> The different legs of a tour are denoted in different ways, dependent on the artist and type of tour, but the most common means of separating legs are dates (especially if there is a long break at some point), countries and/or continents, or different opening acts. In the largest concert tours it is becoming more common for different legs to employ separate touring production crews and equipment, local to each geographical region.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} Concert tours are often administered on the local level by concert promoters or by [[performing arts presenters]]. Usually, small concert tours are managed by a [[road manager]] whereas large concert tours are managed by a [[tour manager]].
==Logistics== The major challenge in concert tours is how to move the performance's logistics from one venue to another venue, especially for a transcontinental tour. Tour logistics should be very organized and everything has to happen on time and in the right order as planned.<ref name="inbound">{{cite web|url=http://www.inboundlogistics.com/cms/article/taking-the-show-on-the-road/|title=Taking the Show on the Road - Inbound Logistics|website=www.inboundlogistics.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> ''[[Autoweek]]'' magazine estimated 30 to 50 trucks were required by [[Taylor Swift]]'s [[1989 World Tour]] to bring all the stage, sound equipment, instruments, props, and clothes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autoweek.com/article/car-news/how-many-trucks-does-it-take-put-taylor-swift-show|title=How many trucks does it take to put on a Taylor Swift show?|website=autoweek.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> When [[Beyoncé]] visited the United Kingdom with her 2016 [[Formation World Tour]], it took seven [[Boeing 747]] air freighters and a fleet of more than 70 trucks to get her stage set and other gear to the venues. The logistics phase of that tour didn't include transportation of the backstage staff, musicians, performers, and the singer herself.<ref>https://www.bbc.com/news/business-39926895</ref>
Rock-It Cargo is one of the company that provided freight forwarding for some of the biggest names in music, such as [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], and [[The Police]]. Before the start of a tour, Rock-It Cargo had to move gear to a central location—either a rehearsal spot or the site of the first engagement. Then it arranged to transport whatever gear the band requires from one venue to the next. The company's vice president, Ed Butler, said "We use different freight modes—local trucking, cross-country trucking, air freight, and ocean freight. We also provide import, export, customs clearance, carnets (a document that allows a shipper—including a band—to move equipment across international boundaries and clear customs without paying duties)—everything a tour would need."<ref name="inbound"/>
==Boxscore== {{main|List of highest-grossing concert tours}} {{As of|2011}}, the highest-grossing concert tour of all time is [[U2 360 Tour]], with gross revenues of $736,137,344.<ref name="wrap">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/468753/u2-set-to-wrap-biggest-concert-tour-ever|title=U2 Set to Wrap Biggest Concert Tour Ever|first=Ray|last=Waddell|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard.com]]|accessdate=31 July 2011|date=29 July 2011}}</ref> The second highest-grossing concert tour of all time is [[The Rolling Stones]]' [[A Bigger Bang Tour]], which earned approximately $558 million between 2005 and 2007.<ref name="biggerbang">{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1048656/rolling-stones-tour-grosses-more-than-half-a-billion|title=Rolling Stones Tour Grosses More Than Half A Billion |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=2009-11-17|date=April 9, 2007|last=Pietrolungo|first=Silvio}}</ref> Madonna's [[Sticky & Sweet Tour]], which earned $408 million in 2008 and 2009 was the highest-earning tour by a female artist.<ref name="stickysweet">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/photos/live/267516/madonna-closes-tour-in-tel-aviv-2nd-highest-grossing-trek-of-all-time|title=Madonna Closes Tour In Tel Aviv;Second Highest Grossing Trek Of All Time|date=September 2, 2009|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=2014-01-08}}</ref> According to the 2014 report from [[Billboard charts|''Billboard'' Boxscore]], six acts having made over US$ 1 billion in touring since 1990 were the Rolling Stones, U2, [[Bruce Springsteen]], Madonna, [[Coldplay]] and [[Bon Jovi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://consequenceofsound.net/2014/05/these-five-artists-have-made-over-a-billion-dollars-touring/|title=These Five Artists Have Made Over a Billion Dollars Touring|date=27 May 2014|website=consequenceofsound.net|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref>
Global touring revenue reported to ''Billboard'' Boxscore exceeded $5.5 billion in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/events/year-in-music-2016/7616524/concert-touring-business-2016|title=How 'The Shared Live Experience' & Even Streaming Fueled the $25 Billion Concert Biz|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> Due to the collapse of [[record sales]] in the 21st century, concert tours have became a major income for recording artists.<ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/jesselawrence/2014/12/30/with-touring-still-a-focal-point-the-rolling-stones-acdc-and-u2-fight-for-top-honors-in-rock-and-roll-history/#7ae08ca5697d</ref> Besides the tickets, touring also generates money from the sales of [[merchandise]] and meet-and-greet package.<ref>https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/9-ways-musicians-actually-make-money-today-20120828/t-shirts-and-merch-19691231</ref><ref>https://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/packages-to-meet-rock-band-kiss-sell-out-in-mebourne-sydney-and-perth-ahead-of-australian-tour/news-story/360bda71c2ef03387417c68ad7717733</ref>
==Response== The mobility of concert tours requires a lot of costs, times, and energy. British singer [[Adele]] expressed her unhappiness of concert tours, saying "Touring is a peculiar thing, it doesn't suit me particularly well. I'm a real homebody and I get so much joy in the small things."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/this-is-it-adele-hints-to-fans-she-may-never-tour-again-10930875|title='This is it': Adele hints to fans she may never tour again|website=sky.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref> A [[concert residency]] concept is offered as an alternative to performers. As opposed to the concert tour, the concert residency consists of multiple shows in one location.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rebeccalerner/2017/06/14/meet-the-celeb-100-stars-cashing-in-on-the-vegas-residency-boom/2/#1b325f685c01|title=Meet The Celeb 100 Stars Cashing In On The Vegas Residency Boom|first=Rebecca|last=Lerner|website=forbes.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}</ref>
The 2015 study by charity [[Help Musicians UK]] found that over 60% of musicians suffered from depression or other psychological issues, with touring an issue for 71% of respondents.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/25/musicians-touring-psychological-dangers-willis-earl-beal-kate-nash|title=Insomnia, anxiety, break-ups … musicians on the dark side of touring|first=Luke Morgan|last=Britton|date=25 June 2015|publisher=|accessdate=4 December 2017|via=www.theguardian.com}}</ref>
