revision.text:
Students of [[George Mason University]], as part of Professor T. Mills Kelly's course – "Lying about the past", have created two popular [[hoax]]es: the "Edward Owens hoax," and the "Reddit serial killer hoax." It is a goal of the course to create a sweeping internet deception. As Prof. Kelly stated in the course's syllabus:
{{Cquote|What's our goal? Buzz, of course! Viral! We want our hoax to be picked up and spread around the Internet like wildfire!}}
==Edward Owens hoax==<!--Anchor for redirect; caution.--> The Edward Owens hoax was a historical hoax created by students at [[George Mason University]] in 2008 as a class project for "Lying About the Past". The students created a website and a [[fictitious entry]] on [[English Wikipedia]] about Edward Owens, purportedly a [[Virginia]] oyster fisherman born in 1853 who became a [[piracy|pirate]]. The hoax was reported as true in some media outlets.<ref name="Atlantic">{{cite news |title=How the Professor Who Fooled Wikipedia Got Caught by Reddit |author=Yoni Appelbaum |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2012/05/how-the-professor-who-fooled-wikipedia-got-caught-by-reddit/257134/ |newspaper=[[The Atlantic]] |date=May 15, 2012 |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref>
===Hoax description=== Students published a blog and videos about then fictional Owens, created by the fictional student "Jane Browning". The blog asserted that Owens fell on hard times during the [[Long Depression]] of the 1870s and took up piracy in [[Chesapeake Bay]] to survive. The students wrote that he robbed smaller [[commercial vessel]]s and wealthy pleasure boaters from [[Maryland]] using a [[punt gun]] to threaten his victims. The class created a fake [[Will (law)|will]], which asserted that Owens and his crew eventually went back to oyster fishing.<ref name="Chron"/><ref>{{cite news|title=The 10 biggest hoaxes in Wikipedia's first 10 years |author=Jon Brodkin |url=http://www.networkworld.com/news/2011/011411-wikipedia-hoaxes.html |newspaper=[[Network World]] |date=January 14, 2011 |accessdate=May 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013195214/http://www.networkworld.com/news/2011/011411-wikipedia-hoaxes.html |archivedate=October 13, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playingwithhistory.com/www.playingwithhistory.com/wp-content/uploads/Kelly_samplechapter.pdf |title=True Facts or False Facts—Which Are More Authentic? |author=T. Mills Kelly |date= |work= |publisher=''Playing With History'' |accessdate=May 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617063030/http://www.playingwithhistory.com/www.playingwithhistory.com/wp-content/uploads/Kelly_samplechapter.pdf |archivedate=June 17, 2012 |df= }}</ref> The students later created a hoax biography of Owens on Wikipedia.<ref name="Chron">{{cite journal |url=http://chronicle.com/article/Teaching-by-Lying-Professor/1420 |title=Teaching by Lying: Professor Unveils 'Last Pirate' Hoax |journal=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]] |last=Howard |first=Jennifer |date=18 December 2008}}{{paywall}}</ref>
After some media outlets and academics reported the hoax as factual, the class divulged the hoax.<ref>Matheson, Whitney. [https://web.archive.org/web/20081205232921/http://blogs.usatoday.com/popcandy/2008/12/ahoy-delve-into.html Pop Candy blog], USAToday.com, December 4, 2008</ref><ref>[http://bavatuesdays.com/the-last-american-pirate/ "The Last American Pirate"], December 4, 2008</ref>
==Reddit serial killer hoax==<!--Anchor for redirect; caution.--> The Reddit serial killer hoax was a second historical hoax perpetrated by "Lying about the past" class members. This one quickly failed, unlike the Owens hoax. In 2012, Professor Kelly taught the course for a second time in a similar format. The Reddit hoax, about an alleged serial killer named Joseph Scafe, was launched on the [[Reddit]] site on the 28th of April, and was first debunked in just over an hour.<ref name="Atlantic" /><ref name=HatesRedditors>{{cite web | url=https://www.reddit.com/r/AskReddit/comments/sxkig/opinions_please_reddit_do_you_think_my_uncle_joe/c4htt9n |title=HatesRedditors comments on Opinions: "Please, Reddit. Do you think my 'Uncle' Joe was just weird or possibly a serial killer?" |publisher=Reddit.com |date=2012-04-28 |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref>
===Hoax description=== The participating students created a [[Sockpuppet (Internet)|sockpuppet]] named Lisa Quinn, and under her name opened a [[Wordpress.com]] blog entitled: "I think my uncle was a serial killer."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://lisaquinn565.wordpress.com/ |title=I Think My Uncle Was A Serial Killer |publisher=Lisaquinn565.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref> In her blog, Lisa wrote that she found some odd items in a Saratoga steamer trunk that she received upon the death of her grandparents. Lisa posted pictures of the trunk; ladies shoes she presumably found inside the trunk; and newspaper clippings from 1895; one of which was about the murder of Alice Walsh—later identified as having been taken from the April 22, 1895 edition of ''[[The Evening World]]''.<ref name="The evening world">{{cite news | title=Who Killed Alice Walsh? |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1895-04-22/ed-1/seq-1/ |newspaper=''[[The Evening World]]'' |date=April 22, 1895 }}</ref> According to Lisa's post, the trunk belonged to a relative, Joseph Scafe, (also called 'Uncle Joe'), and that it contained—in a false panel—ladies' jewelry and a "disturbing" journal. Lisa supposedly wanted to know if—in the opinion of her readers—her uncle was a serial killer.
With a new [[Sockpuppet (Internet)|sockpuppet]], DisturbedThrowaway, the students attempted to start the spread of the hoax with a posting of a question on AskReddit: "Do you think my uncle Joe was just weird or possibly a serial killer?"<ref name=HatesRedditors/> Through Reddit, the hoax was expected to spread. At first, the hoax aroused interest. Many posters requested more photos (which DisturbedThrowaway declined) and alluded to the commercial success the case could lead to. The name of [[Jack the Ripper]] was mentioned as well. Yet, within 26 minutes, suspicions were rising. DisturbedThrowaway, the poster of the question, claimed to have found the names of two victims, Alice Walsh and Diamond Flossie, in the documents she retrieved. She asked the redditors for assistance in research; however, a quick Wikipedia search brought forth information connected with the two names, and posters at the site wondered why DisturbedThrowaway hadn't perform such a simple search herself.
===Discovery=== Just over an hour after the initial posting, HatesRedditors suggested that the post was [[viral marketing]].<ref name=HatesRedditors /> He noted that the Wikipedia entries for the victims had been created within two weeks of the posting and the pictures in the articles looked faked. The students tried to keep the deception going for several weeks, but the story was exposed. On May 14, Kelly revealed the serial killer hoax on his blog.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://edwired.org/2012/05/14/serial-killers-beer-and-lies-about-the-past/ |title=Serial Killers, Beer, and Lies About the Past |publisher=edwired |date=2012-05-14 |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref>
==Aftermath== With the latest hoax exposed, Wikipedia deleted the two entries about Alice Walsh and Diamond Flossie which had been written by the students’ sockpuppets. The professor and students claimed that the subjects were factual, but Wikipedia found them to be of insufficient notability. Wikipedia administrators did raise questions about the course's [[situational ethics]], however, as some claimed that Professor Kelly legitimized [[Vandalism on Wikipedia|Wikipedia vandalism]].<ref name=Wikipedia>{{cite web | title=Admin discussion|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Administrators%27_noticeboard/Archive235#Articles_created_for_the_good_of_education|date= 16–19 May 2012|accessdate=2017-01-30}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=February 2017}}
Professor Kelly did not express regret in this matter, "I don't think there were any real victims here", he blogged: {{cquote|I will also continue to teach Lying About the Past. Given the ubiquitous nature of Wikipedia in the information landscape, I think it's fair to say that whenever I teach the course again, Wikipedia will be a part of it some way, some how.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://edwired.org/2012/06/01/wikipedia-and-me/ |title=Wikipedia and Me |publisher=edwired |date=2012-06-01 |accessdate=2012-07-20}}</ref>}}
==Results== Yoni Appelbaum wrote in ''[[The Atlantic]]'' an article, "How the Professor Who fooled Wikipedia Got Caught by Reddit," in which he compared the serial killer hoax and the last pirate hoax. In his article, he wondered why the 2008 hoax was successful, while this hoax failed in minutes. One answer he suggested was that Wikipedia has a trusting community, while Reddit has a critical and skeptical community.<ref name="Atlantic"/>
In March 2013, Kelly announced that he would no longer be teaching the course, after the university declined to make it part of the regular curriculum of his department,<ref name="Mills Kelly">{{citation | url=http://edwired.org/2013/03/31/no-more-lying-about-the-past/ |title=No More Lying About the Past |publisher=Center for History and New Media, George Mason University |date=March 31, 2013 |author=Mills Kelly }}</ref> however, as of February 2015 Professor Mills continues to delve into topics dealing with editing and/or manipulating Wikipedia in his [[digital history]] class<ref>[http://edwired.org/courses/h390sp15/ History 390 Digital History Class]</ref> at George Mason University.<ref>[http://edwired.org/courses/h390sp15/ The Digital Past 2015]</ref> As of February 2016, all references to the hoaxes and classes have been removed from the university's web pages.

Monica Sears ([[Vice President|VP]] of Operations) | products = | owner = | num_employees = | num_employees_year = | parent = | website = }} '''Golden Boy Promotions''', Inc. is an American boxing and mixed martial arts promotion firm based in [[Los Angeles, California]] which was established in 2002 by 10-time world champion (in six divisions) [[Oscar De La Hoya]]. "Golden Boy" is one of boxing’s most active and high profile promoters, presenting shows worldwide. == History == In 2005 Golden Boy Enterprises announced the formation of Golden Boy Partners, a company focused on urban development in Latino communities.[http://www.goldenboypromotions.com/media/2005/april/goldenboy_partners.html :: Golden Boy Promotions Inc. ::] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927191135/http://www.goldenboypromotions.com/media/2005/april/goldenboy_partners.html |date=2008-09-27 }} [[File:Richard Schaefer with Mayweather and Ortiz.jpg|thumb|Richard Schaefer making a speech at the press conference for the fight between [[Victor Ortiz vs. Floyd Mayweather|Victor Ortiz and Floyd Mayweather, Jr.]]]] Golden Boy promoted the May 5, 2007, [[De La Hoya-Mayweather|"super fight"]] between De La Hoya and [[Floyd Mayweather]] at the [[MGM Grand Garden Arena|MGM Grand]] in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. Mayweather won the bout by a split decision. The fight once held the record for most pay-per-view buys and once held the record as the second highest grossing fight in the history of the sport.{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenboypromotions.com/media/2006/dec/5.5.07_0scar_banner.htm|title=:: Golden Boy Promotions Inc. ::|publisher=}} They also co-promoted along with Top Rank, The Dream Match: Oscar De La Hoya Vs Manny Pacquiao on December 6, 2008. In June 2009, Golden Boy Enterprises became embroiled in a dispute over who would fight for the WBA junior welterweight title. On the one hand, undefeated [[Dmitry Salita]] (the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]]'s No. 1-ranked 140-pounder) was told by the WBA in writing that he will face the winner of the June 27 fight between titleholder [[Andreas Kotelnik]] and [[Amir Khan (British boxer)|Amir Khan]]. On the other hand, [[Richard Schaefer]] of Golden Boy said that ''he'' had it "in writing" that that fight would face the winner of the [[Victor Ortíz]]-Marcos Maidana fight.{{cite web|url=http://www.ringtv.com/blog/712/salita_could_be_odd_man_out_in_wba_junior_welterweight_derby/|title=Data|publisher=}} The WBA's top executives were unavailable for comment. Salita was extremely upset over the prospect that he could lose what would be his first title shot. "They're a big company", he said of Golden Boy. "They're trying to bend the rules. They're trying to kick everyone to the side and get their way, rules or no rules. When Oscar De La Hoya formed Golden Boy, he said he wanted to change boxing, to bring honor to the sport. This isn't the honorable thing to do. This isn't good for boxing. This isn't justice. This goes against the right to pursue happiness, which is why my family immigrated to this country (from Ukraine) and why I've worked so hard. We'll see what happens." Salita ended up fighting Khan, losing by 1st-round TKO. In January 2017, Golden Boy signed a contract to bring their boxing promotions to ESPN under a two year deal of a total of 48 fights{{Cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/boxing/story/_/id/18508305/golden-boy-promotions-espn-enter-partnership-42-fight-cards-next-two-years |title='Golden Boy Boxing on ESPN' begins partnership in March |last=Rafael |first=Dan |date=2017-01-19 |website=ESPN.com |publisher=ESPN Inc |access-date=2018-05-07}}. In October 2018, [[Canelo Álvarez|Canelo Alvarez]] (50-1-2, 34 KOs), the undisputed king of pay-per-view boxing will usher in a new era in the sport by signing an 11-fight deal with sports streaming site [[DAZN]]. The journey begins Saturday, Dec. 15 when Canelo makes his first appearance at the historic [[Madison Square Garden]] challenging [[Rocky Fielding]] (27-1, 15 KOs) for the [[List of WBA world champions#Super middleweight|WBA Super Middleweight World Championship]]. revision.comment: I have removed the nonsense about the etymology of Hop-tu-naa as it is clearly a nonsense rhyme and makes NO sense in Manx or in Irish or Scottish Gaelic but such rhymes are very common. I have also explained that 'Oie Houney' is the same as Irish Oíche Shamhna (which is pronounced the same) and which IS halloween.
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} '''Hop-tu-Naa''' is a [[Celt]]ic festival celebrated in the [[Isle of Man]] on 31 October. It is the celebration of the original New Year's Eve ({{lang|gl|Oie Houney}}). It is thought to be the oldest unbroken tradition in the Isle of Man.[http://www.culturevannin.im/oral_history_article_452607.html Oral history interview with Sue Woolley conducted by [[Culture Vannin]], 19 October 2016] [[File:Hop-tu-naa turnip with witch and cat.jpg|thumb|Hop-tu-naa turnip with witch and cat]] ==Etymology== Hop-tu-Naa is a continuation of the Manx Oie Houiney, which is exactly the same as the Irish Oíche Shamhna and which is pronounced the same. The exact status of Oíche Shamhna and its role in the Celtic calendar has been a matter of debate. Oíche Shamhna eventually mutated in to Halloween in northern England and in Ireland, it was carried to America by Irish immigrants and developed in to the modern Halloween. The term ‘Hop-tu-naa’ comes from a Manx Gaelic song traditionally sung during the festival which included the nonsense Hop-tu-naa as part of the rhyme scheme, such nonsense rhymes are common theme in Irish and Scottish Gaelic music. ==Traditions== On the Isle of Man today, many groups of people continue the tradition of singing Hop-tu-Naa songs "around the houses"{{clarifyme|date=April 2018}} with turnip lanterns. In addition to this, many Hop-tu-Naa events take place across the Isle of Man each year, most of which today include competitions for turnip{{clarifyme|date=April 2018}} and the singing of traditional songs. As well as the many events run within local communities, the National Folk Museum at [[Cregneash]] hosts an event to teach the traditional Hop-tu-Naa song and to help people to carve turnips.[http://www.manx.net/isle-of-man-news/595/hop-tu-naa-celebrations-at-cregneash Manx National Heritage. "Hop Tu Naa Celebrations at Cregneash", ''Isle of Man News'', 26 October 2010] ===Turnip lanterns=== At the modern Hop-tu-Naa, children dress up and go from house to house hoping to be given sweets or money, as elsewhere. The children carry carved "[[Swede (vegetable)|turnip]]" lanterns (which are known as "moots" by the Manx) and sing Hop-tu-Naa songs. There are regional varieties of how turnips should be carved for Hop-tu-Naa, with variations focusing on which way up the turnip is and the nature of the decorations. It is believed that turnip-lanterns do not date earlier than the start of the 19th century, as the vegetable had only been introduced at the end of the previous century.[https://vimeo.com/188829706 ''When did the Manx first carve turnips?'' by [[Culture Vannin]], available on [[Vimeo]]] In the past children would bring the stumps of turnips with them and batter the doors of those who refused to give them any money, in an ancient form of [[trick or treat]]. This practice appears to have died out.[http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/fulltext/folklore/ch06.htm ''Folk Lore of the Isle of Man'' by A. W. Moore, Isle of Man: Brown & Son, Isle of Man, 1891] ===Dancing=== A [[Hop-tu-Naa (dance)|hop-tu-naa dance]] was collected by both [[Mona Douglas]] and Leighton Stowell. It was believed to have been danced through the streets on Hop-tu-Naa night by couples carrying their turnip-lanterns.''Rinkaghyn Vannin: Dances of Mann'' Isle of Man: Sleih gyn Thie. 1983 It is a simple procession dance for pairs of dancers which involves the Manx reel step and a combination of arches only.[http://www.culturevannin.im/media//media%20-%20Customs%20and%20traditions/Hop%20tu%20Naa/Hop-tu-naa%20dance%20instructions.pdf 'Hop tu naa – Hollantide Dance' instructions (accessed 18 October 2017) This dance is taught in many schools on the Isle of Man during October each year, and it is danced at many of the Hop-tu-Naa events across the island.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RDeM6DJga20&t=1s 'Hop-tu-naa: A traditional Manx celebration in Maughold'] on YouTube (accessed 18 October 2017) ===Divination=== Some of the older customs are similar to those now attached to the January New Year. It was a time for prophesying, weather prediction and fortune-telling.[http://smo.uhi.ac.uk/~stephen/chiollaghbooks/JC_MXREM_S.pdf ''Cooinaghtyn Manninagh: Manx Reminiscences'' by Dr John Clague, ed. Stephen Miller, Chiollagh Books, 2005 (originally published 1911)] Last thing at night, the ashes of a fire were smoothed out on the hearth to receive the imprint of a foot. If, next morning, the track pointed towards the door, someone in the house would die, but if the footprint pointed inward, it indicated a birth. A cake was made which was called Soddag Valloo or Dumb Cake, because it was made and eaten in silence. Young women and girls all had a hand in baking it on the red embers of the hearth, first helping to mix the ingredients (flour, eggs, eggshells, soot and salt) and kneading the dough. The cake was divided up and eaten in silence and, still without speaking, all who had eaten it went to bed, walking backwards, expecting and hoping to see their future husband in a dream or vision. The future husband was expected to appear in the dream and offer a drink of water.''Manx Calendar Customs'' by Cyril Ingram Paton, Cribyn: Llanerch Press, 2004 (originally published 1942) Other means of divination was to steal a salt herring from a neighbour, roast it over the fire, eat it in silence and retire to bed.; or to hold a mouthful of water in your mouth and a pinch of salt in each hand as you listen to a neighbour's conversation, whereupon the first name mentioned would be that of your future spouse.[https://vimeo.com/188833786 ''A Manx Superstition for Hop-tu-naa'' by [[Culture Vannin]], available on [[Vimeo]]] ===Traditional foods=== Traditional food for Hop-tu-Naa includes ''mrastyr'': potatoes, parsnips and fish mashed up with butter. Any leftovers from this evening meal would be left out with crocks of fresh water for the [[fairies]].[https://wiki1.sch.im/wiki/pages/5540B66/RECIPES_(hop_tu_naa).html Recipes, Hop-tu-naa] on the Manx curriculum website Toffee would also be made, with just sugar and water, as a communal activity on the evening of Hop-tu-Naa.[https://soundcloud.com/manxliterature/hilda-cowin-november-12th-read-by-constance-radcliffe ''November 12th''] by Hilda Cowin, read by Constance Radcliffe in 1986. Released on [[SoundCloud]] by ManxLiterature.com ==Songs== ===The Hop-tu-Naa Song=== {| cellspacing="10px" |- ! Hop-tu-Naa (as collected by [[Arthur William Moore|A. W. Moore]])[http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/fulltext/mb1896/p068.htm ''Manx Ballads and Music'' edited by A. W. Moore, Douglas: G & R Johnson, 1896] ! English translation ! Hop! Ta’n Oie
(as collected by [[Dr. John Clague]]) ! English translation |- | {{lang|gl|Shoh shenn oie Houiney; Hop-tu-naa}} | This is old Sauin night; Hop-tu-naa | {{lang|gl|Hop! ta'n oie. Ren eh scryssey}} | Hop! ta’n oie. He grinned. |- | {{lang|gl|Er my raad thie, Hop-tu-naa.}} | On my way back, Hop-tu-naa | {{lang|gl|Hop! ta'n oie. Ren mee roie. }} | Hop! ta’n oie. I ran. |- | {{lang|gl|Veeit mee kayt-vuitsh; Trol-la-laa.}} | I met a witch cat; Trol-la-laa. | {{lang|gl|Hop! ta'n oie. Roie mee gys Nalbin. }} | Hop! ta’n oie. I ran to Scotland. |- | {{lang|gl|Va yn chayt-scryssey, Hop-tu-naa.}} | The cat began to grin, Hop-tu-naa | {{lang|gl|Hop! ta'n oie. Cre naight ayns shen?}} | Hop! ta’n oie. What news there? |- | {{lang|gl|As ren mee roie ersooyl. Trol-la-laa.}} | And I ran away. Trol-la-laa. | {{lang|gl|Hop! ta'n oie. Yn cheeaght va traaue. }} | Hop! ta’n oie. Hop! ta'n oie.}} | With the light of the moon. |- | {{lang|gl|Hop-tu-naa, Trol-la-laa}} | Hop-tu-naa, Trol-la-laa | {{lang|gl|Hop! ta'n oie. }} | Hop! ta’n oie. |} ===Modern Hop-tu-Naa songs=== Different versions of Hop-tu-naa songs were sung in different areas of the island. "Jinnie the Witch" is a modern [[Manx English]] song, which was sung around the Douglas area.[http://www.smo.uhi.ac.uk/~stephen/manxnotes/MN144.pdf ‘How Old is Jinny the Witch?’] ed. Stephen Miller, ‘’Manx Notes’’ 144 (2013) According to Hampton Creer, Jinny's real name was Joney Lowney. She lived in [[Braddan]] and was tried at Bishop's Court for [[witchcraft]] in 1715 and 1716. Her greatest "crime" was stopping the Ballaughton Corn Mill. She was sentenced to 14 days' imprisonment, fined £3 and made to stand at the four market crosses dressed in sackcloth.[http://www.culturevannin.im/oral_history_article_288508.html Oral history interview with Hampton Creer] conducted by [[Culture Vannin]] The modern song goes as follows : [[File:Hop-tu-naa turnip with face.jpg|thumb|A Hop-tu-Naa turnip carved with a face]] :Hop-tu-Naa :My mother's gone away :And she won't be back until the morning :Jinnie the Witch flew over the house :To fetch the stick to lather the mouse :Hop-tu-Naa :My mother's gone away :And she won't be back until the morning :Hop-tu-Naa, Traa-la-laa[http://namanx.blogspot.com/2014/10/hop-tu-naa-who-was-jinny-witch.html Caine, Valerie. "Hop tu Naa - Who Was Jinny the Witch?", North American Manx Association, 31 October 2014] In the West of the Island a longer version was sung, which is more closely related to the Manx version. The following version dates from the 1930s – a similar version is recorded in "A Vocabulary of the Anglo-Manx Dialect" by [[Arthur William Moore|A. W. Moore]], [[Sophia Morrison]] and Edmund Goodwin (1924):[http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/fulltext/am1924/index.htm ''A Vocabulary of the Anglo-Manx Dialect'' compiled by A. W. Moore with the co-operation of Sophia Morrison and Edmund Goodwin, Oxford University Press, 1924] [[File:Manx Ballads and Music by A. W. Moore - 1st edition front cover.jpg|thumb|350px|''Manx Ballads and Music'' by A. W. Moore; the earliest book published featuring the Hop-tu-naa song and music]] :Hop-tu-naa! put in the pot :Hop-tu-naa! put in the pan :Hop-tu-naa! I burnt me throt (throat) :Hop-tu-naa! guess where I ran? :Hop-tu-naa! I ran to the well :Hop-tu-naa! and drank my fill :Hop-tu-naa! and on the way back :Hop-tu-naa! I met a witch cat :Hop-tu-naa! the cat began to grin :Hop-tu-naa! and I began to run :Hop-tu-naa! I ran to Ronague :Hop-tu-naa! guess what I saw there? :Hop-tu-naa! I saw an old woman :Hop-tu-naa! baking bonnags :Hop-tu-naa! roasting sconnags :Hop-tu-naa! I asked her for a bit :Hop-tu-naa! she gave me a bit :as big as me big toe :Hop-tu-naa! she dipped it in milk :Hop-tu-naa! she wrapped it in silk :Hop-tu-naa! Traa la lay! :If you're going to give us anything, give it to us soon :before we run away with the light of the moon! The 1970s Southern version from Castletown includes the mention of the Witches Mill, the Smelt Monument and the Old House of Keys: :This is auld hollantide night, the moon shines clear and bright :Hop-tu-naa, traa-la-laa :Jinnie the witch jumped over the college to fetch the stick to stir the porridge :Hop-tu-naa, traa-la-laa :Castletown square is mighty bare, there isn't a statue that should have been there :Hop-tu-naa, traa-la-laa :The castle is grey, and Parliament gone, the harbour is quiet no smugglers run :Hop-tu-naa, traa-la-laa :when lights were turned out and no sweets were given, there was a further chorus:- :This is old hollantide night, the moon is shining bright :if you're going to bring us money :You better bring it quick :as we may start to sing again, and your neighbours will think you're thick :Hop-tu-naa, traa-la-laa :Jinnie the witch is over the mill if you don't give us something quick :she will come and get you. New songs for Hop-tu-Naa continue to be created, the most notable of which was written by Scaanjoon in 2015, having been commissioned by [[Culture Vannin]].[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SCklUnMN0Ks ''Creepy Folk Come Down''] by Scanjoon on [[YouTube]] This has been taken up by the Manx traditional music youth group, Bree, as a part of their repertoire.[https://vimeo.com/148399448 ''"Creepy Folk Come Down" - Big Bree Workshop Weekend 2015 Concert 1''] released by [[Culture Vannin]] on [[Vimeo]] ==Images of carved hop-tu-naa turnips== File:Hop-tu-naa turnip with witch and cat.jpg File:Turnip carved with hop-tu-naa.jpg File:Hop-tu-naa turnip carving of town.jpg File:Hop-tu-naa turnip with face.jpg File:Hop-tu-naa turnip with Jinny the Witch.jpg File:Hop-tu-naa turnip with witch.jpg File:Carved Hop-tu-naa turnip.jpg File:Hop-tu-naa turnip decoration - cottage.jpg File:Hop-tu-naa turnip decoration - cat.jpg File:Hop-tu-naa turnip decoration - castle.jpg File:Hop-tu-naa carved on turnip.jpg ==See also== * [[Allantide]] * [[Calan Gaeaf]] * [[Guising]] * [[Halloween]] * [[Hogmanay]] * [[Samhain]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://wiki1.sch.im/wiki/pages/a1c9J1T4N/Hop_tu_Naa_Resources.html Hoptunaa information and resources] from [[Culture Vannin]] * [http://www.culturevannin.im/video_story_452243.html ''Hop-tu-naa turnip carving''], a short video explaining how to carve a traditional [[Peel, Isle of Man|Peel]] turnip * [https://soundcloud.com/culture-vannin/sets/hop-tu-naa Recordings of the songs associated with hop-tu-naa] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2F5B8gzKAQY A performance of the hop-tu-naa dance] {{Halloween}} [[Category:Festivals in the Isle of Man]] [[Category:Halloween]] [[Category:October observances]] [[Category:Manx words and phrases]] [[Category:Celtic music festivals]] [[Category:Autumn events in the Isle of Man]]

{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use British English|date=July 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:Virgin Killer.jpg|thumb|The cover of the album ''[[Virgin Killer]]'', the image which instigated the controversy]] On 5 December 2008, the [[Internet Watch Foundation]] (IWF), a British [[watchdog group]], [[Blacklist (computing)|blacklisted]] content on the [[English Wikipedia]] related to [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions']] 1976 studio album ''[[Virgin Killer]]'', due to the presence of its controversial [[cover art]]work, depicting a young girl posing nude, with a faux glass shatter obscuring her genitalia. The image was deemed to be "potentially illegal content" under [[Protection of Children Act 1978|English law]] which forbids the possession or creation of indecent photographs of children. The IWF's blacklist are used in [[web filtering]] systems such as [[Cleanfeed (content blocking system)|Cleanfeed]].
The [[URL]] to the image's {{srlink|Help:File page|description page}}, which depicts the cover art, was also blacklisted; however thumbnails and the image itself remained accessible. The album cover had been deemed controversial at the time of its release,<ref name="Buck">{{cite book |last=Berelian |first=Essi |editor=Buckley, Peter |editor2=Buckley Jonathan (eds.) |title=The Rough Guide to Rock |publisher=Rough Guides |year=2003 |location=London |page=909 |isbn=1-84353-105-4}}</ref> and was replaced in some markets with an alternate cover image featuring a photo of the band members.<ref name="Buck"/> The IWF described the image as "a potentially illegal indecent image of a child under the age of 18".<ref name="WP">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/blog/2008/dec/08/internet |first=Jack |last=Schofield |title=Wikipedia page censored in the UK for 'child pornography'|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=8 December 2008|accessdate=9 December 2008 }}</ref> Wikipedia's policies state that it does not censor content "that some readers consider objectionable or offensive, even exceedingly so", although it does remove content that is "obviously inappropriate", violates other Wikipedia policies, or is illegal in the United States.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:What_Wikipedia_is_not&oldid=632013195 | title=Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not | work=Wikipedia | date=1 November 2014 | accessdate=6 November 2014}}</ref>
As well as the direct consequence of censoring the article and image for UK-based readers of the English Wikipedia through the affected [[ISP]]s (a censoring that could be circumvented),<ref>Investigation by several UK based Wikipedians revealed that the page/image was still available using direct addressing URL parameters, or by using the Wikipedia secure server, as detailed in an [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Administrators%27_noticeboard/2008_IWF_action internal discussion] of the issue at the ''Administrator's Noticeboard'' at the time</ref> and that the album cover was being made available unfiltered on other major sites including [[Amazon.co.uk]]<ref name=WP/> (from which it was later removed), and available for sale in the UK,<ref name="guardian1">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2008/dec/08/wikipedia-censorship |title=Wikipedia falls foul of British censors|work=The Guardian |location=UK |first=Bobbie |last=Johnson |date=8 December 2008|accessdate=9 December 2008 }}</ref> the action also had some indirect [[#Effects on Wikipedia|effects on Wikipedia]], namely temporarily preventing all editors using said ISPs in the UK from contributing to any page of the encyclopedia,<ref name="YahooNews8Dec08LeClaire">{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nf/20081208/bs_nf/63458 |title=UK Agency Blocks Wikipedia Image, Editing of Site |publisher=[[Yahoo News]] |date=8 December 2008<!-- 4:48 pm ET -->|accessdate=9 December 2008 |author=Jennifer LeClaire |quote=On its Web site, Wikipedia said several large ISPs that cooperate with the IWF subsequently blocked the image, affecting an estimated 95 percent of residential Internet users in the UK ... ". Due to the way the block was created (via transparent proxies), users from the affected ISPs now share a small number of IP addresses. This means that a user committing vandalism cannot be distinguished from all the other people on the same ISP," Wikipedia said ... ". Unfortunately, the effect of this is that all users from the affected ISPs are temporarily blocked from editing Wikipedia. Simply viewing the site is not affected, aside from the blocked article and image."}}{{Dead link|date=July 2009}}</ref> and preventing anonymous edits from these ISPs while the URL remained on the blacklist. This was described by the IWF as unintended "collateral damage".<ref name="AP8Dec08Satter">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/wikipedia-article-blocked-in-uk-over-child-photo-1057010.html|title= Wikipedia article blocked in UK over child photo|work=The Independent |location=UK |author=Raphael G. Satter|date=8 December 2008|accessdate=18 May 2009|quote="It appears that there's a large number of editors — I can't say all — who appear to have access issues," [Jay Walsh, Wikimedia Foundation] said. [Sarah Robertson, Internet Watch Foundation] said she could not explain reports that other parts of the site were difficult to navigate as a result of the block. "There shouldn't have been any collateral damage," she said. }}</ref> This was due to the proxies used to access Wikipedia, as Wikipedia implements a blocking policy whereby contributors can be blocked if they vandalise the encyclopedia. Therefore, all vandalism coming from one ISP would be directed through one proxy—hence one IP—and all of the ISP's customers using that proxy would be barred from editing.
After invoking its appeals procedure and reviewing the situation, the IWF reversed their blacklisting of the page on 9 December 2008,<ref name="g2">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2008/dec/09/wikipedia-censorship-iwf-reconsiders|title=Internet Watch Foundation reconsiders Wikipedia censorship|work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=9 December 2008|accessdate=10 December 2008 | first=Charles | last=Arthur}}</ref><ref name="cio">{{cite web|url=http://www.cio.com/article/470014/U.K._Wikipedia_Blacklisting_Dropped|title=U.K. Wikipedia Blacklisting Dropped|publisher=CIO|date=9 December 2008|accessdate=10 December 2008}}</ref> and announced that they would not blacklist other copies of the image hosted outside the UK.<ref name="IWF9">{{cite web|url=http://www.iwf.org.uk/about-iwf/news/post/251-iwf-statement-regarding-wikipedia-webpage|title=IWF statement regarding Wikipedia webpage|publisher=Internet Watch Foundation|date=9 December 2008|accessdate=2 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101075354/http://www.iwf.org.uk/about-iwf/news/post/251-iwf-statement-regarding-wikipedia-webpage|archivedate=1 January 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Background == {{further|Virgin Killer#Cover art}} The album art of the [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions']] album ''[[Virgin Killer]]'', featuring a young girl fully nude with a "smashed glass" effect covering her genitalia,<ref name="guardian1"/> was deemed controversial at the time of its release.<ref name="Buck"/> The cover was replaced in some markets with an alternate cover image featuring a photo of the band members. [[RCA Records]] refused to sell the controversial album cover in the United States.<ref>Yasui, Todd. [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73626746.html?dids=73626746:73626746&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&fmac=&date=Aug+30%2C+1988&author=Todd+Allan+Yasui&desc=The+Sign+of+the+Scorpions%3BThe+West+German+Metal+Meisters%27+Tour+de+Force “The Sign of the Scorpions; The West German Metal Meisters' Tour de Force,”] Washington Post (30 August 1988).</ref> The cover was not the only Scorpions' cover which caused controversy however, as the covers for ''[[Taken by Force]]''<ref name="RothRules">{{cite web |author=Syrjälä, Marko |title=Interview with Uli Jon Roth |url=http://www.metal-rules.com/zine/content/view/748/0/ |publisher=Metal-rules.com |accessdate=12 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wYpYzYMv?url=http://www.metal-rules.com/zine/content/view/748/0/ |archivedate=17 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and ''[[Lovedrive]]''<ref name="Buck"/> have also caused controversy with their content.
In the United Kingdom, access to illegal content (such as [[child pornography]]) was strictly self-regulated by individual [[internet service provider]]s. This began when [[BT Group]] introduced [[Cleanfeed (content blocking system)|Cleanfeed]], a server-side [[Content-control software|filtering system]] which uses data obtained from the [[Internet Watch Foundation]]. The IWF is a [[Quango]] organisation that operates a website where users can report web pages containing illegal or dubious content to be added to their blacklists.<ref name="cleanfeedbegin">{{cite news|url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0,6903,1232422,00.html|title=BT puts block on child porn sites|work=The Observer |location=UK |accessdate=10 December 2008 | first=Martin | last=Bright | date=6 June 2004}}</ref> This was implemented in order to prevent users from accessing this material, since it is illegal to possess an indecent image of a child under the age of 18 per the [[Protection of Children Act 1978|Protection of Children Act]].<ref>Internet Watch Foundation — R v Bowden {{cite web |url=http://www.iwf.org.uk/police/page.99.209.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080929093650/http://www.iwf.org.uk/police/page.99.209.htm |archivedate=29 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> British ISPs were later obligated by the government to implement filters for illegal content by the beginning of 2007.<ref name="LINX">"[http://publicaffairs.linx.net/news/?p=497 Government sets deadline for universal network-level content blocking] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060601194532/http://publicaffairs.linx.net/news/?p=497 |date=1 June 2006 }}", LINX, 29 May 2006. Retrieved 29 May 2006.</ref><ref>"[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/05/18/uk_site_blocking/ Govt sets target for blocking child porn sites]", The Register, 18 May 2006. Retrieved 29 May 2006.</ref>
== Addition to IWF blacklist == On 5 December 2008 the Internet Watch Foundation added the [[Wikipedia]] [[URL]]s for the ''Virgin Killer'' article and the [[:Image:Virgin Killer.jpg|description page of the image]] to its blacklist.<ref name="gamazon">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2008/dec/08/amazon-internet-censorship-iwf|title=Internet watchdog considers censoring Amazon US over Scorpions image|last=Arthur|first=Charles|date=8 December 2008|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=8 December 2008 }}</ref> After the blacklisting, users of major UK ISPs, including [[BT Group|BT]], [[Vodafone]], [[Virgin Media]]/[[Tesco|Tesco.net]], [[Be Unlimited|Be]]/[[Telefónica Europe|O2]], [[UK Online|EasyNet/UK Online]]/[[Sky Broadband]], [[Orange United Kingdom|Orange]], [[Demon Internet|Demon]], and [[TalkTalk (telecommunications company)|TalkTalk]] (Opal Telecom), were unable to access the content.<ref name=WP/>
Sarah Robertson, director of communications for the IWF, said that the image was rated "1 on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is the least offensive". She described the picture as "erotic posing with no sexual activity".<ref name="gamazon"/> While the image itself has not been flagged as "illegal", IWF determined it to be a "potentially illegal indecent image of a child under the age of 18".<ref name="WDP">{{cite news|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/155156/wikipedia_censorship_sparks_free_speech_debate.html|title=Wikipedia Censorship Sparks Free Speech Debate|last=Raphael|first=JR|date=8 December 2008|work=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|publisher=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|accessdate=17 December 2008}}</ref>
The IWF said they were first notified of the Wikipedia URL on 4 December 2008. This followed the May 2008 reporting of the cover image on Wikipedia by U.S.-based social conservative site ''[[WorldNetDaily]]'' to the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]. A subsequent investigation by the FBI concluded that the artwork did not violate any US laws.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/dec/09/scorpions-virgin-killer-censorship|title=A nasty sting in the censors' tail|last=Fisher|first=Frank|publisher=The Guardian|date=9 December 2008|accessdate=2 May 2017}}</ref> ''EContent'' magazine subsequently reported that the discussion page associated with the article declared "Prior discussion has determined by broad consensus that the ''Virgin Killer'' cover will not be removed", and asserted that Wikipedia contributors "favour inclusion in all but the most extreme cases".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.econtentmag.com/Articles/News/News-Feature/Wikipedia-Weighs-Information-Against-Indecency-49659.htm|title=Wikipedia Weighs Information Against Indecency|first=Jessica|last=Dye|date=1 July 2008|work=EContent|accessdate=9 December 2008}}</ref> However, according to ''[[The Guardian]]'' because "the IWF doesn't talk to people outside of the UK they weren't able to appreciate what was going on". Internet security expert Richard Clayton explained that "We see this borderline stuff all the time; it's a no-win", before adding that the decision seems to have been based on taking the image out of context, particularly "given that you can go into [[HMV Group|HMV]] and buy a copy on the high street".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/blog/2008/dec/09/wikipedia-censorship|title=Wikipedia censor mess 'a no-win'|last=Johnson|first=Bobbie|date=9 December 2008|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=9 December 2008 }}</ref> On 9 December 2008 the IWF reversed its blacklist of the Wikipedia pages on the basis of the "contextual issues involved in this specific case and, in light of the length of time the image has existed and its wide availability".<ref name="IWF9"/>
== Effects on Wikipedia == {{See also|Cleanfeed (content blocking system)|Proxy server}}
[[File:VK WikipediaBlock.png|thumb|left|Users attempting to access the ''Virgin Killer'' article or image were met with pseudo-[[404 error]]s or other messages.]]
The blacklisting of ''Virgin Killer'' also caused other inadvertent issues for Wikipedia users in the United Kingdom. Usually most Internet users have a unique [[IP address]] visible to websites. However, as a result of ISPs using the IWF blacklist implemented through [[Cleanfeed (content blocking system)|Cleanfeed]] technology, traffic to Wikipedia via those affected ISPs was then routed through a small number of [[proxy server]]s.<ref name="pcworld">{{cite web |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/155112/wikipedia_article_censored_in_uk_for_the_first_time.html|title=Wikipedia Article Censored in UK for the First Time|last=Kirk|first=Jeremy|date=8 December 2008|work=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|accessdate=8 December 2008}}</ref> This caused problems for users of the site. Since Wikipedia allows users to anonymously edit its encyclopaedia articles, these individuals are identified only through their IP addresses, which are used to selectively block users who vandalise the site or otherwise break its rules. The proxy filtering makes it impossible to uniquely distinguish users, and to prevent vandalism Wikipedia "instituted a blanket ban on anonymous edits from the six ISPs, which account for 95% of British residential internet users".<ref name="smh">{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/web/wikipedia-added-to-child-pornography-blacklist/2008/12/08/1228584723764.html |title=Wikipedia added to child pornography blacklist |last=Moses |first=Asher |date=8 December 2008 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=8 December 2008}}</ref> This had the immediate effect of requiring nearly all registered users in the UK to request the lifting of {{srlink|Wikipedia:Autoblock|IP Autoblocks}} on their accounts before they could edit again, and the de facto permanent effect of barring any contribution from people without {{srlink|Wikipedia:Why create an account?|user accounts on the site}}, who contribute merely under an IP address and not a user name.
The [[MediaWiki]] software that Wikipedia runs on can interpret [[X-Forwarded-For]] (XFF) headers, allowing Wikipedia to identify a user's main IP address rather than the proxy IP address, allowing the ability to block proxy users individually by their client's IP rather than the proxy server IP (avoiding the need to block the whole proxy due to the actions of a single user).<ref name="pcworld"/> However, none of the ISPs subscribing to this system pass XFF information to Wikipedia, having the impact of reversing the normal method of identification and blocking on Wikipedia.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/155112/wikipedia_article_censored_in_uk_for_the_first_time.html |title=Wikipedia Article Censored in UK for the First Time |last=Kirk|first=Jeremy |work=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] |accessdate=10 December 2008}}</ref> IP addresses assumed to be assigned to an individual person or organisation were assigned instead to millions of people and thousands of registered editors.<ref name="ORG">{{cite web |url=http://www.openrightsgroup.org/2008/12/08/iwf-censors-wikipedia-chaos-ensues/ |title=IWF censors Wikipedia, chaos ensues |last=Hogge|first=Becky |publisher=[[Open Rights Group]] |accessdate=10 December 2008}}</ref> Wikipedia servers saw them all as the IP of the proxy rather than each as the IP of their own machine.
Due to erroneous use of [[Border Gateway Protocol]] (BGP) and other routing technology to redirect the connections to the filtering proxies, users of some networks were temporarily prevented from accessing or editing any content hosted by Wikimedia, a problem reminiscent of [[Blocking of YouTube#Pakistan|Pakistan's accidental blocking]] of YouTube for much of the world instead of only their own citizens.<ref name=CNN-pak-block>{{cite web|url=http://bookchin.net/trip-research/youtube/pakistanBlocksYoutube.html |title=Pakistan move knocked out YouTube |work=CNN.com (Asia) |publisher=Natalie Bookchin (bookchin.net) |date=25 February 2008 |accessdate=28 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014220714/http://bookchin.net/trip-research/youtube/pakistanBlocksYoutube.html |archivedate=14 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Responses ==
On 7 December 2008, the [[Wikimedia Foundation]], a non-profit organisation which supports Wikipedia, issued a press release about the blacklisting of their sites by the IWF stating that they had "no reason to believe the article, or the image contained in the article, has been held to be illegal in any jurisdiction anywhere in the world", and noting that not just the image but the article itself had been blocked.<ref name="wikimediapr">{{cite press release|url=https://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Press_releases/Censorship_of_WP_in_the_UK_Dec_2008|title=Censorship of WP in the UK December 2008|publisher=[[Wikimedia Foundation]]|date=7 December 2008|last=|accessdate=8 December 2008}}</ref>
On 9 December 2008, [[Jimmy Wales]], co-founder of Wikipedia, who holds the [[Founder's seat|"community founder seat"]] on the [[Wikimedia Foundation Board of Trustees]], told the UK's [[Channel 4 News]] that he had briefly considered legal action.<ref name="c4news">{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/science_technology/wikipedia%20may%20challenge%20iwf%20ban/2877057|title=Wikipedia 'may challenge' IWF ban|publisher=[[Channel 4 News]]|location=London, UK|date=9 December 2008|first=Benjamin|last=Cohen|accessdate=9 December 2008}}</ref><ref name="sentrynews">{{cite web|url=http://www.sentryparentalcontrols.co.uk/news/wikipedia-may-challenge-iwf-ban.aspx |title=Wikipedia 'may challenge' IWF ban |publisher=[[Sentry Parental Controls]] |location=[[Manchester]], UK |date=9 December 2008 |first=Alex |last=Moss |accessdate=9 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211064605/http://www.sentryparentalcontrols.co.uk/news/wikipedia-may-challenge-iwf-ban.aspx |archivedate=11 December 2008 }}</ref><ref name="telegraphuk">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/scienceandtechnology/technology/3689527/Wikipedia-founder-considers-legal-action-over-ban-on-pornographic-album-cover.html|title=Wikipedia founder considers legal action over ban on 'pornographic' album cover|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK|date=9 December 2008|first=Nicole|last=Martin|accessdate=10 December 2008}}</ref> After the block had been removed, [[Mike Godwin]], general counsel for the Wikimedia Foundation, stated "there is still plenty to be troubled by in the operations of the Internet Watch Foundation and its blacklist".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.webmink.net/2008/12/why-iwfs-wikipedia-reversal-is-not.htm|title=Why IWF's Wikipedia Reversal Is Not Enough|accessdate=14 December 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217093048/http://www.webmink.net/2008/12/why-iwfs-wikipedia-reversal-is-not.htm|archivedate=17 December 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 9 December 2008, the IWF rescinded the block,<ref name="ipp">{{cite web|url=http://security.itproportal.com/articles/2008/12/10/iwf-backtracks-wikipedia-controversial-image-ban/ |title=IWF Backtracks On Wikipedia Controversial Image Ban |accessdate=10 December 2008 |date=10 December 2008 |publisher=ITProPortal.com |page=2 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214044320/http://security.itproportal.com/articles/2008/12/10/iwf-backtracks-wikipedia-controversial-image-ban/ |archivedate=14 December 2008 }}</ref><ref name="tb">{{cite web| url = http://www.thinkbroadband.com/news/3819-iwf-appeals-procedure-reverses-wikipedia-block.html| title = IWF appeals procedure reverses Wikipedia block|accessdate=10 December 2008|date=10 December 2008|last=Ferguson|first=Andrew|publisher=thinkbroadband}}</ref><ref name="c42">{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/science_technology/iwf+lifts+wikipedia+ban/2878257|title=IWF lifts Wikipedia ban|date=9 December 2008|work=[[Channel 4 News]]|publisher=[[Channel 4 News]]|accessdate=10 December 2008}}</ref><ref name="telecompaper">{{cite web| url = http://www.telecompaper.com/news/article.aspx?cid=649377|title=IWF removes Wikipedia website from watch list|accessdate=10 December 2008|date=10 December 2008|publisher=Telecompaper}}</ref><ref name="telegraaf">{{cite web| url = http://www.telegraaf.nl/digitaal/2764909/__Wikipedia-ban_ongedaan_gemaakt__.html| title = Wikipedia-ban ongedaan gemaakt|accessdate=10 December 2008|date=10 December 2008|publisher=[[De Telegraaf]]|language = Dutch}}</ref> issuing the following statement:<ref name="IWF9" />
{{quote|[...] the image in question is potentially in breach of the Protection of Children Act 1978. However, the IWF Board has today (9 December 2008) considered these findings and the contextual issues involved in this specific case and, in light of the length of time the image has existed and its wide availability, the decision has been taken to remove this webpage from our list.}}
== Aftermath ==
The incident was commented in some countries implementing or considering to implement Internet filtering or censorship plans. In Australia, [[Electronic Frontiers Australia]] vice-chairman Colin Jacobs said that "[the] incident in Britain, in which virtually the entire country was unable to edit Wikipedia because the country's Internet Watch Foundation had blacklisted a single image on the site, illustrated the pitfalls of mandatory ISP filtering".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/home/technology/labor-plan-to-censor-internet-in-shreds/2008/12/09/1228584820006.html?page=2|title=Labor plan to censor internet in shreds|last=Moses|first=Asher|date=9 December 2008|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=9 December 2008}}</ref><ref name="stuff">{{cite web| url = http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/4788463a28.html| title = Aussie plan to censor Web in shreds|accessdate =10 December 2008|date=10 December 2008|last = Moses|first = Asher| publisher=stuff.co.nz}}</ref> ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' has commented that "Ironically, the banning of the image has only made it visible to more people as news sites publicise the issue and the image spreads across sites other than Wikipedia." an example of the [[Streisand effect]].<ref name="smh"/>
At the time of the incident [[Amazon.com|Amazon US]] were also displaying the image on their site and the IWF stated that it "might yet add Amazon US to its list of 'blocked' sites for hosting the picture";<ref name="gamazon"/> however, Amazon subsequently took the decision to remove the image from their site.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2008/dec/09/wikipedia-censorship-iwf-reconsiders|title=Internet Watch Foundation reconsiders Wikipedia censorship|last=Arthur|first=Charles|date=9 December 2008|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=10 December 2008 }}: "However Amazon US no longer risks being blocked under IWF's rulings. The image, as an album cover, had been on its site earlier this week, but has now been removed, apparently on the site's own initiative."</ref> In an impact study preparing a bill dealing with [[cybercrime]], the [[Cabinet of France]] listed the ''Virgin Killer'' block as an example of indiscriminate filtering.<ref>{{cite web |title=Appendix to the LOPPSI bill |url=http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/13/pdf/projets/pl1697.pdf |publisher=[[National Assembly (France)|Assemblée nationale]] |format=PDF |page= 12 |date=27 May 2009 |quote=''Le récent blocage, au mois de décembre 2008, en Angleterre du site Wikipédia par le filtre de l’Internet Watch Foundation du fait de la présence d’une photo de l’album « virgin killer » du groupe rock Scorpion a été commenté comme un exemple des limites d’un filtre qui ne discrimine pas.'' The recent blocking of Wikipedia in England in December 2008 by a filter from the Internet Watch Foundation, because of a photo from the album "virgin killer" by the rock band Scorpions, has been given as an example of the effect of an indiscriminate filter.}}</ref>
The [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] criticised the IWF's reasoning:<ref>[https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2008/12/internet-censors-must-be-accountable-things-they-b Internet Censors Must Be Accountable For The Things They Break,], Peter Eckersley, 9 December 2008</ref>
{{quote|We agree with their decision [to reverse the ban], but they have the wrong reasoning [for the reversal]: they had no business censoring that article in the first place — the community of Wikipedia editors is if anything the more legitimate, reliable and grown-up adjudicator of which images are appropriate subject matter for an encyclopaedia.}}
The IWF continues to assert that the image is indeed child porn, and asserts that the image would be blocked if it were on a British server.<ref name="Doctorow">Doctorow, Cory. [https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2008/dec/16/cory-doctorow-wikipedia “How to make child-porn blocks safe for the internet”], ''The Guardian'' (16 December 2008).</ref>

{{for|the actor|Jayson Blair (actor)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Jayson Blair |birth_name = Jayson Thomas Blair |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|03|23}} |birth_place = [[Columbia, Maryland|Columbia]], [[Maryland]], United States |death_date = |death_place = |alma_mater = [[University of Maryland, College Park]] |occupation = {{hlist |Writer |journalist |life coach}} }} '''Jayson Thomas Blair''' (born March 23, 1976) is a former American journalist who worked for ''[[The New York Times]]''. He resigned from the newspaper in May 2003 in the wake of the discovery of [[plagiarism]] and fabrication in his stories. Blair published a memoir of this period, entitled ''Burning Down My Master's House'' (2004), recounting his career, a diagnosis of [[bipolar disorder]] after his resignation, and his view of race relations at the newspaper. He later established a support group for people with bipolar disorder. ==Background== Blair was born in [[Columbia, Maryland]], the son of a federal executive and a schoolteacher. While attending the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], he was a student journalist. For 1996–1997, he was selected as the second African-American editor-in-chief of its student newspaper, ''[[The Diamondback]]''. According to a 2004 article by the ''Baltimore Sun'', some of his fellow students opposed his selection. After a summer interning at ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 1998, Blair was offered an extended internship there. He declined in order to complete more coursework for graduation. But he returned to the ''Times'' in June 1999, with a year of coursework left to complete.{{cite news |title=Times Reporter Who Resigned Leaves Long Trail of Deception |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 11, 2003 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/11/national/11PAPE.html?ex=1367985600&en=d6f511319c259463&ei=5007&partner=USERLAND}} That November, he was classified as an "intermediate reporter". He was later promoted to a full reporter and then to editor. ==Plagiarism and fabrication scandal== On April 28, 2003, Blair received a call from ''Times'' national editor [[Jim Roberts (New York Times journalist)|James Roberts]] asking him about similarities between a story he had written two days earlier{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A06E7DE153DF935A15757C0A9659C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=AFTEREFFECTS: THE MISSING; Family Waits, Now Alone, for a Missing Soldier | first=Jayson | last=Blair | date=April 26, 2003 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} and one published April 18 by ''[[San Antonio Express-News]]'' reporter [[Macarena Hernandez]].{{cite web | title = MySA.com: Iraq: After the War | url = http://www.mysanantonio.com/specials/battlefield/stories/MYSA982379.xml.d7d1e3.html | accessdate = February 24, 2008 | year = 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083427/http://www.mysanantonio.com/specials/battlefield/stories/MYSA982379.xml.d7d1e3.html | archivedate = September 29, 2007 | df = mdy-all }} The senior editor of the ''Express-News'' had contacted the ''Times'' about the similarities between Blair's article in the ''Times'' and Hernandez's article in his paper. The resulting inquiry led to the discovery of fabrication and plagiarism in a number of articles written by Blair.{{cite journal |last= Rosen |first= Jill |title= All about the retrospect: Jayson Blair charmed and dazzled the right people on his rapid rise from cocky college student to ''New York Times'' national reporter. But he left plenty of clues about the serious problems that lay beneath the surface |journal= ''[[American Journalism Review]]'' |location= College Park |publisher= University of Maryland |volume= 25 |issue= 5 |date= June–July 2003 |page= 32+ }} Some fabrications include Blair's claims to have traveled to the city mentioned in the [[dateline]], when in fact he did not. Suspect articles include the following: *In the October 30, 2002 piece "US Sniper Case Seen as a Barrier to a Confession", Blair wrote that a dispute between police authorities had ruined the interrogation of [[Beltway sniper attacks|Beltway sniper]] suspect [[John Muhammad]] and that Muhammad was about to confess, quoting unnamed officials.{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9406E3DC133FF933A05753C1A9649C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=Retracing A Trail: The Investigation; U.S. Sniper Case Seen As A Barrier To A Confession | first=Jayson | last=Blair | date=October 30, 2002 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} This was swiftly denied by everyone involved. Blair also named certain lawyers, who were not present, as having witnessed the interrogation.{{cite news|title=CORRECTING THE RECORD; Witnesses and Documents Unveil Deceptions In a Reporter's Work|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/11/us/correcting-record-witnesses-documents-unveil-deceptions-reporter-s-work.html|accessdate=17 February 2018|work=New York Times|date=May 11, 2003}} *In the February 10, 2003 piece "Peace and Answers Eluding Victims of the Sniper Attacks", Blair claimed to be in Washington.{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9906E7DD113BF933A25751C0A9659C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=Peace and Answers Eluding Victims of the Sniper Attacks |first=Jayson | last=Blair | date=February 10, 2003 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} He allegedly plagiarized quotations from a ''Washington Post'' story and fabricated quotations from a person he had never interviewed. Blair ascribed a wide range of attributes to a man featured in the article, almost all of which the man in question denied. Blair also published information that he had promised was to be [[Journalism sourcing#Using confidential information|off the record]]. *In the March 3, 2003 piece "Making Sniper Suspect Talk Puts Detective in Spotlight", Blair claimed to be in [[Fairfax, Virginia]].{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9900E3DD1F3CF930A35750C0A9659C8B63%20 | work=The New York Times |title=Making Sniper Suspect Talk Puts Detective in Spotlight | first=Jayson | last=Blair | date=March 3, 2003 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} He described a videotape of [[Lee Malvo]], the younger defendant in the case, being questioned by police and quoted officials' review of the tape. No such tape existed. Blair also claimed a detective noticed blood on a man's jeans leading to a confession, which had not occurred. *In the March 27, 2003 piece "Relatives of Missing Soldiers Dread Hearing Worse News", Blair claimed to be in [[West Virginia]].{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C03E3DE1E30F934A15750C0A9659C8B63 | work=The New York Times| title=A NATION AT WAR: MILITARY FAMILIES; Relatives of Missing Soldiers Dread Hearing Worse News | first=Jayson | last=Blair | date=March 27, 2003 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} He allegedly plagiarized quotations from an Associated Press article. He claimed to have spoken to the father of [[Jessica Lynch]], who had no recollection of meeting Blair; said "tobacco fields and cattle pastures" were visible from Lynch's parents' house when they were not; erroneously stated that Lynch's brother was in the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]]; misspelled Lynch's mother's name; and fabricated a dream that he claimed she had had. *In the April 3, 2003 piece "Rescue in Iraq and a 'Big Stir' in West Virginia", Blair claimed to have covered the Lynch story from her hometown of [[Palestine, Wirt County, West Virginia|Palestine, West Virginia]].{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9506E6D61F39F930A35757C0A9659C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=A NATION AT WAR: THE HOMETOWN; Rescue in Iraq and a 'Big Stir' in West Virginia | first1=Douglas | last1=Jehl | first2=Jayson | last2=Blair | date=April 3, 2003 |accessdate=May 6, 2010}} Blair never traveled to Palestine, and his entire contribution to the story consisted of rearranged details from [[Associated Press]] stories. *In the April 7, 2003 piece "For One Pastor, the War Hits Home", Blair wrote of a church service in [[Cleveland]] and an interview with the minister.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE1DB1338F934A35757C0A9659C8B63 | work=The New York Times | title=A NATION AT WAR: THE FAMILIES; For One Pastor, the War Hits Home | first=Jayson | last=Blair | date=April 7, 2003 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} Blair never went to Cleveland; he spoke to the minister by telephone, and copied portions of the article from an earlier ''[[Washington Post]]'' article. He also plagiarized quotations from ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' and ''[[New York Daily News]]''. He fabricated a detail about the minister keeping a picture of his son inside his Bible and got the name of the church wrong. *In the April 19, 2003 piece "In Military Wards, Questions and Fears from the Wounded", Blair described interviewing four injured soldiers in a naval hospital.{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9407EFDD153AF93AA25757C0A9659C8B63 |work=The New York Times | title=A NATION AT WAR: VETERANS; In Military Wards, Questions and Fears From the Wounded | first=Jayson | last=Blair| date=April 19, 2003 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} He had never gone to the hospital and had spoken to only one soldier by telephone, to whom he later attributed made-up quotes. Blair wrote that the soldier "will most likely limp the rest of his life and need to use a cane", which was untrue. He said another soldier had lost his right leg when it had been amputated below the knee. He described two soldiers as being in the hospital at the same time, but they were admitted five days apart. After internal investigations, ''The New York Times'' reported on Blair's [[journalism ethics and standards|journalistic misdeeds]] in an "unprecedented" 7,239-word front-page story on May 11, 2003, headlined "Times Reporter Who Resigned Leaves Long Trail of Deception." The story called the affair "a low point in the 152-year history of the newspaper." On the [[NPR]] radio show ''[[Talk of the Nation]]'', Blair explained that his fabrications started with what he thought was a relatively innocent infraction: using a quote from a press conference which he had missed. He described a gradual process whereby his ethical violations became worse, and contended that his main motivation was a fear of not living up to the expectations that he and others had for his career.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} After the scandal broke, some 30 former staffers of ''The Diamondback'', who had worked with Blair when he was editor-in-chief at the university newspaper, signed a 2003 letter alleging that Blair had made four serious errors as a reporter and editor while at the University of Maryland. They said these and his work habits brought his integrity into question. The letter-signers alleged that questions raised by some of these staffers at the time were ignored by Maryland Media, Inc. (MMI), the board that owned the paper.{{cite news |title=The Making of Jayson Blair |first=David |last=Folkenflik |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/topic/bal-as.blair23,0,5336838.story |work=[[The Baltimore Sun|Baltimore Sun]] |date=February 29, 2004}}{{cite web |title=Former Blair co-workers claim warnings ignored |author=Jason Flanagan |work=[[The Diamondback]] |publisher=[[UWIRE]].com |url=http://www.uwire.com/content/topnews061303002.html |accessdate = June 13, 2003 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060115191349/http://www.uwire.com/content/topnews061303002.html |archivedate = January 15, 2006}} ==Aftermath== The investigation, known as the Siegal committee, found heated debate among the staff over [[affirmative action]] hiring, as Blair is African American. Jonathan Landman, Blair's editor, told the Siegal committee he felt that Blair's being [[Black people|black]] played a large part in the younger man's initial promotion in 2001 to full-time staffer. "I think [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]] was the decisive factor in his promotion," he said. "I thought then and I think now that it was the wrong decision."{{cite web|title=Jayson Blair: A Case Study of What Went Wrong at The New York Times |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/media/media_ethics/casestudy_blair.php |accessdate=February 24, 2008 |year=2008 |work=PBS |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819012801/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/media/media_ethics/casestudy_blair.php |archivedate=August 19, 2008 }} Others disagreed. Five days later, ''New York Times'' op-ed columnist [[Bob Herbert]], an African American, asserted in his column that race had nothing to do with the Blair case:
"Listen up: the race issue in this case is as bogus as some of Jayson Blair's reporting." Herbert said, "[F]olks who delight in attacking anything black, or anything designed to help blacks, have pounced on the Blair story as evidence that there is something inherently wrong with ''The New York Times''{{'}}s effort to diversify its newsroom, and beyond that, with the very idea of a commitment to diversity or affirmative action anywhere. And while these agitators won't admit it, the nasty subtext to their attack is that there is something inherently wrong with blacks."{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DE0DF133EF93AA25756C0A9659C8B63|title=Truth, Lies and Subtext|first=Bob|last=Herbert|work=The New York Times|date=May 19, 2003}}
Two senior editors, Executive Editor [[Howell Raines]] and Managing Editor [[Gerald M. Boyd|Gerald Boyd]], resigned after losing newsroom support in the aftermath of the scandal. After resigning from ''The New York Times'', Blair struggled with severe depression and, according to his memoir, entered a hospital for treatment. He was diagnosed with [[bipolar disorder]] for the first time. He has acknowledged that he had been self-medicating when he was dealing with substance abuse of alcohol and cocaine in earlier years.[https://web.archive.org/web/20050618081724/http://poynter.org/forum/?id=letters Letter by Jayson Blair: "Blair: Outsourcing EAP is a mistake"], ''Poynter Online'', 15 June 2005 ==Later career== Blair later returned to college to complete his postponed degree. At one time he said he considered going into [[politics]].{{cite web |url=http://www.timescommunity.com/site/tab5.cfm?newsid=14666157&BRD=2553&PAG=461&dept_id=506096&rfi=6 |title=Jayson Blair searches for new life, reflects ...|work=[[Times Community Newspapers|Fairfax County Times]] |author=Perrone, Matthew |date=June 9, 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201111446/http://www.timescommunity.com/site/tab5.cfm?newsid=14666157&BRD=2553&PAG=461&dept_id=506096&rfi=6 |archivedate=December 1, 2006}} The year after he left the ''Times'', Blair wrote a memoir, ''[[Burning Down My Master's House]]'', published by New Millennium Books in 2004. Its initial print run was 250,000 copies; some 1,400 were sold in its first nine days.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/mar/20/entertainment/et-quick20.4 | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Ex-journalists' books not selling | date=March 20, 2004}} The Associated Press reported that the potential audience for his book may have gained enough information from the ''New York Times'' coverage of the reporting scandal. Although most reviews were critical, sales of the book increased after Blair was interviewed by King and Fox News Channel host [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]].[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/books/news/2004-03-18-blair-book_x.htm Associated Press, "Few buyers for books by disgraced journalists Jayson Blair and Stephen Glass"], ''USA Today'', 18 March 2004 In his book Blair revealed extended substance abuse, which he had ended before he resigned from the newspaper, and a struggle with [[bipolar disorder]], which was diagnosed and first treated after he resigned. He also discussed journalistic practices at the ''Times'', and his view of race relations and disagreements among senior editors at the newspaper. In 2006 Blair was running a support group for people with [[bipolar disorder]], for which he has received continuing treatment.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/jayson-blair-the-man-who-fooled-america-6101932.html|title=Jayson Blair: The man who fooled America|last=Caesar|first=Ed|date=May 3, 2006|accessdate=July 2, 2017|publisher=The Independent}} ==In popular culture== * ''Choke Point'', the play written by [[Colm Byrne]] and produced in 2007 in Los Angeles by Che'rae Adams, is based on Blair's downfall.{{cite journal| url=https://archive.org/stream/chokePointByColmByrne-EngrossingIntelligent-3weeksMagazine/ThreeWeeks#page/n0/mode/2up | work=Three Weeks Magazine | title=Choke Point Theatre Review|author= Colm Byrne | date=September 15, 2007}} *A play about Blair, ''[[CQ/CX]]'', written by Gabe McKinley, was produced by the [[Atlantic Theater Company]] in 2012.{{cite news| url=http://theater.nytimes.com/2012/02/16/theater/reviews/cq-cx-by-gabe-mckinley-at-peter-norton-space.html | work=New York Times | first=Frank | last=Rizzo | title='CQ/CX' by Gabe McKinley at Peter Norton Space | date=February 15, 2012}} McKinley knew Blair personally, having worked at the ''Times'' during the period Blair was there.{{cite news| url= http://articles.latimes.com/2012/feb/24/entertainment/la-et-jayson-blair-20120224| work=Los Angeles Times | first=Steven | last=Zeitchik | title=Ripped from the fake headlines | date=February 24, 2012|accessdate = October 15, 2017}} * The television series ''[[Law & Order]]'' used the Blair story as the inspiration for Episode 14.02: "Bounty".{{cite web|url=http://www.filmjerk.com/news/article.php?id_new=299|last=Faile|first=Chris|title="Law & Order" Takes on The New York Times Scandal|work=Filmjerk.com|date=July 31, 2003|accessdate=October 15, 2017}} * In the television series ''[[Law & Order: Criminal Intent]]'', the Blair story inspired an episode about a young journalist in the third season episode "Pravda" (3.5).{{cite web|url=http://www.filmjerk.com/news/article.php?id_new=299|last=Faile|first=Chris|title="Law & Order" Franchise to Give Jayson Blair/New York Times Saga One More|work=Filmjerk.com|date=September 22, 2003|accessdate=October 15, 2017}} * Season 5 of the HBO series ''[[The Wire]]'' dealt with the subject of journalist fabrication, as well as the decline of print journalism. It mentions Jayson Blair in the last episode. ''The Wire'' creator [[David Simon]] had been a ''[[Baltimore Sun]]'' journalist and worked on ''[[The Diamondback]]'', the student newspaper at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], where Blair was editor. * A 2003 series of ''[[Pearls Before Swine (comics)|Pearls Before Swine]]'' comic strips portray Rat writing fraudulent ''New York Times'' stories on former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein.[https://www.amazon.com/Lions-Tigers-Crocs-Oh-My/product-reviews/0740761552 Amazon.com] * A scene in ''[[Gilmore Girls]]'' episode "The Reigning Lorelai" (4.16) shows Rory's editor, Doyle, becoming frustrated with the way ''Yale Daily News'' staffers act in the newsroom, calling it "the breeding ground for the next Jayson Blair." *A documentary film featuring Jayson Blair was made by director/producer Samantha Grant. ''[[A Fragile Trust: Plagiarism, Power, and Jayson Blair at The New York Times]]'' premiered at the [[Sheffield Doc/Fest|Sheffield International Documentary Film Festival]] on June 14, 2013.{{cite web|title=Synopsis|url=http://www.afragiletrust.com/the-film/synopsis/#.U4dQtCjjLXA|work=A Fragile Trust website|publisher=A Fragile Trust|accessdate=May 29, 2014}} * An episode of the television series ''[[The Simpsons]]'' based a joke on the Blair story in Episode 15.22: "Fraudcast News". Milhouse tells Lisa he's sorry but a story he "filed from Baghdad was all made up, (he) was actually in Basrah."[http://www.lardlad.com/assets/quotes/season15/FABF18.shtml] * During the ''[[White House Correspondents' Dinner]]'' 2008, in response to the ''[[New York Times]]'' declining to attend that year because they felt the event undercut the credibility of the press,[https://www.poynter.org/news/why-nyt-doesnt-attend-white-house-correspondents-association-dinner][https://www.bustle.com/p/who-is-boycotting-the-white-house-correspondents-dinner-lots-of-people-it-seems-53725] [[Craig Ferguson]] remarked "I thought Jayson Blair and ''[[Judith Miller]]'' took care of that". ==See also== * [[Brian Williams]] * [[Jack Kelley (journalist)|Jack Kelley]] * [[Janet Cooke]] * [[Johann Hari]] * [[Journalism scandals]] * [[Stephen Glass]] ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|last=Blair|first=Jayson|title=Burning Down My Masters' House: My Life at the New York Times|publisher=New Millennium Press|year=2004|isbn=1-932407-26-X}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2003/05/11/ny-times-uncovers-dozens-of-faked-stories-by-reporter/cf38d271-f799-44e4-91a1-b51dec1329af/ "N.Y. Times Uncovers Dozens of Faked Stories by Reporter"], ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]''. May 11, 2003. * Kugler, Sara. [http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/new-york-times-executives-howell-raines-gerald-boyd-resign/article_a0025523-591d-52ca-81a0-b0ad62c19816.html "New York Times executives Howell Raines, Gerald Boyd resign"], ''[[Associated Press]]''. June 5, 2003. * "[https://www.bphope.com/Item.aspx/236/first-person-jayson-blair- Making a Turnaround,"] ''bp Magazine'' (bphope.com). Spring 2005. Retrieved 2010-12-06. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060113083458/http://www.timescommunity.com/site/tab5.cfm?newsid=14666157&BRD=2553&PAG=461&dept_id=506096&rfi=6 "Jayson Blair searches for new life, reflects on legacy."] ''[[Times Community Newspapers|Fairfax County Times]]''. June 9, 2005. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050618081724/http://poynter.org/forum/?id=letters "Blair: Outsourcing EAP [NYT's employee assistance program] is a mistake"], ''[[Jim Romenesko|Romenesko]] Media News'' ([[Poynter Institute]]). June 15, 2005. ==External links== *[http://www.journalism.org/search/node/Jayson+Blair Global coverage of articles on the story] at ''[[Project for Excellence in Journalism|Journalism.org]]'' *[http://www.mediabistro.com/articles/cache/a1303.asp Q&A: Jayson Blair] via mediabistro * {{C-SPAN|Jayson Blair}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blair, Jayson}} [[Category:American newspaper reporters and correspondents]] [[Category:Journalistic hoaxes]] [[Category:African-American writers]] [[Category:American writers]] [[Category:Writers from New York (state)]] [[Category:Writers from Maryland]] [[Category:University of Maryland, College Park alumni]] [[Category:People from Columbia, Maryland]] [[Category:People with bipolar disorder]] [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People involved in plagiarism controversies]] [[Category:Hoaxes in the United States]] [[Category:The New York Times writers]]
