'''Missing and murdered Indigenous women''' ('''MMIW''') is an issue affecting [[Indigenous peoples in Canada|Indigenous]] people in [[Canada]] and the [[United States]], including the [[First Nations]], [[Inuit]], [[Métis]] and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] communities.<ref name=Heitcamp>{{cite web|title=Missing & Murdered Indigenous Women: Resources & Information|url=https://www.heitkamp.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?p=missing-murdered-indigenous |website=[[Heidi Heitkamp|Heidi Heitkamp - United States Senator for North Dakota]]|accessdate=31 Oct 2017 |quote=In 2016, North Dakota alone had 125 cases of missing Native women reported to the National Crime Information Center (NCIC), compared to 5,712 total Native women cases reported in the United States. However, the actual number is likely much higher, as cases of missing Native women are often under-reported and the data has never been officially collected.}}</ref> It has been described as a Canadian national crisis.<ref name=Krishnan>{{cite web|last=Krishnan |first=Manisha |title=Here's What the Missing And Murdered Indigenous Women Inquiry is Missing|url=https://www.vice.com/en_ca/article/bn3b98/heres-what-the-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-inquiry-is-missing |website=[[Vice News]]|date= 3 Aug 2016|accessdate=25 Oct 2017 |quote=After years of debate and inaction, the Canadian government has finally launched an inquiry into the national crisis of missing and murdered Indigenous women.}}</ref><ref name=WalkerCrisis>{{cite web|last=Walker |first=Connie |title=Missing, murdered aboriginal women crisis demands a look at root causes|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/indigenous/missing-murdered-aboriginal-women-crisis-demands-a-look-at-root-causes-1.3027023 |website=[[CBC News]]|date= 10 April 2016|accessdate=25 Oct 2017 }}</ref><ref name=Bailey&Shayah>{{cite journal |last1=Bailey |first1=Jane |last2=Shayan |first2=Sara |date=2016 |title=Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women Crisis: Technological Dimensions |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/629379 |journal=Canadian Journal of Women and the Law |volume=28 |issue=2 |pages=321–341 |doi= |access-date=25 Oct 2017}}</ref> Canadian indigenous women are disproportionately affected by all forms of violence,<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1449240606362/1449240634871|title=Background on the inquiry|first=Government of Canada; Indigenous and Northern Affairs|last=Canada|website=www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca|access-date=2017-10-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170913072151/https://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1449240606362/1449240634871|archive-date=2017-09-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and are significantly over-represented among female Canadian homicide victims.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/1335731/live-rcmp-news-conference-about-murdered-missing-aboriginal-women/|title=Disproportionate number of women killed in Canada aboriginal: RCMP|publisher=}}</ref> They are also far more likely than other women to go missing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://beta.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/missing-murdered-indigenous-women-inquiry-to-ask-for-more-time/article36163093/|title=Missing, murdered Indigenous women inquiry to ask for more time|date=4 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
The exact number of Indigenous women and girls who have gone missing or have been murdered in Canada since the 1970s is uncertain, with estimates ranging from approximately 1,000 to nearly 4,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/politics/mmiw-4000-hajdu-1.3450237|title=Minister's comment highlights confusion over missing, murdered women numbers|publisher=CBC}}</ref> In response to activists, the Canadian government funded data collection on missing and murdered women, ending in 2010; the Native Women's Association of Canada has documented 582 cases since the 1960s, with 39% occurring after 2000. But advocacy groups say that many more women have been missing, with the highest number of cases in British Columbia. Some notable cases have included 19 women killed in the [[Highway of Tears murders]], and up to 49 women, many of whom were indigenous, murdered by [[Robert Pickton]].
Responding to repeated calls of Indigenous groups, other activists, and [[non-governmental organization]]s, the Government of Canada under Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] established the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in September 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmiwg-ffada.ca/en/about-us/|title=About Us — National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls|website=National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls|access-date=2017-10-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180423153818/http://www.mmiwg-ffada.ca/en/about-us|archive-date=2018-04-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
== Background == As a group that has been "socially, economically, and politically marginalized",<ref name="Harper, Anita 2006">Harper, Anita (Winter 2006). "Is Canada Peaceful and Safe for Aboriginal Women?". ''Canadian Woman Studies''. '''25''': 33–38</ref> Indigenous women have been frequent targets for hatred and violence.<ref>Harper, Anita (Winter 2006).</ref> Underlying factors such as poverty and homelessness contribute to their victimization, as do historical factors such as racism, sexism, and the legacy of colonialism. The trauma caused by abuses under Canada's [[Canadian Indian residential school system|residential school system]] also likely plays a role.<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/07/06/the-vanishing-of-canadas-first-nations-women-harper-trudeau-violence-highway-of-tears-indigenous/|title=The Vanishing of Canada's First Nations Women|publisher=}}</ref> Indigenous women are between 3 and 3.5 times more likely to be victims of violent crime than other women,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mmiwg-ffada.ca/en/background/|title=Background|last=|first=|date=|website=National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls|access-date=February 10, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/85-002-x/2011001/article/11439-eng.htm#a1|title=Violent victimization of Aboriginal women in the Canadian provinces, 2009|website=www.statcan.gc.ca}}</ref> and the violence they face is often more severe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/85-002-x/2011001/article/11439-eng.htm|title=Violent victimization of Aboriginal women in the Canadian provinces, 2009|website=www.statcan.gc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-03-07}}</ref>
==Statistics== Canada does not maintain a database for missing people, which makes it difficult to determine the rate at which Indigenous women are murdered or go missing, or to compare their data to those of other populations. In addition, various groups have collected data from different periods of time and different criteria. Available data suggests, however, that the number of missing and murdered Indigenous women is disproportionately high compared to their percentage of the total population.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fact Sheet: Missing and Murdered Aboriginal Women and Girls|url=http://www.nwac.ca/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Fact_Sheet_Missing_and_Murdered_Aboriginal_Women_and_Girls.pdf|website=Native Women's Association of Canada|accessdate=19 May 2016}}</ref>
Although Indigenous women and girls make up only 4% of the female population in Canada, they represented 16% of all female homicides in Canada between 1980 and 2012.<ref name="auto"/> A 2011 Statistics Canada report estimated that Indigenous women are seven times more likely than other women to be victims of a homicide.<ref>[http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/89-503-x/2010001/article/11442-eng.pdf Vivian O’Donnell and Susan Wallace, ''Women in Canada: A Gender based Statistical Report: First Nations, Inuit and Métis Women'' (Statistics Canada, 2011)]</ref><ref name="amnesty.ca">https://www.amnesty.ca/sites/amnesty/files/iwfa_submission_amnesty_international_february_2014_-_final.pdf</ref> According to a 2007 study by the province of Saskatchewan – the only province to have systematically reviewed its missing persons files for cases involving Indigenous women – Indigenous women were found to have made up 6% of the province's population, and 60% of the province's missing women cases.<ref name="sask">[http://www.justice.gov.sk.ca/adx/aspx/adxGetMedia.aspx?DocID=3025,104,81,1,Documents&MediaID=1615&Filename=missing-persons-final.pdf ''Saskatchewan Provincial Partnership Committee on Missing Persons, Final Report'', October 2007]</ref>
The total number of missing and murdered Indigenous women is unclear. A 2014 report by the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]], ordered by the [[Stephen Harper]] administration, stated 1,181 Indigenous women were killed or went missing across the country between 1980 and 2012.<ref name="rcmp">{{cite web|url=http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/pubs/mmaw-faapd-eng.htm|title=RCMP Report 2014|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510113547/http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/pubs/mmaw-faapd-eng.htm|archivedate=2016-05-10|df=}}</ref> With government funding, the [[Native Women's Association of Canada]] (NWAC) had documented 582 cases of missing and murdered Aboriginal women from the 1960s to 2010,<ref name="humwatch">[https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/canada0213webwcover_0.pdf ''Those Who Take Us Away''], Human Rights Watch, 2013, p. 12</ref> but they believe there are many more. Of the cases analyzed by the RCMP, 67% were murder victims, 20% were missing persons, 4% were suspicious deaths, and 9% were unknown.<ref name="rcmp"/>
In 2016 [[Patricia Hajdu]], the Canadian minister for the status of women, suggested that the total number of missing and murdered Indigenous women could be closer to 4,000. She was basing her statement on information supplied by NWAC and originally collected by the Walk 4 Justice initiative. She said that historically there had been underreporting by law enforcement of cases of murdered or missing Indigenous women.
"Gladys Radek, co-founder of Walk 4 Justice, said her group collected the names while speaking to people during a trek across Canada in 2008. They stopped collecting information in 2011." Further, "When CBC News contacted one of the activists who supplied NWAC with the information, she said "roughly 60 to 70 per cent" of the 4,000 or so people on her list were Indigenous."<ref name=Tasker/><ref name="amnesty14">[https://www.amnesty.ca/sites/amnesty/files/iwfa_submission_amnesty_international_february_2014_-_final.pdf ''VIOLENCE AGAINST INDIGENOUS WOMEN AND GIRLS IN CANADA: A SUMMARY OF AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL’S CONCERNS AND CALL TO ACTION - February 2014'']</ref><ref name=Guardian4000>{{cite web|last=Guardian Staff |first= |title=A Canadian government minister has suggested that as many as 4,000 indigenous women have gone missing or been murdered over the past three decades|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/17/missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-in-canada-could-number-4000 |website=[[The Guardian]]|date= 16 Feb 2016|accessdate=23 Oct 2017 |quote=Walk 4 Justice initiative had collected at least 4,232 names of missing or murdered indigenous women}}</ref><ref name=Tasker>{{cite web|last=Tasker |first=John Paul |title=Confusion reigns over number of missing, murdered indigenous women - RCMP said 1,017 indigenous women were killed between 1980 and 2012;, activists say it's closer to 4,000. |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/mmiw-4000-hajdu-1.3450237 |website=[[CBC News]]|date= 16 Feb 2016|accessdate=15 Oct 2017}}</ref>
[[CBC News|CBC]] in 2016 investigated accounts of unsolved cases of missing and murdered Indigenous women, creating an interactive database that now numbers more than 300 persons.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/missingandmurdered/?profileID=karina-wolfe|title=Missing and Murdered Aboriginal Women|website=www.cbc.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref> CBC investigated 34 cases in which families disagreed with authorities' determination that no foul play was involved; it found "suspicious circumstances, unexplained bruises and other factors that suggest further investigation is warranted".<ref name="unsolved">[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/unresolved-cases-of-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women-1.3651516 Holly Moore, Martha Troian, "'No foul play' found in deaths of dozens of Indigenous women, but questions remain"], CBC News, 28 Jun 2016</ref>
===Details of 2014 RCMP investigation and update=== In late 2013, the Commissioner of the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) initiated a study of reported cases of missing and murdered Indigenous women across all police jurisdictions in Canada. The 2014 report found that there were 1,181 incidents of female homicides and unresolved missing Indigenous females.<ref>{{cite web|title=Missing and Murdered Aboriginal Women: A National Operational Overview|url=http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/pubs/mmaw-faapd-eng.htm|website=Missing and Murdered Aboriginal Women: A National Operational Overview|publisher=RCMP|accessdate=19 May 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510113547/http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/pubs/mmaw-faapd-eng.htm|archivedate=10 May 2016|df=}}</ref> Of these 1,181 incidents, there were 225 unsolved cases between 1980 and 2012; 80% of all female homicides (Indigenous and non-Indigenous) are solved. RCMP statistics were updated in 2015, showing murder rates and the percentage solved (80%) to be essentially unchanged. The RCMP does not collect figures from the 300 non-RCMP police agencies in Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/en/missing-and-murdered-aboriginal-women-2015-update-national-operational-overview#exec|title=Missing and Murdered Aboriginal Women: 2015 Update to the National Operational Overview - Royal Canadian Mounted Police|first=Government of Canada, Royal Canadian Mounted|last=Police|website=www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca}}</ref>
=== Highway of Tears === {{main|Highway of Tears murdered and missing}} The term "Highway of Tears" refers to the 700-kilometer stretch of [[British Columbia Highway 16|Highway 16]] from [[Prince George, British Columbia|Prince George]] to [[Prince Rupert, British Columbia|Prince Rupert]], British Columbia, which since 1969 has been the site of the murder and disappearance of a number of mainly Indigenous women.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/society/crime-justice/cold-cases-unsolved-crimes-in-canada/bcs-infamous-highway-of-tears.html|title=BC's infamous 'Highway of Tears'|last=Lee|first=Miyoung |date=November 17, 2009|work=CBC Digital Archives|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref><ref>"[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/07/10/canada-s-highway-of-tears-why-are-women-disappearing.html Highway of Vanishing Women]", ''[[Daily Beast]]'', July 10, 2011</ref><ref name="Harper, Anita 2006"/> Government organizations and Indigenous organizations have different estimates of the number of victims along the highway, with police identifying 18 murders and disappearances, 13 of them teenagers, and other organizations placing the number as closer to 40.<ref name=HRW2013>Human Rights Watch, 2013, "Those Who Take Us Away: Abusive Policing and Failures in Protection of Indigenous Women and Girls in Northern British Columbia, Canada". https://www.hrw.org/sites/default/files/reports/canada0213webwcover_0.pdf</ref> A reason for this numerical discrepancy is that for a disappearance or murder to be included in the RCMP’s [[E-Pana]] project statistics, the RCMP requires for the crime to have happened within a mile of Highway 16, 97, or 5; their count rejects all cases that take place elsewhere along the route.<ref name=HRW2013/>
Many people hitchhike along this stretch of highway because they do not own cars and there is a lack of public transit. The Highway of Tears murders has led to initiatives by the British Columbia government to dissuade women from hitchhiking, such as billboards along the highway warning women of the potential risks.<ref>Morton, Katherine (2016). "HITCHHIKING AND MISSING AND MURDERED INDIGENOUS WOMEN: A CRITICAL DISCOURSE ANALYSIS OF BILLBOARDS ON THE HIGHWAY OF TEARS". ''Canadian Journal of Sociology''. '''41''': 299–325.</ref> Numerous documentaries have focused on the victims associated with this highway. The Canadian media often refer to the highway in coverage of missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and [[Two-spirit|Two-Spirit people]] in Canada.{{fact|date=November 2018}}
The RCMP in British Columbia launched [[Highway of Tears murdered and missing#Project E-Pana|Project E-Pana]] in 2005, in response to the Highway of Tears crisis. It initiated an investigation of 9 murdered women, launching a task force in 2006. In 2007 it added an additional 9 cases, which include cases of both murdered and missing women along Highways 16, 97 and 5. The task force consists of more than 50 investigators, and cases include those from the years 1969 to 2006.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bc.cb.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/ViewPage.action?siteNodeId=1525|title=Project E-PANA: Missing Women (photos)|publisher=Royal Canadian Mounted Police in British Columbia|language=en|access-date=November 3, 2018}}</ref>
== Canadian National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls== [[File:Justin Trudeau speech on missing and murdered indigenous women – Ottawa, October 2016.jpg|thumb|Prime Minister of Canada, [[Justin Trudeau]], giving a speech on missing and murdered Indigenous women in front of Parliament in Ottawa in October 2016.]] After the [[Canadian federal election, 2015|2015 Canadian federal election]], the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Government]] upheld their campaign promise and announced the initiation of a national inquiry on December 8, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Government of Canada: National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls|url=http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1448633299414/1448633350146|website=Government of Canada|publisher=Government of Canada|accessdate=19 May 2016}}</ref> The Canadian government had pre-inquiry meetings with a variety of people including families, front-line workers, representatives of the provinces and Indigenous organizations from December 2015 through February 2016, in order to determine how to structure the inquiry. The mandate of the inquiry and the projected length of time of the inquiry were published August 3, 2016. The estimated cost is $53.8 million. In addition, the government announced $16.17 million over four years to create family information liaison units in each province and territory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1448633299414/1448633350146|title=National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls|first=Government of Canada; Indigenous and Northern Affairs|last=Canada|website=[[Indigenous Services Canada]]}}</ref>
The inquiry was established as independent from the Government of Canada, and five commissioners were appointed to oversee the independent inquiry process: [[Marion Buller]] (chief commissioner), [[Michèle Audette]], Qajaq Robinson, Marilyn Poitras, and Brian Eyolfson.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1470141223313/1470141325236|title=About the commissioners|last=|first=|date=October 11, 2016|website=Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160806050756/http://www.aadnc-aandc.gc.ca/eng/1470141223313/1470141325236|archive-date=2016-08-06|dead-url=yes|access-date=February 10, 2017}}</ref> An interim report was expected from the Inquiry in November 2017. The initial conclusion date for the inquiry was set as December 31, 2018; however, in May 2017 the Chief Commissioner of the inquiry said the inquiry might seek an extension from the federal government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/mmiwg-media-avail-criticism-1.4124463|title=MMIWG chief commissioner still has 'hope' despite rocky start|last=Tasker|first=John Paul|date=May 19, 2017|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en}}</ref>
After the first public hearing in April 2017, complaints by observers started to arise about the inquiry's terms of reference, its composition and administration, and a perceived lack of transparency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macleans.ca/society/canadas-mmiw-inquiry-is-falling-apart-before-it-even-begins/|title=Canada's MMIW inquiry is falling apart before it even begins|work= Macleans|date=8 May 2017|publisher=macleans.ca}}</ref> Evidence was taken from 50 witnesses during the first hearings at [[Whitehorse, Yukon Territory]], over three days in May 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/indigenous/mmiwg-whitehorse-first-hearings-wrap-1.4142419|title=Missing and murdered inquiry wraps emotional 1st hearings in Whitehorse|publisher=}}</ref>
In July 2017 the [[Assembly of First Nations]] asked the Federal Government to reset the inquiry, revisit its mandate, and extend its timeline to allow more data gathering.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/lost-and-broken/|title=Inside the meltdown of Canada's inquiry into missing and murdered Indigenous women|last=MacDonald|first=Nancy|date=September 13, 2017|work=Macleans.ca|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en-US}}</ref> Throughout 2017 a number of key staffers left the inquiry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/indigenous/mmiw-inquiry-commission-staff-departures-1.4161957|title=4th staffer leaves MMIWG inquiry commission amid calls for reform|last=Sterritt|first=Angela|date=June 15, 2017|website=[[CBC News]]|access-date=July 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/thunder-bay/tanya-kappo-mmiw-1.4160105|title=Tanya Kappo resigns from MMIWG national inquiry staff|last=Porter|first=Jody|date=June 14, 2017|website=[[CBC News]]|access-date=July 11, 2017}}</ref> Executive director Michèle Moreau announced in June that she would leave her position at the end of July 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2017/06/30/executive-director-of-murdered-and-missing-indigenous-women-and-girls-inquiry-resigns.html|title=Executive director of murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls inquiry resigns|last=Talaga|first=Tanya|date=June 30, 2017|website=[[Toronto Star]]|access-date=July 11, 2017}}</ref> In July 2017 Marilyn Poitras resigned as a commissioner. She said in her resignation letter to the Prime Minister,
<blockquote>It is clear to me that I am unable to perform my duties as a commissioner with the process designed in its current structure ... I believe this opportunity to engage community on the place and treatment of Indigenous women is extremely important and necessary. It is time for Canada to face this relationship and repair it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/politics/poitras-commissioner-resignation-1.4199126|title=Marilyn Poitras resigns as MMIWG commissioner|website=[[CBC News]]|access-date=July 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/mmiw-commissioner-marilyn-poitras-resigns-in-another-blow-to-inquiry/article35653097/|title=MMIW commissioner Marilyn Poitras resigns in another blow to inquiry|last=Galloway|first=Gloria|date=July 11, 2017|website=[[The Globe and Mail]]|access-date=July 11, 2017}}</ref></blockquote>
On August 8, 2017, Waneek Horn-Miller, the inquiry's director of community relations, stepped down,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/indigenous-inquiry-mmiwg-1.4238881|title=MMIWG loses another key staffer as families slam 'colonial' inquiry process, demand hard reset|website=[[CBC News]]|access-date=August 8, 2017}}</ref> and on October 8, 2017, [[CBC News]] reported that the Inquiry's lead lawyer and research director had also resigned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/another-staffer-resigns-mmiwg-inquiry-1.4345757|title=MMIWG inquiry losing 2 more staffers|first=Austin|last=Grabish|date=October 8, 2017|work=[[CBC News]]|access-date=October 8, 2017}}</ref>
In October 2018 the Inquiry announced the last of its public hearing dates, following which the commissioners will write a final report and submit recommendations to the Canadian government by April 30, 2019.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://aptnnews.ca/2018/10/10/national-mmiwg-inquiry-sets-dates-for-final-submissions/|title=National MMIWG Inquiry sets dates for final submissions - APTN News|date=2018-10-10|work=APTN News|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
== US Initiatives == Activism and proposed legislation has drawn the issue of MMIW to the attention of some lawmakers.<ref name=Heitcamp/> Currently, the federal laws surrounding violent crimes create difficulties in dealing with non-Native perpetrators on native lands.<ref name=NIJ>{{Cite web|url=https://nij.gov/journals/277/Pages/violence-against-american-indians-alaska-natives.aspx#table2|title=Violence Against American Indian and Alaska Native Women and Men|website=National Institute of Justice|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref><ref name=Heitcamp/><ref name=Bachman>{{Cite journal|last=Ronet Bachman, Heather Zaykowski, Rachel Kallmyer, Margarita Poteyeva, Christina Lanier|date=|title=Violence Against American Indian and Alaska Native Women and the Criminal Justice Response: What is Known|url=https://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/nij/grants/223691.pdf|journal=US Department of Justice|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
According to the Supreme Court ruling in ''Oliphant v. Suquamish Indian Tribe'' (1978) tribal courts do not hold any jurisdictional powers over non-American Indians and Alaska Natives, and therefore cannot prosecute or punish them for their crimes. Additionally, the Indian Civil Rights Act (1968) limits the maximum punishment for any crime to a $5000 fine and up to one year in prison.<ref name=Bachman/> All violent felonies committed on tribal lands are prosecuted by the federal government. This continues to raise problems as law enforcement departments must compete over jurisdictional powers based on the nature of the crime, lowering the overall effectiveness of law enforcement, and providing enough immunity to non-citizens of the tribes (usually members of the dominant culture) for these crimes to become commonplace.<ref name=Bachman/>
=== National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls === On May 5th the US has declared a national day of awareness in order to raise concern for the crisis, and refocus attention on issues affecting Indigenous women with the hopes of improving relations between the federal and tribal governments. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.justice.gov/ovw/blog/recognizing-national-day-awareness-missing-and-murdered-native-women-and-girls|title=Recognizing the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Native Women and Girls|date=2018-05-04|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en}}</ref>
=== Washington State House Bill 2951 === Effective May 7, 2018, this bill orders an inquiry into how to increase rates of reporting for missing Native American women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://apps2.leg.wa.gov/billsummary?BillNumber=2951&Year=2017&BillNumber=2951&Year=2017|title=Washington State Legislature|website=apps2.leg.wa.gov|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
== Activism == Indigenous activists have been organizing protests and vigils relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit individuals for decades.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/missing-murdered-women-parliament-hill-vigil-tuesday-1.3790383|title='We're back again. We want justice': Activists hold vigil on Parliament Hill for missing and murdered women|last=|first=|date=October 4, 2016|work=|publisher=CBC|access-date=December 20, 2016|via=}}</ref> The Native Women's Association of Canada was one of many organizations that created a database of missing and murdered Indigenous women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://itstartswithus-mmiw.com/why-community-led//background|title=Background|last=|first=|date=|website=It Starts With Us - Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women|publisher=|access-date=December 20, 2016}}</ref> The community-based activist groups Families of Sisters in Spirit and No More Silence have also been gathering the names of missing and murdered Indigenous women since 2005.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.itstartswithus-mmiw.com/|title=Honouring The Lives Of Missing And Murdered Indigenous Women|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=December 20, 2016}}</ref> In 2015 the [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (Canada)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada]]'s Calls to Action also called for the federal government to establish a public inquiry into the issues of MMIW. Prime Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] announced the inquiry in December 2015.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.trc.ca/websites/trcinstitution/File/2015/Findings/Calls_to_Action_English2.pdf|title=Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada: Calls to Action|last=|first=|publisher=Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada|year=2015|isbn=|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|pages=4|quote=|via=}}</ref>
=== Women's Memorial March === The first [[Women's Memorial March]] was on February 14, 1991, in [[Downtown Eastside]], [[Vancouver]], which had numerous missing or murdered Indigenous women.<ref name="Ajik">{{cite web|url=https://womensmemorialmarch.wordpress.com/|title=26th Annual Feb 14th Women's Memorial March|website=Feb 14th Annual Women's Memorial March|publisher=Ajik|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref> The march was in response to the murder of a [[Coast Salish]] woman.<ref name="Ajik" /> The annual marches were intended to commemorate Indigenous women who have been murdered or have gone missing to build support for a national inquiry and program of response. In 2016 the government announced it would undertake such an inquiry. During the Vancouver march, the committee and public stop at the sites where the women were last seen, or murdered, holding a moment of silence as a sign of respect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/women-s-memorial-march-in-vancouver-attracts-hundreds-1.2957930|title=Women's memorial march in Vancouver attracts hundreds|website=CBC News British Columbia|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref> The committee has drawn attention to the issue locally, nationally and internationally.<ref name="Annual Women's Memorial March">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/player/play/2653830572|title=Annual Women's Memorial March|website=CBC Player|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref> The committee is made up of family members, front-line workers, close friends, and loved ones who have suffered the losses of Indigenous women during recent decades.<ref name="Ajik" />
This event has expanded and as of 2017, was held annually on Valentine's Day in more than 22 communities across North America. The march aims to break down barriers and raise awareness about racial stereotypes and stigmas that contribute to the high rate of missing and murdered Indigenous women in Canada.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.straight.com/news/867271/why-way-we-remember-missing-and-murdered-women-downtown-eastside-matters|title=Why the way we remember missing and murdered women of the Downtown Eastside matters|last=Siebert|first=Amanda|date=February 9, 2017|newspaper=The Georgia Straight|access-date=February 10, 2017|work=|via=}}</ref>
=== Sisters in Spirit Vigils === In 2002 the [[Native Women's Association of Canada]] (NWAC), [[Amnesty International]] Canada, [[KAIROS]], [[Canadian Association of Elizabeth Fry Societies|Elizabeth Fry Society]], and the [[Anglican Church of Canada]] formed the [[National Coalition for our Stolen Sisters]], an initiative designed to raise awareness about the MMIW crisis in Canada. In 2005 Indigenous women founded Sisters in Spirit, a research, education and policy program run by Indigenous women, with a focus on raising awareness about violence against Indigenous women, girls, and [[two-spirit]] persons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nwac.ca/home/policy-areas/violence-prevention-and-safety/sisters-in-spirit/|title=Sisters In Spirit - NWAC|work=NWAC|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US}}</ref> Sisters in Spirit collected the details of almost 600 cases of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women in Canada, including some historical cases that were not accepted by police, and cases where police closed the book on a woman's death despite lingering questions from family members.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://rabble.ca/news/2010/11/sisters-spirit-program-used-feds-squeeze-native-womens-association-canada|title=Sisters in Spirit program used by feds to 'squeeze' Native Women's Association of Canada {{!}} rabble.ca|website=rabble.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> This was the first database of its kind in Canada in terms of its detail and scope, however the federal government stopped funding the program in 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://aptnnews.ca/2010/12/01/need-for-action-behind-funding-cut-to-sisters-in-spirit-cabinet-ministers-letter-2/|title=Need for 'action' behind funding cut to Sisters in Spirit: cabinet ministers' letter - APTN News|date=2010-12-01|work=APTN News|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US}}</ref> Critics of the cut say it was meant to silence the Native Women's Association of Canada, the group behind the database.<ref name=":1" /> However, Sisters in Spirit vigils continue to be held across Canada every year on the 4th of October.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/sudbury/sisters-spirit-sudbury-1.4331297|title=Indigenous women and girls face 'internal terrorism,' says Sudbury vigil organizer|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en}}</ref>
Bridget Tolley founded the Sisters in Spirit vigils in 2005 to honour of the lives of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls and [[two-spirit]] persons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/mmiw-mmaw-missing-murdered-indigenous-women-canada-march-1.3256366|title=Marches, vigils held to remember missing and murdered indigenous women|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.metronews.ca/news/ottawa/2015/10/04/families-share-memories-of-missing-and-murdered-aboriginal-women.html|title=Families share memories of missing and murdered Aboriginal women {{!}} Metro Ottawa|work=metronews.ca|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en}}</ref> This annual event is organized in partnership with the NWAC. In 2006, 11 vigils were held across the country and in 2014, there were 216 vigils.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nwac.ca/policy-areas/violence-prevention-and-safety/sisters-in-spirit/october-4th-vigils/|title=October 4th Vigils|work=NWAC|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en-US}}</ref> The annual [[Fort St. John, British Columbia]] vigil has been taking place since 2008, honouring missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in northeast British Columbia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/northern-resource-development-boosts-violence-against-indigenous-women-report/article32660031/|title=Northern resource development tied to violence against indigenous women: report|last=Blaze Baum|first=Kathryn|date=3 November 2016|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=}}</ref> Sisters in Spirit continue to hold an annual, national vigil on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.energeticcity.ca/2017/10/fort-st-john-resident-says-wanted-make-trudeau-aware-government-failings-vigil-parliament-hill/|title=Fort St. John resident says she wanted to make Trudeau aware of government failings at vigil on Parliament Hill|last=Newton|first=Chris|date=6 October 2017|work=Energetic City|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Families of Sisters in Spirit === In 2011 Bridget Tolley cofounded [https://fsismmiw.wordpress.com/ Families of Sisters in Spirit] (FSIS) in response to the funding cuts to Sisters in Spirit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/03/seeking-justice-canada-murdered-women-2014338655968569.html?xif=.|title=Seeking justice for Canada's murdered women|last=O'Toole|first=Megan|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/7/5/12096898/missing-indigenous-women-canada|title=Why thousands of indigenous women have gone missing in Canada|work=Vox|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> FSIS is a grassroots group led by Indigenous women dedicated to seeking justice for missing Indigenous women, girls, and two-spirit persons through public awareness and advocacy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rabble.ca/rabbletv/program-guide/2012/10/features/families-sisters-spirit-justice-missing-and-murdered-indigen|title=Families of Sisters in Spirit: Justice for missing and murdered Indigenous women in Canada {{!}} rabble.ca|website=rabble.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> FSIS differs from Sisters in Spirit insofar as FSIS is fully autonomous, all-volunteer, and accepts no government funding.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://itstartswithus-mmiw.com/about/|title=About – It Starts With Us|website=itstartswithus-mmiw.com|language=en-CA|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> Tolley is Algonquin from the Kitigan Zibi Anishinabeg First Nation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rabble.ca/news/2011/03/bridget-tolleys-search-justice-her-mother|title=Bridget Tolley's search for justice for her mother {{!}} rabble.ca|website=rabble.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> Her activism began after her mother, Gladys Tolley, was struck and killed by a Sûreté du Québec police cruiser while walking across a two-lane highway on the Kitigan Zibi-Anishinabeg First Nation on October 5, 2001.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mcgilldaily.com/2016/11/tears-from-up-above/|title=Tears from up above {{!}} The McGill Daily|website=www.mcgilldaily.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> A police investigation into her death revealed no wrongdoing and deemed the case an accident.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2017/10/03/vigils-being-held-across-canada-wednesday-for-murdered-and-missing-indigenous-women-and-girls.html|title=Vigils being held across Canada Wednesday for murdered and missing Indigenous women and girls|last=Talaga|first=Tanya|date=2017-10-03|work=The Toronto Star|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-CA|issn=0319-0781}}</ref> However, Tolley claims police failed to inform her family that her mother's case was closed, and that Montreal police were brought in even though the local Kitigan Zibi police department had jurisdiction over the scene and should have been called to secure it.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/missingandmurdered/mmiw/profiles/gladys-tolley|title=Unresolved: Gladys Tolley|website=www.cbc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> Bridget Tolley has since campaigned for justice for her mother, demanding her case be reopened and subject to an independent investigation by the Province of Quebec.<ref name=":3" /> She remains a committed activist for social justice regarding police violence, education, housing, and child welfare.<ref name=":2" />
== Creative responses == === REDress Project === The REDress Project is based in Canada and is a public art commemoration of the Aboriginal women known to be missing or murdered.<ref name=about/> The installation consists of red dresses, which are placed to hang or flat in public spaces.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The REDress Project|url = http://www.redressproject.org/|website = www.redressproject.org|access-date = 2016-02-03}}</ref><ref name=about>{{Cite web|title = About ‹ The REDress Project|url = http://www.redressproject.org/?page_id=27|website = www.redressproject.org|access-date = 2016-02-03}}</ref> Canadian Jaime Black ([[Métis in Canada|Métis]]) began the project in 2000. She told [[CTV News]] that "a friend of hers, who is also an aboriginal, explained that red was the only colour spirits could see. 'So (red) is really a calling back of the spirits of these women and allowing them a chance to be among us and have their voices heard through their family members and community.{{'"}}<ref>{{Cite web|title = Red dresses seek to draw attention to missing, murdered aboriginal women|url = http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/red-dresses-seek-to-draw-attention-to-missing-murdered-aboriginal-women-1.2593772|website = CTVNews|access-date = 2016-02-03}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = About the REDress project|url = http://Indigenousfoundations.arts.ubc.ca/home/culture/artistic-expressions/jaime-black/about-the-redress-project.html|website = Indigenousfoundations.arts.ubc.ca|access-date = 2016-02-03|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160203131722/http://indigenousfoundations.arts.ubc.ca/home/culture/artistic-expressions/jaime-black/about-the-redress-project.html|archive-date = 2016-02-03|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref> The REDress Project has been displayed at the campuses of the universities of Winnipeg, Saskatchewan, Kamloops, Alberta, Toronto, and Queen's University as well as the Manitoba Legislature, and the [[Canadian Museum of Human Rights]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2017/03/21/red-dresses-a-visual-reminder-of-missing-and-murdered-indigenous-women.html|title=Red dresses a visual reminder of missing, murdered Indigenous women|last=Beeston|first=Laura|date=March 21, 2017|website=thestar.com|access-date=2017-03-22}}</ref>
=== ''Walking with Our Sisters''=== [[File:Walking With Our Sisters Shingwauk Auditorium 2014.jpg|thumb|''Walking with Our Sisters'' exhibition in the Shingwauk Auditorium at Algoma University in 2014]] ''[[Walking with Our Sisters]]'' is a community-based art installation, commemorating murdered or missing women and children from Indigenous communities. The project is community-led, from the creation of the piece to the facilitation of the exhibit at different sites. The hope is to raise awareness on this issue and create a space for dialogue-based community discussions on this issue. It is a solely volunteer initiative.
The art project is a collection of vamps from [[moccasins]]. A vamp is the extra layer of leather for the top lip of the moccasin. The installation has more than 1763 pairs of adult vamps and 108 pairs for children. Each pair is authentic and custom made for each individual woman reported missing. The vamps represent the unfinished lives of the missing or murdered women.
The project began in 2012, with a call to action issued on [[Facebook]]. People were asked to design and create moccasin tops. By July 2013, the project leaders had received 1,600 vamps, more than tripling their initial goal of 600. Men, women, and children of all races responded to the call and became active in the project.
This installation consists of vamps placed on the floor of a public space. It travels to select galleries and art exhibition halls. Patrons are asked to take off their shoes and walk alongside the vamps in the gallery, to ensure that the people they represent are not forgotten and to show solidarity with the missing or murdered women. Booked until 2019, the installation is scheduled for 25 locations across North America.<ref>{{cite web|title=Walking With Our Sisters|url=http://walkingwithoursisters.ca/|website=Walking With Our Sisters|accessdate=11 December 2015}}</ref>
=== Faceless Dolls Project === Begun by the Native Women's Association of Canada (NWAC) in 2012, the Faceless Dolls Project consists of making dolls to represent missing and murdered women, and those affected by violence.<ref name="dolls">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/manitoba/scene/other/2012/04/16/faceless-dolls-project-gives-voice-to-missing-and-murdered-aborginal-women/|title="Faceless Dolls Project" gives voice to missing and murdered Aborginal women|last=Morrisseau|first=Miles|date=April 16, 2012|newspaper=CBC Manitoba|access-date=February 14, 2017|work=|via=}}</ref> The dolls are designed as "a process of reconstructing identity" for women who lose individuality in becoming victims of crime. The first dolls were made to commemorate the 582 MMIW documented by the Association. They are intended as an artistic reminder of the lives and identities of the affected women and girls.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thewesternstar.com/news/local/2016/2/2/murdered-women-recognized-in-faceless-do-4424056.html|title=Murdered women recognized in Faceless Doll presentation|last=Gale|first=Frank|date=February 3, 2016|newspaper=The Western Star|access-date=February 14, 2017|work=|via=}}</ref> NWAC has brought this art project to universities and communities across Canada, where participants join in making dolls as a form of activism and raising awareness of the issue of MMIW.<ref name="dolls"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.brantfordexpositor.ca/2014/08/20/faceless-doll-project-remembering-victims|title=FACELESS DOLL PROJECT: Remembering victims|last=Ruby|first=Michelle|date=August 20, 2014|newspaper=Brantford Expositor|access-date=February 14, 2017|work=|via=}}</ref>
=== Female inuksuit=== Since late 2015 Kristen Villebrun, a local activist in [[Hamilton, Ontario]], and about ten other Indigenous women have been constructing [[inuksuk|inuksuit]] on the Chedoke Radial Trail.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Windigo|first1=Delaney|title=Inuksuks along Hamilton hiking trail created to remember missing, murdered Indigenous women|url=http://aptn.ca/news/2015/11/12/inuksuks-along-hamilton-hiking-trail-created-to-remember-missing-murdered-Indigenous-women/|accessdate=11 December 2015|agency=Aboriginal Peoples Television Network|publisher=Aboriginal Peoples Television Network|date=November 12, 2015}}</ref> This trail connects to the [[Chedoke Creek]], a watercourse in Hamilton. An inuksuk is a man-made stone structure commonly used for navigation or trail markers. ''Inuksuk'' translates to "in the likeness of a human".<ref>{{cite web|title=What is an Inukshuk?|url=http://www.inukshukgallery.com/inukshuk.html|website=Inukshuk Gallery|publisher=Gallery Indigena|accessdate=11 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151209150852/http://www.inukshukgallery.com/inukshuk.html|archive-date=2015-12-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
The women began the project in October 2015 when they noticed that shadows cast by previously constructed inuksuit on the trail were lifelike and reminiscent of women. These activists saw an opportunity to use these structures as a way of drawing attention to the issue of the missing women. They have constructed 1,181 inuksuit, working for six hours a day, four days a week. The project has attracted many questions, with hundreds of people stopping to inquire about the inuksuit. The women welcomed the questions, and they announced their intention to continue to build the female inuksuit until the government undertook an official inquiry into missing Indigenous women.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Carter|first1=Adam|title=Aboriginal women remembered with 1,181 inukshuks|url=http://www.rememberoursisterseverywhere.com/photo/missing-married-women|accessdate=11 December 2015|agency=CBC|publisher=Remember Our Sisters Everywhere|date=November 5, 2015}}</ref> In December 2015 Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced he would initiate such an inquiry.
In February 2016, Lucy Annanack ([[Nunavik]]) and a team of women built and placed another 1,200 inuksuit in [[Montreal]], Quebec.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=David|title=Nunavik woman spearheads Inuksuit campaign for Aboriginal women|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674nunavik_woman_spearheading_inuksuit_campaign_for_aboriginal_women/|accessdate=1 April 2017|work=Nunatsiaq Online|language=en}}</ref>
=== ''Missing & Murdered: Who Killed Alberta Williams?'' === In October 2016 journalist [[Connie Walker (journalist)|Connie Walker]] and the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] launched a podcast<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/webby-nominees-2017-1.4054424|title=Webby Awards: CBC's Missing & Murdered podcast, NFB's Seances vie for online prize|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-04-21|language=en}}</ref> titled ''Who Killed Alberta Williams?''<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.flare.com/culture/meet-the-woman-behind-a-new-must-listen-podcast-on-canadas-mmiw/|title=Meet the Reporter Behind a New, Must-Listen Canadian Crime Podcast - Flare|date=2016-10-20|work=Flare|access-date=2017-03-30|language=en-US}}</ref> The eight-part podcast examines the missing and murdered Indigenous women crisis in Canada though the lens of a specific case, the murder of Alberta Williams in 1989 along the [[Highway of Tears]] in British Columbia. The series was nominated for a [[Webby Award]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.flare.com/culture/meet-the-woman-behind-a-new-must-listen-podcast-on-canadas-mmiw/|title=Meet the Reporter Behind a New, Must-Listen Canadian Crime Podcast|last=Halushak|first=Maureen|date=October 20, 2016|work=Flare|access-date=December 21, 2016|via=}}</ref>
=== Big Green Sky === ''Big Green Sky'' is a social justice play commissioned and produced by Windsor Feminist Theatre, which debuted in May 2016 in Windsor Ontario. It was prompted by the outrage over the acquittal of Bradley Barton in the trial of Cindy Gladue's murder. This play is a direct result of reaching out to Muriel Stanley Venne,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://indspire.ca/laureate/muriel-stanley-venne-2/|series=Indspire |title=Muriel Stanley Venne|website=indspire.ca|access-date=2018-03-24}}</ref> Chair of the Aboriginal Commission on Human Rights and Justice, and President of the Institute for the Advancement of Aboriginal Women. Venne's report<ref name="Venne_Anaya_2016">{{Cite web|url=http://www.iaaw.ca/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/UN-Presentation-Booklet-V11.pdf |format=PDF |title=Presentation to the United Nations For All the Missing and Murdered Aboriginal Women of Canada|last=Stanley Venne|first=Muriel|date=October 2016|access-date=October 20, 2018 |publisher=[[Institute for the Advancement of Aboriginal Women]] |pages=11}}</ref> was submitted to United Nations rapporteur [[James Anaya]]. Venne created her report because she wanted to 'influence decision makers who have become very complacent and unconcerned about the lives of Indigenous women in our country."<ref name="Venne_Anaya_2016"/>
The playwright has created his heroine to be a Nigerian woman who moves to Northern Canada to see the Northern Lights and immerses herself in aboriginal culture. In this sense, members of the audience who are non-aboriginal are invited to take part in the journey of this "outsider" as she learns and uncovers the mysteries of murdered and missing aboriginal women. The title Big Green Sky comes from the display of the aurora borealis or Northern Lights. Aboriginal interpretations include that the Northern Lights represent the spirits of the departed who are communicating with their loved ones. The play will be gifted by WFT to any organization or individual wishing to bring awareness to this issue, and distributed without royalty fees, providing that all revenues/fundraising efforts be donated to local First Nations, Inuit or Métis women's initiatives.

revision.text:
[[File:United States POW-MIA flag.svg|right|thumb|The League's [[POW/MIA flag]]]] The '''National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia''' is an [[United States|American]] [[501(c)(3)]] [[non-profit organization]] that is concerned with the [[Vietnam War POW/MIA issue]]. According to the group's web site, its sole purpose is "to obtain the release of all prisoners, the fullest possible accounting for the missing and repatriation of all recoverable remains of those who died serving our nation during the [[Vietnam War]] in Southeast Asia." The League's most prominent symbol is its famous [[POW/MIA flag]].
==History==
===Founding===
The League's origins date to groups created by [[Sybil Stockdale]] and a group of POW/MIA wives in [[Coronado, California]], as well as POW/MIA wives in the [[Hampton, Virginia]], area led by [[Evelyn Grubb]] and Mary Crowe, in 1967.<ref name="ReferenceA">Grubb and Jose, ''You Are Not Forgotten'', {{Page needed|date=April 2011}}.</ref><ref name="Wainwright, Loudon">{{cite news | author=Wainwright, Loudon | title=When Johnny Comes Marching Home Again - or doesn't | magazine=[[Life (magazine)|Life]] | date= November 10, 1972 | authorlink= Loudon Wainwright, Jr. }}</ref><ref name="lat-obit">{{cite news | title=Evelyn Grubb, 74; Advocated Humane Treatment for POWs of Vietnam Era | newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date= January 4, 2006 | url= http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jan/04/local/me-grubb4}}</ref> Sybil Stockdale's husband, Navy Commander [[James Stockdale]], was shot down in 1965 and she was determined to make the American people aware of the mistreatment of U.S. POWs. Grubb and Crowe were frustrated with the lack of information from federal officials.<ref name="nyt-obit"/> It was these groups that finally convinced the U.S. government to change their official stance on the POW/MIA issue in 1969.<ref name="Wainwright, Loudon"/> Eventually, the League was incorporated in [[Washington, D.C.]], on May 28, 1970.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="Wainwright, Loudon"/>
Another notable member of the league during the war was [[Joe McCain]], brother of imprisoned U.S. Navy pilot and future U.S. Senator and presidential candidate [[John McCain]].<ref>McCain and Salter, ''Faith of My Fathers'', pp. 290–291.</ref>
===Increased national attention after 1972 ''Life'' magazine article===
The league gained increased international attention in 1972 when ''[[Life Magazine]]'' ran a feature article on the organization.<ref name="Wainwright, Loudon"/> The article started with a full page photograph of Major Wilmer Newlin Grubb of the United States Air Force, the husband of National League of Families President Evelyn Grubb, from after he had been shot down in 1966 and taken prisoner by the North Vietnamese Army.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="Wainwright, Loudon"/><ref name="nyt-obit"/> Evelyn Grubb by then was also serving as the League's representative to the [[White House]], the [[United Nations]] and the [[Paris Peace Talks]], pressing for better accountability, treatment and the speedy return of American MIA and POW soldiers, pilots, airmen, and sailors in the Vietnam War, as well as better policies related to their families.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Grubb did not find out until after the war was over that her husband had died shortly after being shot down.<ref name="nyt-obit">{{cite news| url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9900EEDC1130F937A35752C0A9609C8B63| title = Evelyn Fowler Grubb, 74, Leader Of a Group Supporting P.O.W.'s| date = January 4, 2006| newspaper = [[The New York Times]] }}</ref>
===Creation and adoption of "You Are Not Forgotten, POW/MIA" flag===
Then League President and POW wife [[Evelyn Grubb]] oversaw the development of the now-famous National League of Families' [[POW/MIA flag]] in the early 1970s.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="lat-obit"/> The flag's original design by military wife Haydn Anthony, was passed on to an ad agency and slightly modified by employee Newt Heisley, to represent America's missing men. The original design showed a POW crouched in a cage rather than the head of a POW now shown. Evelyn Grubb was then also a driving force in gaining the flags adoption by the military, the U.S. Postal Service and other federal service agencies.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Eventually the flag became widely popular and adoption of its use began to spread on its own, as the flag became a national symbol of Vietnam war remembrance.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The flag, with the now widely recognized "You Are Not Forgotten, POW/MIA" logo is still flown in front of all U.S. post offices, all major U.S. military installations, and most fire stations, police stations, many state level agencies and also most veterans organizations chapters across the United States today, and is almost always present at most local and national veterans events in the United States.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The flag is consequently still visible to millions of Americans on a daily basis.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===1980s: Split and founding of alternate group===
In the 1980s a different group, the [[National Alliance of Families|National Alliance Of Families For the Return of America's Missing Servicemen]], was formed as a split-off by National League of Families members over a disagreement with then League President Ann Mills Griffith over tactics the organization should employ in pursuing its goals, and disagreements about the status of missing servicemen by the 1980s.<ref name="skk">Keating, ''Prisoners of Hope'', p. 52.</ref> Compared to the league, the National Alliance takes a more activist, radical stance, especially with regards towards the [[Vietnam War POW/MIA issue]] and belief in the existence of "live prisoners" in Southeast Asia.<ref name="inside">McConnell and Schweitzer, ''Inside Hanoi's Secret Archives'', p. 390.</ref>
===Current status of organization===
The League's national office, based in [[Arlington, Virginia]], is still run by one full-time employee and various volunteers. To date, more than sixteen hundred U.S. servicemen are still listed as Missing in Action in the Vietnam War and efforts continue by certain departments of the U.S. government and the National League of Families to ascertain the fate of these missing service members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dtic.mil/dpmo/vietnam/statistics/2010/documents/Stats20100805.pdf|title=Vietnam-era unaccounted for statistical report|date=August 5, 2010 | publisher=[[Defense Prisoner of War/Missing Personnel Office]]}}</ref> Debate continues as to whether or not the efforts by the U.S. government, the Vietnamese government in Hanoi and other governments historically involved in the war have been, or continue to be, sufficient regarding the effort to find these missing soldiers, pilots, airmen and sailors.<ref name="nyt061692">{{cite news | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE4DD103AF935A25755C0A964958260 | title=Gulag Held M.I.A.'s, Yeltsin Suggests | author=Barbara Crossette | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=June 16, 1992}}</ref> The National League of Families continues to work at keeping the pressure on both Washington and Hanoi to bring complete resolution to this issue on behalf of each family with a loved one still missing in Vietnam.

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2008}} {{Criminal law}} '''Obstruction of justice''', in United States [[jurisdiction]]s, is a [[crime]] of obstructing [[prosecutor]]s or other (usually government) officials. [[Common law]] jurisdictions other than the United States tend to use the wider offense of [[perverting the course of justice]]. Obstruction also applies to overt coercion of court or government officials via the means of threats or actual physical harm, and also applying to deliberate sedition against a court official to undermine the appearance of legitimate authority. ==Legal overview== Generally, obstruction charges are laid when it is discovered that a person questioned in an investigation, other than a [[suspect]], has lied to the investigating officers. However, in most common law jurisdictions, the [[right to remain silent]] can be used to allow any person questioned by police merely to deny answering questions posed by an investigator without giving any reason for doing so. (In such a case, the investigators may [[subpoena]] the witness to give [[testimony]] under [[oath]] in court, though the witness may then exercise their rights, for example in the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]], if they believe their answer may serve to [[Self-incrimination|incriminate themselves]].) If the person willfully and knowingly tried to protect a suspect (such as by providing a false [[wikt:Alibi|alibi]]) or to hide from investigation of their own activities (such as to hide their involvement in another crime), this may leave them liable to prosecution. Obstruction charges can also be laid if a person alters, destroys, or conceals [[physical evidence]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/1519|title=18 U.S. Code § 1519 - Destruction, alteration, or falsification of records in Federal investigations and bankruptcy|website=LII / Legal Information Institute|access-date=2016-09-13}} Obstruction charges may also be laid in unique situations such as [[Refusing to assist a police officer|refusal to aid a police officer,]] escape through voluntary action of an officer and refusing to assist prison officers in arresting escaped convicts. Obstruction can include crimes committed by [[judge]]s, [[prosecutor]]s, [[Attorney General|attorneys general]], and elected officials in general. It is [[misfeasance]], [[malfeasance]] or [[nonfeasance]] in the conduct of the office. Most commonly it is prosecuted as a crime for [[perjury]] by a non governmental official primarily because of prosecutorial discretion. ==Notable examples== * [[Bill Clinton]] was [[Impeachment of Bill Clinton|impeached]] by the [[United States House of Representatives]] in 1998 for obstruction of justice charges based on allegations Clinton lied about his relationship with [[Monica Lewinsky]] in a sworn [[Deposition (law)|deposition]] in the [[Paula Jones]] lawsuit. This made Clinton only the second U.S. president to be impeached after [[Andrew Johnson]]. He was later acquitted by the Senate. * [[Richard Nixon]] was being investigated for obstruction of justice for his alleged role in the cover-up of the break-in at the [[Watergate complex|Watergate]] hotel during his [[United States presidential election, 1972|re-election campaign in 1972]]. Although it is unknown whether Nixon had foreknowledge of his re-election committee's "dirty tricks" campaign against [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] presidential candidates that led to the break-in, he was aware of it after the fact and paid money to keep the participants quiet. * Former Vice-Presidential adviser [[Scooter Libby|I. Lewis "Scooter" Libby]] was convicted of obstruction of justice in March 2007 for his role in the investigation of a [[Plame affair|leak to reporters]] by [[Richard Armitage (naval officer)|Richard Armitage]] of the identity of a CIA agent, [[Valerie Plame]]. His prison sentence was commuted by President [[Presidency of George W. Bush|George W. Bush]] in July 2007, so that Libby was no longer required to serve a two-and-a-half-year prison sentence, but was still required to pay a $250,000 fine, be recorded as a convicted felon, obey probation terms, and be disbarred. [[Donald Trump]] pardoned Libby on April 13, 2018. * [[Conrad Black]] was convicted of obstruction of justice in July 2007{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/14/business/13cnd-black.html|title=Conrad Black Found Guilty in Fraud Trial|last=Siklos|first=Richard|date=2007-07-14|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-08-31}} for removing 13 boxes containing financial records from his office in Toronto after they had been sealed by a court order, returning the boxes a few days later. * [[Barry Bonds]] was convicted of obstruction of justice on April 13, 2011 for his testimony in front of the [[grand jury]] during the [[BALCO]] steroid scandal.{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/04/barry-bonds-verdict-.html |work=Los Angeles Times |title=Barry Bonds convicted of obstruction of justice in performance-enhancing-drugs case |date=April 13, 2011 |accessdate=May 22, 2018}} The conviction was later overturned by an appellate court.{{cite news| url=http://www.mercurynews.com/crime-courts/ci_27967951/barry-bonds-conviction-overturned | work=San Jose Mercury News | title=Barry Bonds conviction overturned}} * In ''[[United States v. Binion]]'', malingering (feigning illness) during a competency evaluation was held to be obstruction of justice and led to an enhanced sentence.{{cite web |url=http://www.jaapl.org/cgi/content/full/34/1/126 |title=Behavior of the Defendant in a Competency-to-Stand-Trial Evaluation Becomes an Issue in Sentencing |publisher=Journal of the American Psychiatric Association |accessdate=October 10, 2007 }} ==Obstruction trends== "Anticipatory obstruction of justice" has recently appeared on the horizon in cases such as ''US v. Wolff''.{{Cite web|title = FindLaw's United States DC Circuit case and opinions |url = https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-dc-circuit/1161200.html |website = Findlaw|access-date = 2016-01-20}} However, the operative section, 1519, passed in 2002, has thus far languished in quasi-obscurity. Titled “Destruction, Alteration or Falsification of Records in Federal Investigations and Bankruptcy,” the provision was passed under Section 802 of the [[Sarbanes–Oxley Act]] of 2002. The text of the statute is relatively straightforward:
Whoever knowingly alters, destroys, mutilates, conceals, covers up, falsified, or makes a false entry in any record, document, or tangible object with the intent to impede, obstruct, or influence the investigation or proper administration of any matter within the jurisdiction of any department or agency of the United States or any case filed under Title 11, or in relation to or contemplation of any such matter or case, shall be fined under this title, imprisoned not more than 20 years, or both.
Aside from Section 1519’s 20-year maximum prison [[Sentence (law)|sentence]] (no small benefit to the government in big-dollar fraud loss cases such as Wolff), its primary appeal is that it uniquely removes certain key proof burdens from prosecutors’ collective shoulders. Prosecutors charging violations of Section 1519 must still establish either of the following: * The accused knowingly did the obstructive act with the intent to affect the investigation or proper administration of any matter within the jurisdiction of any U.S. department or agency or any case filed under Title 11; or * The accused knowingly did the obstructive act at least “in relation to or in contemplation of any such matter or case”. Not on the list, however, is the requirement that prosecutors demonstrate to the finder of fact which specific “matter or case” the accused attempted to obstruct. That is a significant benefit to the government.{{cite journal |url=https://www.perkinscoie.com/images/content/2/3/v2/23402/lit-11-03funkcommentary.pdf |first=T. Markus |last=Funk |title=Charges that Sting: 'Honey Laundering' and the New Era of Obstruction Prosecutions |volume=25 |journal=Westlaw Journal - White Collar Crime |pages=6 |date=March 2011 }} ==See also== * [[Accessory after the fact]] * [[False evidence]] * [[Jury tampering]] * [[Obstructing government administration]] * [[Perverting the course of justice]], a similar concept in the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] * [[Spoliation of evidence]] * [[Witness tampering]] ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL34303.pdf Obstruction of Justice: an Overview of Some of the Federal Statutes that Prohibit Interference with Judicial, Executive, or Legislative Activities], Congressional Research Service, April 17, 2014. * [https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL34304.pdf Obstruction of Congress: A Brief Overview of Federal Law Relating to Interference with Congressional Activities], Congressional Research Service, November 5, 2010.
