Retreat: 40 killed and 10 captured }} {{Campaignbox French and Indian War}} The '''St. Francis Raid''' was an attack in the [[French and Indian War]] by [[Robert Rogers (soldier)|Robert Rogers]] on [[Odanak|St. Francis]], near the southern shore of the [[Saint Lawrence River]] in what was then the French province of [[Canada, New France|Canada]], on October 4, 1759. Rogers and about 140 men entered the village, which was reportedly occupied primarily by women, children, and the elderly, early that morning, slaughtered many of the inhabitants where they lay, shot down many who attempted to flee, and then burned the village. Rogers reported killing as many as 300 people, while French reports placed the number closer to thirty, mainly women and children. One of Rogers' men was killed, and seven were wounded. Rogers and his men endured significant hardships to reach the village from the British base at [[Fort Crown Point]] in present-day [[New York (state)|New York]], and even more hardship afterwards. Chased by the French and vengeful Indians, and short on rations, Rogers and his men returned to Crown Point via the [[Connecticut River]] valley. Missteps in caching food stores for the expedition's use led to starvation, and some of Rogers' men were reportedly driven to [[cannibalism]] in order to survive. About one third of the raid's participants did not return. British colonial reports of the raid were unapologetic, as St. Francis had long been a place from which the natives raided colonial settlements as far south as [[Province of Massachusetts Bay|Massachusetts]], and Rogers reported a large number of English [[scalping|scalps]] decorating the main village buildings. ==Background== The 1759 summer campaign season in the [[French and Indian War]] was a resounding success for the forces of [[Kingdom of Great Britain|Great Britain]]. [[Battle of Ticonderoga (1759)|Fort Ticonderoga was captured]] in July, as was [[Battle of Fort Niagara|Fort Niagara]], and [[Siege of Quebec (1759)|Quebec was under siege]]. General [[Jeffery Amherst]], the victor at Ticonderoga, had little news of the situation before [[Quebec City|Quebec]], and he required accurate intelligence before deciding whether a move of his army along [[Lake Champlain]] was warranted. To that end he sent one party of rangers out on August 7 to reach General [[James Wolfe]] near Quebec by traveling up the [[Kennebec River]], a long and roundabout route that took the party nearly one month to complete. Although this party successfully traveled the route in both directions, the time taken meant that their news was effectively useless to Amherst due to the lateness of the season. [[File:Amherst.jpg|thumb|right|upright|General [[Jeffrey Amherst, 1st Baron Amherst|Jeffrey Amherst]]]] Amherst sent a second party, consisting of two officers from the 17th Regiment and a handful of [[Stockbridge Indians]], on a route from the northern end of Lake Champlain toward Quebec via the primarily [[Abenaki]] village of [[Saint-François-du-Lac, Quebec|St. Francis]]. In addition to dispatches for Wolfe, this party, led by Captain Quinton Kennedy, had, as a sort of cover for their movements, instructions to make offers of friendship to the Abenakis in exchange for their non-participation in the hostilities between the British and French. They carried a belt of [[wampum]] as part of this offer. The village of St. Francis, which was regarded by many as an Abenaki village, was in fact inhabited by a diverse community. In addition to the Abenakis who arrived after [[Father Rale's War]], members of other tribes that had been driven from [[New England]] in earlier conflicts lived there, as did white settlers that had either by choice or by capture adopted native ways. The village consisted of what were then typical European-style homes centered around a church. It had a reputation among British colonists to the south as the launching point for raids into communities as far south as [[Province of Massachusetts Bay|Massachusetts]].Fowler, p. 217 Robert Rogers was a teenager in [[Province of New Hampshire|New Hampshire]] at the time of one such raid in 1746.Brumwell, p. 54 ==Kennedy party captured== Kennedy and his party left [[Fort Crown Point]] on August 8. Word reached Amherst on August 19 that they had successfully reached [[Missisquoi Bay]] at the northern end of the lake in spite of French ships patrolling the area. French General [[François-Charles de Bourlamaque]], in command of the French defenses at [[Île-aux-Noix]], was alerted to the presence of Kennedy's party and intended movements by the arrival of British deserters on August 22. Bourlamaque immediately sent out patrols and alerted the St. Francis Abenakis to do the same. On August 24 Kennedy's party was surrounded and captured by the Abenakis; despite attempts at bribery and negotiation, they were turned over to General [[Louis-Joseph de Montcalm]] in Quebec. Amherst learned of this on September 10 when a letter from Montcalm reached him indicating that the two British officers were his prisoners. Montcalm noted that the men were not in uniform, a tacit implication that Montcalm could have treated them as [[spy|spies]] and hanged them, rather than treating them as [[prisoners of war]]. [[File:Abenakis.jpg|thumb|left|upright|18th-century depiction of an [[Abenaki]] couple]] Accounts circulated within the British camps that the two officers had been mistreated by the Abenaki, including the possibility of ritual torture. This heightened anger and resentment among the British, and Amherst, apparently upset over the Abenaki behavior, decided to send [[Robert Rogers (soldier)|Robert Rogers]] on a mission of revenge.Brumwell, p. 159 Rogers assembled a company of 220 men, drawn in part from [[Rogers' Rangers|his ranger companies]] but also including men he selected from the [[regular army]]. A significant number of his men were Stockbridge Indians bent on freeing their compatriots, and others were [[Mohegan]]s from his ranger corps. Amherst's orders to Rogers on September 13 included the following: "Remember the barbarities that have been committed by the enemy's Indian scoundrels on every occasion, where they had an opportunity of showing their infamous cruelties on the King's subjects, which they have done without mercy. Take your revenge, but don't forget ... it is my orders that no women or children are killed or hurt."Parkman, p. 264 ==Expedition starts== The expedition left Crown Point on the night of September 13. Its departure was not a well-kept secret, although Rogers and Amherst were the only ones to know its actual destination, and Amherst took steps to publish false instructions about Rogers' movements. The party, occupying 17 whaleboats, rowed north. Due to heightened French patrolling in the wake of Kennedy's mission, they made slow progress. The early days brought some notable disappointments, as more than 40 men turned back due to a variety of accidents and illnesses. Rogers reached the head of Missisquoi Bay early on September 23, where the boats and supplies for the return trip were concealed and left with two Indians as guards.Parkman, p. 265 Unfortunately for Rogers, his landing had not gone unnoticed. Although he had successful eluded the naval patrols, the British [[Battle of the Plains of Abraham|victory at Quebec]] on September 13 had resulted in the movement of French troops toward Lake Champlain, and there were increased French patrols in the area. General Bourlamaque had recently personally scouted Missisquoi Bay and declared it a good place from which the British could launch an attack. While French scouting expeditions the previous days had not turned up anything noteworthy, one party sent out the very day Rogers landed found a British oar floating in the bay. The next day, a larger party of scouts, coincidentally led by Oliver de la Durantaye, who had [[Battle on Snowshoes|battled Rogers in 1758]], discovered the boats. Some were destroyed and others were taken by the French for their use. Bourlamaque learned on September 25 that a sizable British force was in the area, and immediately raised the alarm to Montreal and sent out detachments in force to scour the countryside. He also concluded that the force might be targeting St. Francis in retaliation for Kennedy's capture, and stationed several hundred men near the site where the boats were hidden to set up an ambush in the event of Rogers' return. ==Change of plans== Rogers at first chose a course that headed primarily east, in order to avoid both the French defenses at Île-aux-Noix and the more northerly route that Kennedy had followed. This took the party through extremely swampy terrain. Two days into the trek the two Indian guards brought the news that the boats had been taken by the French. This change of circumstance led Rogers to hold a council to discuss their options. As they were behind enemy lines and far from any support, all their options were relatively poor. Rogers reported that they decided to continue with the mission, and then to "attempt a retreat (the only way we could think of) by way of [[Fort at Number 4|No. 4]]".Brumwell, p. 185 As part of this daring plan, Rogers sent Lieutenant Andrew McMullen and a half dozen men overland to Crown Point with instructions to deliver a cache of food to the confluence of the [[Connecticut River|Connecticut]] and [[Ammonoosuc River|Ammonoosuc]] rivers, a point about {{convert|60|mi|km}} north of Number Four. McMullen and his men made the overland trek to Crown Point (more than {{convert|100|mi|km}} over difficult terrain) in nine days, arriving on October 3.Brumwell, p. 186 Amherst immediately sent a ranger, Lieutenant Samuel Stevens, to Number Four with specific orders to deliver supplies to the agreed rendezvous point and to wait there until either Rogers and his men appeared or Stevens felt there was no probability of their appearance.Parkman, p. 267 Rogers and his men spent the next week slogging through swampy terrain, covering a distance Rogers estimated at {{convert|50|mi|km}} during which they were rarely dry. The conditions were so difficult that the French pursuit gave up, never discovering who they were looking for. On October 3 they finally reached dry land along the banks of the [[Saint-François River|St. Francis River]]. The village of St. Francis lay downstream and across the river, and was closer than Rogers realized. When his men began chopping down trees to construct rafts for use in crossing the river, the sounds of the axes were heard in the village, but disregarded. Rogers and his men eventually moved several miles upstream to locate a suitable ford. In spite of this, he reported that the crossing "was attended with no small difficulty",Brumwell, p. 189 with swiftly flowing water {{convert|5|ft|m}} deep. ==Raid== Many of the Abenaki men had been called out by Governor [[Pierre François de Rigaud, Marquis de Vaudreuil-Cavagnal|Vaudreuil]] to assist in tracking down the mysterious British force, which had seemingly vanished. On October 3 Vaudreuil wrote to Bourlamaque that he had called on the Abenakis and some local militia to set up an ambush on the [[Yamaska River]], the route Kennedy had used on his expedition. By the time Rogers and his company saw the smoke from the fires of St. Francis late on October 3, his force had been reduced to 142 men, and their rations had been completely exhausted. That night, Rogers donned Indian dress and sneaked into the village. There he observed that the natives were dancing, apparently a war dance in preparation for a major scouting expedition. One news report claimed that Rogers learned that this expedition was to look for the unknown British force that might be in the area. Rogers was not the only one of his party to enter the village. According to Abenaki oral tradition, a strange native identifying himself as a Mahican (as the Stockbridge Indians were also known) entered the village and circulated warnings that it was about to be attacked. A significant number of its inhabitants withdrew from the village in response to this warning, as many of the menfolk had answered Vaudreuil's call. At 3:00 am on October 4 Rogers marched his men near the village and then divided them into companies for the attack. The best shooters were placed to fire on anyone trying to escape the village. At about 5 am the attack began. In complete surprise they fell on the village inhabitants, many sleeping in their houses after the long night of dancing. There was little to no organized defense as Rogers and his men broke down doors and shot, tomahawked, or bayoneted people where they lay. Amherst's order to avoid killing women and children was lost in the frenzy. Any resistance was quickly dealt with, and many who tried to escape were shot by the sentries posted outside the village. Some inhabitants managed to reach their canoes and attempted to escape across the river; they were chased down and the canoes were sunk with their occupants, which included children.Brumwell, pp. 196-198 After sunrise, Rogers ordered the village burned down. As the houses burned it became clear that some of the inhabitants had attempted to escape the carnage by hiding in the attic spaces, which then became death traps. The church was burned, but not before it was ransacked for its more valuable trappings, and at least one priest refused quarter and perished in the flames.Brumwell, p. 198 The only structures not destroyed were the storehouses, which contained corn that Rogers and his men would require as sustenance during their retreat. Only a few of the village's inhabitants at the time the raid began survived the experience. Robert Kirkwood, a Scotsman who had been mistreated by [[Shawnee]] earlier in the war, wrote that "This was I believe the bloodiest scene in all America, our revenge being complete."Brumwell, p. 203 Rogers interrogated some of the captives, and learned that large companies of French and Indians were within easy marching distance,Parkman, p. 266 including a force of about 400 that were expected to arrive the next day. After a brief council, Rogers and his men agreed that the only reasonable means of retreat was to Number Four, a straight-line distance of about {{convert|200|mi|km}} through uncharted wilderness. Rogers and his men gathered up their loot and as much of the stored corn as they could carry, and set off to the south. ==Pursuit== News of the raid reached [[Trois-Rivières]] around noon on the day of the raid, and traveled quickly throughout the province. The attack on loyal allies of the French had to be answered, in spite of the larger threats posed by the armies of Amherst and Wolfe. Bourlamaque, in a somewhat naive move, sent a further 300 men to join the 400 already awaiting the British return to their boats on Missisquoi Bay, unaware that Rogers knew his boats were lost and had planned a different route of retreat. Vaudreuil also sent additional native reinforcement to assist in scouting the area around the bay. In Trois-Rivières a small force of experienced fighters under Captain [[Jean-Daniel Dumas]] mustered to chase after Rogers. Going first to Yamaska to pick up some the force that had gathered there, they finally reached St. Francis on October 5, more than a day behind Rogers. A few men came out of the woods to join the party there as the carnage was surveyed and plans formulated to give chase. The British force, burdened by supplies and prisoners, made fairly good progress, covering the {{convert|70|mi|km}} from St. Francis to [[Lake Memphremagog]] in about eight days. At this point rations began to run out again, and Rogers made a critical decision. Somewhere near present-day [[Sherbrooke]], Rogers broke the party up into companies of ten to twenty men, so that they might forage and hunt more effectively. While each party might be able to more readily supply itself for food, they also made easier targets for the pursuit.Fowler, p. 218 Several of the small companies were tracked down by determined pursuers. According to one French account, some forty of Rogers' men were killed and ten were brought as prisoners back to St. Francis, although historian Frank McLynn says that the expedition had 3 officers and 46 other ranks killed or captured.McLynn, Frank, ''1759: The Year Britain became Master of the World'', 2004, Jonathan Cape, London, {{ISBN|0-224-06245-X}}, p. 352 At St. Francis, some of the prisoners "fell a victim to the fury of the Indian women, notwithstanding the efforts the Canadians could make to save them", suggesting that they were not subjected to ritual torture or killing.Brumwell, p. 216 Two of Rogers' men survived after being spirited away by a sympathetic "English Indian" to the relative safety of Trois-Rivières. ==Starvation== The journals of the later stages of the expedition provide only a fragmented picture of what occurred to those of Rogers' force that eluded the pursuit, as men subjected to exhaustion, exposure, and starvation are unlikely to make good reporters. The journal kept by Rogers was relatively terse concerning the trek to the Connecticut River, with "many days tedious march over steep rocky mountains or thro' wet dirty swamps, with the terrible attendants of fatigue and hunger".Brumwell, p. 223 They reported eating bark, roots, mushrooms, and gnawed fragments of flesh off beaver skins. One widely reported account of cannibalism was recounted to historian [[Thomas Mante]] by Lieutenant George Campbell, in which his party of men came upon scalped remains trapped in logs on a small river, "devouring part of them raw" because they were too impatient to wait for a fire.Brumwell, p. 229 Robert Kirkwood, in a relatively unadorned account, tells how Rogers killed one of their prisoners, an Indian woman, butchered the remains, and divided them among his men.Brumwell, p. 230 After nine days of difficult travel, the group led by Rogers reached the appointed rendezvous on October 20. He found there a burning fire and no provisions. Lieutenant Stevens, whom Amherst had sent to Number Four to deliver the provisions to the rendezvous, had camped below the rendezvous point, and men from his party went to the rendezvous daily and fired their muskets to see if anyone was nearby. After several days of this, Stevens gave up, eventually returning to Crown Point on October 30. Amherst noted in his own journal that Stevens should probably have remained longer than he did. Rogers took the disappointment in stride. Leaving most of his emaciated company behind with promises to return with supplies in ten days, he and three men descended the Connecticut River on rafts, reaching Number Four on October 31, where he was reportedly barely able to walk. Supplies were immediately dispatched upriver, which Rogers reported as reaching his starving men "the tenth [day] after I left them".Brumwell, p. 232 ==Aftermath== On November 2, French scouts on the shores of Missisquoi Bay heard English voices. Investigating in force, they discovered five English survivors of the St. Francis raid, whom they took prisoner. These men reported that at least one more small company was in the area; three more men were found, whose throats were slit when they were found to be carrying human flesh. November 2 was also the day the General Amherst learned that Rogers had executed the raid. The account, delivered by a French officer under a truce flag, included mention that women and children had been slain, an observation Amherst discounted. Rogers' second in command arrived at Crown Point on November 7 with Rogers' report. That same afternoon an Indian from the expedition appeared at Crown Point with word that a party of Rogers' men was on the far side of the lake. The party consisted of six rangers, three prisoners, and a white woman freed from captivity, as well as a large amount of gathered loot. Amherst replied to Rogers' report with approval: "... every step you inform me you had taken has been very well Judged and Deserves my full approbation."Brumwell, p. 240 News of the raid was first treated with skepticism in the British colonies, but when confirmation came from Rogers himself, he and his men were treated as heroes. The ''New Hampshire Gazette'' devoted considerable space to coverage of the exploits of one of the province's famous fighters. The scope of the feat served to raise Rogers' popularity, even while he still worried about the fate of all of his men. Many of the village's residents who were not present at the time of the raid continued to serve with the French forces in the war, settling in other native communities along the Saint Lawrence. The village itself was eventually rebuilt. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== * {{cite book|last=Brumwell|first=Stephen|title=White Devil|publisher=Da Capo|year=2004|location=Cambridge, MA|ref=Brumwell|isbn=0-306-81389-0|oclc=57655778}} * {{cite book|last=Fowler, Jr.|first=William|authorlink=William M. '''Farzana Parveen Iqbal was stoned to death''' on 27 May 2014 outside a court in [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]]. Her father, two brothers and former fiancé were among the nearly twenty attackers. Farzana, who was pregnant by her husband Muhammad Iqbal, was killed following the tradition of [[Honour killing in Pakistan|honour killing]].<ref name=au>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-05-27/pakistani-woman-stoned-to-death-in-27honour-killing27/5482308 |title=Pakistani woman stoned to death in 'honour killing' - Australia Network News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=2014-08-03}}</ref><ref name=bbc1>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-27599325 |title=BBC News - Pakistan woman stoned by family outside Lahore court |publisher=Bbc.com |date=2014-05-28 |accessdate=2014-08-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press in Lahore |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/27/pregnant-pakistani-woman-stoned-to-death |title=Pregnant Pakistani woman stoned to death by family | World news |publisher=theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-03}}</ref>
==Incident== By his own admission, Muhammad Iqbal strangled his first wife in 2008 out of love for Farzana Parveen, and so that he would be free to marry her. Police said he had been released after that murder when a "compromise" was reached with his first wife's family. Iqbal and Farzana had an engagement that had lasted years. When she became pregnant by him, they decided to marry. According to Iqbal, Farzana's father, Muhammad Parveen, withdrew support for the marriage after Iqbal refused his demands for more money, beyond the originally agreed bride-price.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/29/pakistan-man-protesting-honour-killing-admits-strangling-first-wife|title=Pakistani man protesting 'honour killing' admits strangling first wife|date=29 May 2014 |website=The Guardian |publisher=theguardian.com |accessdate=May 27, 2014 |location=London}}</ref>
On 27 May 2014, Farzana Iqbal, 30, was attacked by about a dozen male family members in front of a [[High Courts of Pakistan|Pakistani High Court]]. The attackers were led by her father, Muhammad Parveen, but included her two brothers and other family members. They began by punching and kicking, then it escalated to using clubs and bricks, then hurling stones. She was killed for eloping and marrying Muhammad Iqbal, 45, whom she loved and by whom she was pregnant.<ref name=bbc1 /><ref>{{cite news |last=Associated Press in Lahore |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/may/27/pregnant-pakistani-woman-stoned-to-death |title=Pregnant Pakistani woman stoned to death by family | work = [[The Guardian]] | World news | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] |date= 27 May 2014 |accessdate= 3 August 2014 }}</ref> Farzana Iqbal was pronounced dead at a local hospital.
Most of the attackers initially escaped except for Farzana's father, Muhammad Parveen, who was arrested. Police investigator Mujahid quoted the father as saying: "I killed my daughter as she had insulted all of our family by marrying a man without our consent, and I have no regret over it."<ref> {{cite web |url=https://in.news.yahoo.com/pregnant-pakistani-woman-stoned-death-family-163143284.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215205524/https://in.news.yahoo.com/pregnant-pakistani-woman-stoned-death-family-163143284.html |archivedate=2015-02-15 |df= }}</ref><ref name=au/> As of 5 June 2014, 12 people have been arrested in connection with Iqbal's death, including her father.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/06/05/world/asia/pakistan-stoning-death/index.html?hpt=wo_c2 |title=More arrests made in stoning death of pregnant Pakistani woman |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-03}}</ref>

== Shortlisted Criteria == 1. The "data-based category" award nominees are artists who released an official MV in between January 1, 2015 to December 31, 2015 and the artist must be ranked in the chart throughout the whole year.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://vchart.yinyuetai.com/awards2015/news-detail/58|title=第三届音悦V榜年度盛典"最具人气歌手"入围歌手名单|last=|first=|date=|website=[[yinyuetai]]|language=zh|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 10, 2017}}</ref>
2. "The Most Popular Artists" series of shortlisted nominees are the top 30 artists in the TOP100 list in all five regions.<ref name=":0" />
3. "Artist Award" series nominees are artists who released music-related work(s) in between January 2015 to December 31, 2015. In addition to the results of the MV chart, the awards will be based on a combination of criteria: the standard of the released album, participation in offline activities, performances, film and television, hosting and the results that accompanies.<ref name=":0" />
4. "Composition Category" award nominees are artists who released an official MV from January 1, 2015 to December 31, 2015 and the artist must have the most #1 wins in the chart throughout the whole year. "MV Awards" are based on MV production standards, word of mouth, shooting, conception, production and list of achievements to determine the winning entries.<ref name=":0" />
5. "Album of The Year" is determined according to the annual album sales data ranking on the Yin Yue Shopping Mall 2015. Shortlisted nominees are the top 10 albums on the data ranking.<ref name=":0" />

2008 [[New York Musical Theatre Festival|NYMF]]
2011 Melbourne
2012 London |awards= }} '''''The Hatpin''''' is a musical by [[James Millar (Australian actor)|James Millar]] (book and lyrics) and [[Peter Rutherford]] (composer). It was inspired by the true story of Amber Murray who in 1892 gave up her son to the [[John and Sarah Makin|Makin family]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]. Written and developed in 2006–2007, ''The Hatpin'' opened at the York Theatre, [[Seymour Centre]] in [[Sydney]] on 27 February 2008.{{cite web|title=The Hatpin|url=http://www.australianstage.com.au/reviews/sydney/the-hatpin-1166.html|publisher=Australian Stage|accessdate=29 June 2013|author=Brett Casben|date=1 March 2008}} The musical has received subsequent productions in Australia, the United Kingdom and the United States. ==Synopsis== {{see also|John and Sarah Makin}} ''The Hatpin'' is the true story of a single mother, Amber Murray, who advertised her baby in a newspaper trading column in the hope of saving his life. [[Baby farmer]]s take the child in return for regular support payments, but in fact murder the child. Eventually the evil couple are arrested and tried for the murder of several infants - leading to one of the most moving criminal trials in Australian history. Using the moral support she gains from her friendship with the free spirited Harriet Piper, Amber fights the injustices of circumstance and tragedy to find hope and strength.http://www.stagewhispers.com.au/news/hatpin-%E2%80%93-aussie-musical-melbourne ==Productions== The original Australian production of ''The Hatpin'' opened at the York Theatre, Seymour Centre in [[Sydney]] on 27 February 2008, produced by [[Neil Gooding Productions]] and [[White Box Theatre]]. It starred [[Melle Stewart]], [[Peter Cousens]], [[Michelle Doake]], [[Gemma-Ashley Kaplan]], [[Caroline O'Connor (actress)|Caroline O'Connor]] and [[Barry Crocker]].{{cite web|title=The Hatpin|url=http://www.australianstage.com.au/reviews/sydney/the-hatpin-1166.html|publisher=Australian Stage|accessdate=29 June 2013|author=Brett Casben|date=1 March 2008}} ''The Hatpin'' made its US premiere on 15 September 2008 at the American Theatre of Actors in the Chernuchin Theatre as a participant of the [[New York Musical Theatre Festival]]. [[Caroline O'Connor (actress)|Caroline O'Connor]] followed ''The Hatpin'' overseas to reprise her role of Harriet Piper, as did [[Gemma-Ashley Kaplan]], who returned to play Clara Makin.{{cite web|title=The Hatpin Review|url=http://www.nytheatre.com/Review/russell-m-kaplan-2008-9-17-the-hatpin|accessdate=29 June 2013|date=17 September 2008}} In 2011 ''The Hatpin'' made its Melbourne premiere with [[Magnormos]] at [[Theatre Works|Theatre Works, St. Kilda]], with a season from 16 to 28 May. Directed by Shaun Kingma with musical direction by [[Sophie Thomas]], the production's cast included [[Samantha Morley]] as Harriet Piper, [[Philip Gould]] as Charles Makin, [[Sophie Collins]] as Agatha Makin, [[Emma Jones (actress)|Emma Jones]] as Clara Makin, and [[Gemma-Ashley Kaplan]] who this time played the role of Amber Murray.{{cite web|title=Review: The Hatpin, Magnormos|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/arts/review-the-hatpin-magnormos/story-fn7eul6a-1226059524598|publisher=Herald Sun|accessdate=29 June 2013|author=Kate Herbert|date=20 May 2011}} The musical received a London fringe production from 30 October to 24 November 2012 at the [[Blue Elephant Theatre]], in a Heather Doole, Blue Elephant & Greenwich Theatre co-production in association with Lazarus Theatre.http://www.blueelephanttheatre.co.uk/hatpinhttp://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/the-hatpin-the-blue-elepha-8234 The West Australian premiere of ''The Hatpin'' {{update|date=December 2017}} {{Sinai insurgency}} The following is a chronological timeline of fatal incidents during the ongoing [[Sinai insurgency]], which was invigorated by [[Egyptian Crisis (2011–14)|a period of relative instability and political turmoil]] in Egypt, beginning with the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|2011 uprising]] against former autocrat [[Hosni Mubarak]]. Insurgent attacks, however, intensified significantly following the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|July 2013 coup]] that ousted [[Muslim Brotherhood]]-backed president [[Mohamed Morsi]] and subsequent crackdown on his supporters.
==2011==
* 30 July 2011 - 6 Egyptian security forces killed.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} * 14 August–September 2011, [[Operation Eagle]]: 1 Islamist militant and 2 civilians killed.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} ** 15 August 2011 - 1 Islamist militant killed, 6 captured.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} ** 17 August 2011 - 2 Bedouins killed in unclear circumstances.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} * [[2011 southern Israel cross-border attacks|18 August 2011]] - 6 Israeli civilians and two soldiers and 5 Egyptian soldiers killed, as well as 10 attackers.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}
==2012==
=== March ===
* 27 March 2012 - 2 smugglers killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/154225#.U6bil7HiA0U|title=Egypt Kills 2 Israel-bound Smugglers|publisher=Arutz Sheva|date=27 March 2012|accessdate=22 June 2014|author=Kahn, Gabe}}</ref>
=== April ===
* 15 April 2012 - 2 policemen killed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/militants-kill-two-egyptian-policemen-in-sinai-suez-oil-facility-attacked-again-1.424479|title=Militants kill two Egyptian policemen in Sinai; Suez oil facility attacked again|publisher=Haaretz|agency=Associated Press|date=16 April 2012|accessdate=22 June 2014}}</ref>
=== May === * 2 May 2012 – 1 policeman killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.trend.az/regions/met/arabicr/2021336.html|title=Egyptian policeman killed in Sinai attack|publisher=Trend News Agency|date=2 May 2012|access-date=22 June 2014}}</ref> * 19 May 2012 – 1 tribe chief killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/sinai-tribe-chief-killed-arish|title=Sinai tribe chief killed in Arish|publisher=Egypt Independent|date=19 May 2012|access-date=22 June 2014}}</ref>
=== June === * 4 June 2012 – one policeman killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/04/us-egypt-sinai-idUSBRE85310Z20120604|title=Bedouin tribesmen, police clash in Egypt's Sinai, one dead: sources|publisher=Reuters|date=4 June 2012|access-date=22 June 2014}}</ref> * 18 June 2012 – one Israeli civilian killed and two wounded by an attack on Israeli-Egyptian border fence.<ref name=ismfa>{{cite web|title=Terror attack in the south|url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Terrorism-+Obstacle+to+Peace/Palestinian+terror+since+2000/Terror_attack_in_south_18-Jun-2012.htm|publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs|access-date=30 January 2013|date=18 June 2012}}</ref>
=== August ===
* [[2012 Egyptian–Israeli border attack|5 August 2012]] - 16 Egyptian soldiers and 8 militants killed.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} * 7 August 2012, [[Operation Sinai (2012)]] - 32 militants and suspects killed, 38 arrested; 2 civilians killed (by early September 2012).{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} ** 8 August 2012 – 20 militants killed in Sinai.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} ** 12 August 2012 – 7 suspected militants killed.{{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} ** 13 August 2012 – Armed men shot dead tribal leader Khalaf Al-Menahy and his son.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/13/us-egypt-sinai-violence-idUSBRE87C02C20120813|title=Gunmen kill Egyptian tribal leader and son in Sinai|publisher=Reuters|date=12 August 2012|accessdate=6 September 2014}}</ref> ** 29 August 2012 – Egyptian Army tanks and helicopters attack Jihadi cells, resulting in 11 dead militants and 23 more taken prisoner with no reported military casualties.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/08/29/world/meast/egypt-sinai-operation/index.html?hpt=hp_t3|title=Egyptian forces kill 11 militants in Sinai|newspaper=CNN|date=29 August 2012|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref>
=== September ===
* 16 September 2012 - 1 Egyptian soldier killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/9546944/Egyptian-soldier-killed-in-Sinai-clashes.html|title=Egyptian soldier killed in Sinai clashes |publisher=The Telegraph|work=Agence France-Presse|date=16 September 2012|accessdate=3 July 2014}}</ref> * [[September 2012 southern Israel cross-border attack|21 September 2012]] - 1 Israeli soldier and 3 militants killed.
=== November ===
* 3 November 2012 - 3 policemen killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-20192613|title=Gunmen kill three policemen in Sinai|publisher=BBC News|date=3 November 2012|accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref>
==2013==
===April=== * 16 April 2013 - 1 policeman killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/149166/gunmen-kill-egyptian-policeman-in-sinai.html|title=Gunman kill Egyptian policeman in Sinai|publisher=Turkishweekly.net|date=17 April 2013|accessdate=2013-09-03}}</ref>
===May=== * 7 May 2013 - 1 civilian killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/05/us-egypt-sinai-shooting-idUSBRE9440FL20130505|title=Gunmen kill alcohol seller in Egypt's Sinai|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=2013-09-03}}</ref> * 21 May 2013 - 1 militant killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/05/21/clashes-between-egypt-troops-and-gunmen-in-sinai-1-killed/|title=Clashes between Egypt troops and gunmen in Sinai leaves one gunman dead|publisher=Fox News|date=21 May 2013|accessdate=6 September 2014}}</ref>
===July=== * June–July 2013 - 1 Egyptian soldier and 20 gunmen killed in clashes.<ref name=ahram5july>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/75792/Egypt/Politics-/Clashes-in-Sinai-over-Morsi-removal.aspx|title=Clashes in Sinai over Morsi removal|publisher=Ahram Online|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=5 July 2013}}</ref> * 3 July to 15 July 2013 - Following the ouster of President Morsi, 8 policemen, 2 Christians, one a priest, and five civilians have been killed in attacks by Islamist militants in the Sinai peninsula.<ref name="ao18julysinai">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/76802.aspx|title=Sinai, Egypt's unsolved problem|publisher=Ahram Online|date=18 July 2013|accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/egypt-s-army-chief-defends-mohammed-morsi-s-ouster-1.1366568|title=Egypt's army chief defends Mohammed Morsi's ouster | CTV News|publisher=Ctvnews.ca|date=2013-07-14|accessdate=2013-08-13}}</ref> * 16–17 July 2013 - 10 militants killed.<ref name=ei18julyjihad>{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/ten-jihadists-killed-north-sinai-last-48-hours|title=Ten jihadists killed in North Sinai in last 48 hours|publisher=Egypt Independent|date=18 July 2013|accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref> * 17 July 2013 - 3 policemen killed.<ref name="ei18july">{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/three-policemen-killed-militant-attacks-north-sinai|title=Three policemen killed in militant attacks in North Sinai|publisher=Egypt Independent|date=18 July 2013|accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref> * 18 July 2013 - 1 policeman killed.<ref name=ao18july>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/76835.aspx|title=Egypt policeman killed in Sinai attack: medics|publisher=Ahram Online|date=18 July 2013|accessdate=18 July 2013}}</ref> * 19 July 2013 - 2 civilians killed.<ref name=ao19july>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/76897/Egypt/0/Rocket-attack-kills--civilians-in-Egypts-Sinai-Sec.aspx|title=Rocket attack kills 2 civilians in Egypt's Sinai: Security|publisher=Ahram Online|date=19 July 2013|accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref> * 21 July 2013 - 2 civilians, 2 officers, and 2 policemen killed.<ref name=ao22july>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/77061.aspx|title=Six killed in militant attacks in Egypt's Sinai|publisher=Ahram Online|date=22 July 2013|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> * 22 July 2013 - 1 civilian killed.<ref name=ao22julyciv>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/77140/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-man-killed-in-armed-attack-on-Sinai-check.aspx|title=Egyptian man killed in armed attack on Sinai checkpoint|publisher=Ahram Online|date=22 July 2013|accessdate=23 July 2013}}</ref> * 24 July 2013 - 2 soldiers and 3 jihadists killed.<ref name=Reuters24july>{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/two-egyptian-soldiers-three-militants-killed-sinai|title=Two Egyptian soldiers, three militants killed in Sinai|publisher=Reuters|date=24 July 2013|accessdate=27 July 2013}}</ref> * 26 July 2013 - 1 civilian killed.<ref name=dne27july>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/07/27/wave-of-violence-continues-in-sheikh-zuweid/|title=Wave of violence continues in Sheikh Zuweid|publisher=Daily News Egypt|date=26 July 2013|accessdate=27 July 2013}}</ref> * 27–28 July 2013 - 10 militants killed.<ref name=ei28july>{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/security-source-10-militants-killed-20-arrested-sinai|title=Security source: 10 militants killed, 20 arrested in Sinai|publisher=Egypt Independent|date=28 July 2013|accessdate=28 July 2013}}</ref> * 28 July 2013 - 1 officer killed.<ref name=dne28july>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/07/28/militants-strike-sinai-security-targets/|title=Militants strike Sinai security targets|publisher=Daily News Egypt|date=28 July 2013|accessdate=28 July 2013}}</ref> * 29 July 2013 - 4 soldiers killed.<ref name=dne30july>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2013/07/30/more-dead-and-injured-in-sinai/|title=More dead and injured in Sinai|publisher=Daily News Egypt|date=30 July 2013|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref> * 30 July 2013 - 1 soldier killed.<ref name=ao30july>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/77844.aspx|title=Egyptian soldier shot dead in Sinai by militants|publisher=Ahram Online|date=30 July 2013|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref>
===August=== * 2 August 2013 - 1 policeman killed.<ref name=ao2aug>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/78001/Egypt/0/Bomb-attack-on-Sinai-hotel-leaves-no-casualties.aspx|title=Bomb attack on Sinai hotel leaves no casualties|publisher=Ahram Online|date=2 August 2013|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref> * 5 August 2013 - 1 soldier killed.<ref name=ao5aug>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/78365.aspx|title=Gunmen kill soldier in Egypt's Sinai|publisher=Ahram Online|date=5 August 2013|accessdate=6 August 2013}}</ref> * 7 August 2013 - 1 civilian killed.<ref name=Reuters9aug>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/09/us-egypt-explosions-idUSBRE9780TB20130809|title=Four Islamist militants killed in Egypt near Israel: sources|publisher=Reuters|date=9 August 2013|accessdate=9 August 2013}}</ref> * 9 August 2013 - It was flying to [[Saint Petersburg]] from [[Sharm el-Sheikh|Sharm-el-Sheikh]] when it broke up over Hasna (Egypt), killing all on board.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/11967725/Russian-plane-crash-Isil-claims-it-brought-down-airliner-that-crashed-in-Sinai-with-224-people-on-board-latest-news.html|title=Russian plane crash: Isil claims it 'brought down' airliner that crashed in Sinai with 224 people on board - latest news|work=The Telegraph (uk)|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref> Data obtained from the airplane [[Flight recorder|black boxes]] gives credence to the idea that there was a bomb attack.<ref>{{cite news|title=Russian plane black boxes point to 'attack', Putin halts flights|url=https://news.yahoo.com/black-box-confirms-violent-sudden-demise-russian-plane-172633620.html|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=AFP|date=6 November 2015}}</ref>

=== February === {{expand section|date=September 2016}}
=== March === * 19 March 2016 - an attack on a checkpoint in [[Arish]] killed 13 policemen.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-35854404|title=Egypt: 'IS attack' kills 13 policemen in Sinai|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref>
=== April === * 7 April 2016 - an attack killed 15 soldiers and two civilians.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://time.com/4322544/israel-patrols-its-southern-border-as-isis-lurk-in-the-sinai-peninsula/|title=Israel Patrols Its Southern Border as ISIS Lurks in the Sinai Peninsula|last=Schwartz|first=Yardena|date=10 May 2016|work=Time|accessdate=5 September 2016|issn=0040-781X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-violence/seven-killed-15-injured-in-sinai-blasts-idUSKCN0X50CT|title=Seven killed, 15 injured in Sinai blasts|date=8 April 2016|work=Reuters|accessdate=2017-12-24}}</ref>
=== May === * 30 May 2016 - 88 militants were killed and many supply caches were destroyed in an air attack on Jabal Halal.<ref name="Issacharoff">{{Cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/sinai-attacks-decline-as-egypts-fight-against-is-yields-results/|title=Sinai attacks decline as Egypt's fight against IS yields results|last=Issacharoff|first=Avi|publisher=The Times of Israel|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref>
=== June === * 28 June 2016 - A series of air strikes killed 33 ISIS fighters and injured 50 others.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/over-30-gunmen-said-killed-in-egyptian-strikes-in-sinai/|title=Over 30 gunmen said killed in Egyptian strikes in Sinai|access-date=2017-12-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== July === {{expand section|date=September 2016}}
=== August === * 4 August 2016 - Egyptian military spokesperson said that Abu Doaa Al-Ansari, the leader of the North Sinai-based group that is affiliated with ISIS, was killed along with 45 other militants in air strikes in the south and south-west of El-Arish.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://egyptianstreets.com/2016/08/04/egypt-kills-leader-of-isis-affiliate-in-sinai-and-45-other-terrorists/|title=Egypt Kills Leader of ISIS-Affiliate in Sinai and 45 Other Terrorists|publisher=Egyptian Streets}}</ref><ref name="Vocativ">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vocativ.com/351630/egypt-claims-to-have-killed-sinai-isis-branch-leader/|title=Egypt Claims To Have Killed A Top ISIS Leader In Sinai|date=17 August 2016|publisher=Vocativ|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref>
=== September === * 4 September 2016 - The army reported another 40 militants killed by airstrikes in September.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20160904/1044957356/egypt-sinai-militants.html|title=Egyptian Air Force Kill Over 40 Militants in North Sinai - Reports|publisher=Sputnik News|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref>
=== October === * ''' 1 October 2016 ''' - 5 police conscripts killed. * ''' 14 October 2016 ''' - 12 soldiers and 15 militants killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-insurgency-idUSKBN12E14Q|title=A suspected ISIL attack on a security checkpoint in North Sinai Governorate, Egypt, leaves at least 12 Egyptian military personnel and 15 terrorists dead|publisher=Reuters|date=14 October 2016|accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref> * ''' 17 October 2016 ''' - Clashes in North Sinai Governorate left 3 soldiers and 18 insurgents dead.<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/245926/Egypt/Politics-/Three-Egyptian-soldiers-killed-during-air,-ground-.aspx</ref> * ''' 30 October 2016 ''' - A military operation in North Sinai Governorate left 4 soldiers and 6 insurgents dead.<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/246886/Egypt/Politics-/Four-Egyptian-army-personnel-killed-in-North-Sinai.aspx</ref>
=== November === * ''' 5 November 2016 '''- In [[North Sinai Governorate]] Egyptian soldiers killed at least 11 terrorist.<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/247364/Egypt/Politics-/-militants-killed-in-North-Sinai-military-operatio.aspx</ref> * ''' 10 November 2016 ''' - Soldiers killed at least 6 insurgents in [[North Sinai Governorate]]<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/248784/Egypt/Politics-/Six-militants-killed-in-North-Sinai-military-opera.aspx</ref>
=== December === {{expand section|date=September 2016}}
== 2017 ==
===January===
* '''16 January''' - Bombing left one dead and 2 injured in Aris city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/256202/Egypt/Politics-/One-civilian-killed,-two-injured-in-IED-explosion-.aspx|title=Bombing left one dead and 2 injured in Aris city|publisher=Al-Ahram|date=16 January 2017|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> * '''17 January''' - Insurgents kills at least 8 police in New Valley governorate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/256235/Egypt/Politics-/Militants-kill--Egyptian-policemen-in-attack-on-Ne.aspx|title=Insurgents kills at least 8 police|publisher=Al-Ahram|date=17 January 2017|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> * '''20 January''' - Terrorist shoot dead a civilian in the city of Arish.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/256477/Egypt/Politics-/Militants-gun-down-teacher-in-Egypts-North-Sinai-.aspx|title=Terrorist shoot dead a civilian in the city of Arish|publisher=Al-Ahram|date=20 January 2017|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> * '''23 January''' - Insurgents kills at least 5 Egyptian soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/256684/Egypt/Politics-/Five-soldiers-killed-by-militants-in-Sinai-Egyptia.aspx|title=Insurgents kills at least 5 Egyptian soldiers|publisher=Al-Ahram|date=23 January 2017|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> * '''25 January''' - Soldiers kills at least 3 terrorists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/256823/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-army-kills-three-militants-in-Sinai-raid-on.aspx|title=Soldiers kills at least 3 terrorists|publisher=Al-Ahram|date=25 January 2017|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref>
===February=== * '''9 February''' - ISIL-linked operatives launched four Grad rockets from Egyptian territory in Sinai peninsula on the Israeli southernmost city of Eilat, prompting Israeli [[Iron Dome]] system to intercept three of the rockets, with no physical casualties or damage reported, though 11 civilians were brought to Eilat Josephtal Hospital to be treated for shock.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4207832/ISIS-rocket-attack-Israel-foiled-missiles-shot-down.html]</ref>
===March===
* '''9 March''' - Two police officers were killed and four wounded after an IED exploded near a security convoy in Arish.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/260641/Egypt/Politics-/Two-police-officers-killed-by-IED-in-North-Sinai.aspx|title=Two police officers killed by IED in North Sinai|publisher=Ahram Online}}</ref> * '''18 March''' - Egyptian military killed 18 militants during recent air raids in North Sinai province.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/world/air-raids-kill-18-militants-in-egypts-sinai/|title=Air raids kill 18 militants in Egypt's Sinai|publisher=The Indian Express}}</ref> * '''20 March''' - Three people were killed and 11 others injured in two attacks across Sinai province, according to a local security source. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/roadside-bombs-kill-3-in-egypt-s-sinai-peninsula/776103|title=Roadside bombs kill 3 in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula|publisher=Anadolu Agency|date=21 March 2017}}</ref> * '''23 March''' - Ten Egyptian soldiers and two policemen have been killed by two car bomb explosions in central Sinai during an operation against militants. Fifteen militants were also killed and seven others arrested, the military said in a statement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-39364778|title=Ten Egyptian soldiers killed in Sinai car bombings|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/egypt-says-sinai-fighting-kills-12-security-forces/|title=Egypt says Sinai fighting kills 12 security forces|publisher=Times of Israel}}</ref> * '''26 March''' - Army forces thwarted an ambush by militants in Rafah city, killing eight militants. * '''27 March''' - An army soldier was killed when gunmen opened fire on a military checkpoint in Sheikh Zuweid. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/violence-kills-soldier-8-militants-in-egypts-sinai/780486|title=Violence kills soldier, 8 militants in Egypt's Sinai|publisher=Anadolu Agency}}</ref>
===April===
* '''3 April''' - A police officer was injured when he thwarted a terrorist attack on a security checkpoint in Arish.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://egypt.liveuamap.com/en/2017/3-april-police-officer-injured-thwarted-a-terrorist-attack|title=Police officer injured thwarted a terrorist attack on a security checkpoint in the Street of gisr el wadi - El Arish|work=egypt.liveuamap|access-date=2017-04-03|language=en}}</ref> * '''18 April''' - A suicide bomber detonated at a checkpoint near a church in Southern [[Sinai Peninsula|Sinai]], killing an officer and wounding four others.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt: Sinai Monastery Attacked|url=https://www.stratfor.com/situation-report/egypt-sinai-monastery-attacked|website=stratfor.com|publisher=Stratfor|accessdate=April 18, 2017}}</ref> * '''21 April''' - It was reported on 21 April 2017 that an Egyptian air raid killed 19 ISIL fighters, including three unnamed leaders.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/04/egypt-air-raids-kill-19-isil-fighters-sinai-170420144817777.html Egypt says air raids kill 19 ISIL fighters in Sinai]</ref> * '''27 April''' - An Islamic State suicide bomber killed four members of a Bedouin tribe and wounded others in Rafah.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/suicide-bomber-kills-4-bedouin-in-egypts-sinai/|title=Suicide bomber kills 4 Bedouin in Egypt's Sinai|access-date=2017-04-27|language=en}}</ref>
===May===
* '''20 May''' - Two civilians were abducted and beheaded in Rafah and Arish, a security source said. In another incident, seven gunmen were killed by army shelling in southern Rafah.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/egypt-nine-killed-in-sinai-violence/822341|title=Egypt: Nine killed in Sinai violence|publisher=Anadolu Agency|accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref>
=== June === {{expand section|date=December 2017}}
===July=== * '''22 July''' - 30 militants killed and four vehicles destroyed in airstrikes in Arish, Sheikh Zuweid and Rafah in the northern Sinai peninsula.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/30-militants-killed-in-egypts-sinai/866926|title=30 militants killed in Egypt's Sinai|publisher=Anadolu Agency|accessdate=22 July 2017}}</ref>
===August === {{expand section|date=December 2017}}
===September === * '''12 September''' - At least 18 Egyptian policemen killed and three injured in an attack near Arish claimed by Islamic State.<ref>[http://m.jpost.com/arab-israeli-conflict/nine-egyptian-policemen-killed-in-sinai-blast-504785 18 EGYPTIAN POLICEMEN KILLED IN SINAI BLAST]</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sweilam|first1=Ashraf|last2=Hendawi|first2=Hamza|title=Militants attack convoy in Egypt's Sinai, kill 18 police|url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2017/sep/11/militants-attack-convoy-in-egypts-sinai-kill-18-po/|accessdate=12 September 2017|work=Spokesman.com|language=en}}</ref>
=== October === {{expand section|date=December 2017}}
=== November === * 24 November 2017 - In [[bir al-Abed attack]] jihadists killed 311 people and injured at least 122.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/24/world/middleeast/mosque-attack-egypt.html|title=Militants Kill 305 at Sufi Mosque in Egypt's Deadliest Terrorist Attack|last=Walsh|first=Declan|date=2017-11-24|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-12-24|last2=Youssef|first2=Nour|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
=== December === * 19 December 2017 - one officer was killed and two were injured in a failed assassination attempt on the Minister of Interior [[Magdi Abdel-Ghaffar]] and the minister of defense [[Sedki Sobhy]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-security-claim/islamic-state-claims-air-base-attack-in-egypts-north-sinai-idUSKBN1EE1SA|title=Islamic State claims air base attack in Egypt's North Sinai|date=20 December 2017|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> * 20 December 2017 - 5 ISIS militants were killed and an army captain was killed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/egypt/1.830179|title=Egyptian Forces Clash With ISIS Militants Near Sinai Airport|last=Reuters|date=2017-12-20|work=Haaretz|accessdate=2017-12-24}}</ref>
== 2018 ==
===January===
* '''3 January''' - Bombing left one police officer dead in North Sinai <ref>{{cite web|title=Egyptian police officer killed in bomb blast in Sinai|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-01/04/c_136870072.htm|website=www.xinhuanet.com|publisher=Xinhua|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref> * '''4 January''' - Three police officers and one civilian killed in an ambush outside of el-Arish<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sweilam|first1=Ashraf|title=Egypt say 3 policemen killed in northern Sinai: officials|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2018/01/04/egypt-say-3-policemen-killed-in-northern-sinai-officials.html|website=foxnews.com|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref> * '''9 January''' - Egyptian forces kill 8 suspected militants in a shootout in el-Arish<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt says its forces killed 8 suspected jihadists in Sinai|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/egypt-says-its-forces-killed-8-suspected-jihadists-in-sinai/|website=timesofisrael.com|publisher=Times of Israel|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref> * '''17 January''' - Egyptian army kills one suspected terrorist and arrests 22 others in North Sinai<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt army kills terrorist, arrests 22 suspects in Sinai: spokesman|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-01/17/c_136902885.htm|website=www.xinhuanet.com|publisher=Xinhua News|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref> * '''23 January''' - Egyptian Armed Forces kill two suspected militants in raids on hidouts in North Sinai <ref>{{cite web|title=Two militants killed, hideouts destroyed in military operations in Siani|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/two-militants-killed-hideouts-destroyed-in-military-operations-in-sinai/|website=egyptindependent.com|publisher=Egypt Independent|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref>
===February===
* '''1 February''' - A Central Security Forces conscript was killed and another wounded after militants opened fire on a police checkpoint in south el-Arish<ref>{{cite web|title=Police conscript killed, another injured in N. Sinai terror attack|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/police-conscript-killed-another-injured-in-n-sinai-terror-attack/|website=www.egyptindependent.com|publisher=Egypt Independent|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref> * '''4 February''' - Roadside bomb kills two Egyptian security officials just south of el-Arish<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sweilam|first1=Ashraf|title=Roadside Bomb in Sinai Kills 2 Egyptian Security Forces|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-04/roadside-bomb-in-sinai-kills-2-egyptian-security-forces|website=www.bloomberg.com|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref> * '''19 February''' - 3 Egyptian soldiers and four militants affiliated with Islamic State killed in Sinai during government operation<ref>{{cite web|title=Three Egyptian soldiers killed in Sinai campaign|url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/three-egyptian-soldiers-killed-in-sinai-campaign-20180219|website=News24|publisher=Associated Free Press|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref> * '''27 February''' - Two Egyptian soldiers and one officer killed while fighting militants in Northern Sinai<ref>{{cite web|last1=Magdy|first1=Samy|title=Egypt says 3 troops killed fighting militants in Siani|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/egypt-says-3-troops-killed-fighting-militants-in-sinai/2018/02/27/c51794c2-1bd5-11e8-98f5-ceecfa8741b6_story.html|website=washingtonpost.com|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref>
=== March ===
* '''4 March''' - Four Egyptian soldiers and ten militants killed in Arish<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20180304-4-egyptian-troops-killed-amid-sinai-operation/|title=4 Egyptian troops killed amid Sinai operation|date=2018-03-04|work=Middle East Monitor|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-GB}}</ref> * '''11 March''' - 2 Egyptian soldiers and 16 militants killed during military operation<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/egypt-2-soldiers-killed-amid-sinai-offensive/1085433|title=Egypt: 2 soldiers killed amid Sinai offensive|website=Anadolu Agency|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> * '''19 March''' - 4 Egyptian soldiers and 36 militants killed<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/egypt/four-egyptian-soldiers-36-militants-killed-in-sinai-clashes-1.5913870|title=Four Egyptian Soldiers, 36 Militants Killed in Sinai Clashes|last=Press|first=The Associated|date=2018-03-19|work=Haaretz|access-date=2018-04-18|last2=Haaretz|language=en}}</ref> * '''March 31''' - Two Egyptian soldiers and 6 militants reported killed in northern Sinai<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.enca.com/africa/six-jihadists-two-egyptian-soldiers-killed-in-sinai|title=Six jihadists, two Egyptian soldiers killed in Sinai|website=www.enca.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
=== April ===
* '''14 April''' - 8 Egyptian troops killed and 15 wounded, 14 militants dead after attack on a military base in central Sinai<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wboy.com/news/egypt-says-8-troops-killed-15-wounded-in-sinai-clashes/1121715127|title=Egypt says 8 troops killed, 15 wounded in Sinai clashes|date=2018-04-14|work=WBOY|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US}}</ref> * '''25 April''' - Egyptian Army reports 30 militants and 3 soldiers killed<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.enca.com/africa/30-jihadists-3-egyptian-soldiers-killed-in-sinai-army|title=30 jihadists, 3 Egyptian soldiers killed in Sinai: army|website=www.enca.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref>
=== May ===
* '''29 May''' - 8 militants and 2 soldiers killed in crackdown on Sinai's western border<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailysabah.com/mideast/2018/05/29/8-militants-and-2-egyptian-soldiers-killed-in-sinai-peninsula|title=8 militants and 2 Egyptian soldiers killed in Sinai Peninsula|work=DailySabah|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref>
=== June ===
=== July ===
=== August ===
* '''19 August''' - A car bomb kills one military officer and wounds four conscripts south of El Arish <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/egypt-officials-car-bomb-kills-officer-wounds-4-in-sinai-20180820|title=Egypt officials: Car bomb kills officer, wounds 4 in Sinai|work=News24|access-date=2018-09-11|language=en}}</ref> *'''25 August''' - Four soldiers and four militants killed in clashes at a checkpoint in Arish city, another 10 soldiers reported wounded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fox13memphis.com/news/egypt-officials-say-4-police-4-militants-killed-in-sinai/820359058|title=Egypt officials say 4 police, 4 militants killed in Sinai|last=EndPlay|date=2018-08-25|work=WHBQ|access-date=2018-09-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== September ===
* '''7 Sept''' - A car bomb detonates during vehicle inspection, killing a colonel at Jabal al Halal. Another car bomb detonates injures a soldier near Sheikh Zuweld.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/blast-kills-army-officer-inspecting-car-egypts-sinai-57669645|title=Blast kills army officer inspecting car in Egypt's Sinai|last=News|first=ABC|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-09-11|language=en}}</ref>
=== October ===
* '''20 October''' - Militants opened fire on workers who were building a security wall in Arish, the attack left 3 workers dead and a fourth worker injured, counter-terrorism operations afterwards resulted in 6 militants dead.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/suspected-militants-kill-3-workers-in-egypts-sinai/2018/10/21/d6ddb29a-d516-11e8-8384-bcc5492fef49_story.html?utm_term=.396ba9e03b10|title=Suspected militants kill 3 workers in Egypt’s Sinai|work=www.washingtonpost.com|accessdate=2018-10-21}}</ref> * '''25 October''' - A roadside bomb struck workers who were building a security wall in Arish, the bombing killed 3 workers and injured 10 more, the attack was blamed on the Islamic State.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/egyptian-officials-roadside-bomb-kills-3-workers-in-sinai/2018/10/25/8ca73da4-d82c-11e8-8384-bcc5492fef49_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.2e9a14542ac8|title=Egyptian officials: Roadside bomb kills 3 workers in Sinai|work=Washingtonpost|accessdate=2018-10-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/egyptian-officials-roadside-bomb-kills-3-workers-in-sinai-20181025|title=Egyptian officials: Roadside bomb kills 3 workers in Sinai|work=www.news24.com|accessdate=2018-10-25}}</ref>

{{About|the theatre in Boston, Massachusetts, in the 1820s-1840s||Tremont Theatre (disambiguation)}}
[[Image:TremontSt ca1843 Boston byPhilipHarry MFABoston.png|400px|thumb|right|Tremont Theatre (at right), Tremont Street, Boston, ca.1843 (Museum of Fine Arts, Boston)]]
The '''Tremont Theatre''' (1827–1843) on 88 [[Tremont Street]] was a [[theatre|playhouse]] in [[Boston]]. A group of wealthy Boston residents financed the building's construction. Architect [[Isaiah Rogers]] designed the original Theatre structure in 1827 in the [[Greek Revival architecture|Greek Revival]] style. The playhouse opened on 24 September 1827.<ref>Bowen's picture of Boston. 1838</ref>
==History== In the early part of the 19th Century, Boston was still a small town, not yet the bustling metropolis it is today. The town already had one playhouse, the [[Federal Street Theatre]], and the city's small population made supporting a second theatre difficult.<ref name="Banham 1122">Banham 1122.</ref> The owners tried to bring in patrons by booking big-name performers. These included [[Junius Brutus Booth]], [[Charlotte Cushman]], [[George Washington Dixon]], [[Fanny Elssler]], [[Edwin Forrest]], [[John Gilbert (actor)|John Gilbert]], [[Charles Kemble|Charles]] and [[Fanny Kemble]], and [[Thomas D. Rice]]. Nevertheless, the Tremont never turned a profit during its 16-year life.<ref name="Banham 1122"/>
Around 1829 Tom Comer served as musical director.<ref>Tom Comer (1790–1862); cf. Daily Picayune (New Orleans); Date: 08-14-1862</ref>
On 28 December 1843, the [[Free Church Baptists]] bought the theatre and renamed it the [[Tremont Temple]]. Although the building was largely used for religious events after this, it still served as the venue for public events on occasion.
==Image gallery== <gallery> Image:TremontTheatre Bowen PictureOfBoston 1838.png|Tremont Theatre, ca.1838 Image:1842 TremontTheatre BostonDailyAtlas April4.png|Advertisement for "Bubbles of the Day," 1842 Image:1843 TremontTheatre Feb16 DailyAtlas Boston.png|Advertisement for "Timour the Tartar" and "Cavern of Death," 1843 Image:1843 circus TremontTheatre Boston DailyAtlas March14.png|Advertisement for Olympic Circus, 1843 </gallery>
==See also== * [[Tremont Temple]], est.1843
==External links== {{Commons category|Tremont Theatre, Boston (1827–1843)}} *Map: {{Coord|42|21|27|N|71|03|39|W|format=dms|display=inline,title|type:landmark_region:US-MA}} * Boston Public Library. [http://www.bpl.org/research/special/collections.htm Tremont Theatre Archives], 1839–1843
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Banham, Martin (1998). [https://books.google.com/books?id=_MxJbvpz_rwC&printsec=frontcover ''The Cambridge Guide to Theatre'']. New York: Cambridge University Press. Cf. especially p. 1122, article on the "Tremont Theatre". * Kilde, Jeanne Halgren (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=eYNjS56yx-0C&printsec=frontcover ''When Church Became Theatre: The Transformation of Evangelical Architecture and Worship in Nineteenth-Century America'']. New York: Oxford University Press. Cf. especially p. 142 * Savage, Edward H. (1865). [https://books.google.com/books?id=PnZCAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover ''A Chronological History of the Boston Watch and Police, from 1631 to 1865: Together with Recollections of a Boston Police Officer, or Boston by Daylight and Gaslight.: From the Diary of an Officer Fifteen Years in the Service'']. Boston. Cf. p. 82, &c. * Shand-Tucci, Douglass (1999). [https://books.google.com/books?id=pE-raWX3k8kC&printsec=frontcover ''Built in Boston: City and Suburb, 1800–2000'']. Amherst: [[University of Massachusetts Press]]. Cf. pp. 153, 177, 182, 207, 209, &c.
